title: RAIDING A BABOON CAMP with Hadza Hunter-Gatherers in Tanzania
description:
The Hadza Tribe or Hadzabe are a remote African Tribe of Hunter-Gatherers in Tanzania.
They live off a diet of plants and animals, eating only what they catch. There are only about 1200 left in existence, and of those, only 400 live traditionally. The Hadza tribe we hunt with are of this small group.

I was fortunate to join them for 2 days in an attempt to catch baboon. Normally in these circumstances, not much is caught. We didn't stop catching animals for 2 days.

My Secrets on How I Discover & Film Lost Tribes: 
https://www.fearlessandfar.com/tribes

title: LIVING A WEEK with the DEATH TRIBE of Indonesia
description:
This is Tana Toraja, also known as "The Land of the Dead" 
In the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, the Torajan people have some of the music elaborate funeral rituals on the planet. They are one of must unique tribes I've ever come across. After experiencing death in my own life, I wanted to tackle the discomfort head on, and went out in search of answers.

title: CATCHING BABOONS with the HADZA PEOPLE (We finally got them)
description:
The Hadza People are a remote African Tribe of Hunter-Gatherers in Tanzania. A few months ago, I was lucky to enough to be able to join them on a hunt for baboons. We didn't catch any, so we decided to return to try again. This time for a 72 hour hunting trek, deep into the African bush.

The experience I had, was one of the most intense of my life. These people are amazing, and I'm so fortunate to be able to share this with you on Youtube. Enjoy.

title: WHANG OD Tattoo... GONE WILD? üòÆKalinga Tattoo Philippines travel vlog 2018
description:
https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

In this Philippines travel vlog, I head to Kalinga in northern Luzon to find the tattoo artist legend Apo Whang Od. The last mambatok, a style of traditional tattoo found only in the Philippines.

The people of Kalinga were head hunters. Buscalan, the home of Wang Od was particularly famous for their strange tradition of tattooing. They thought tattoos were beautiful, and the women would cover themselves in full body tattoos to attract men. The men however, would have to earn their tattoos by bringing back the heads of rival tribes. The more ink, the greater the warrior.

After being featured recently in a documentary, and multiple TV shows, visiting Whang-Od and her granddaughters has become a tourist attraction. Many people make the trip from Manila to receive one.

It's about a 12h bus ride north of Manila to Sagada, from there, it's another 4 hours to the trail to Buscalan, then an hour walk.

To my filipino and filipina fans. Would do you get a tattoo from Apo Whang Od? 

Big thanks to my friends Joan of Art, Ken's life Journey, and Hannah for all the help organizing this trip!

title: Painful RITES of PASSAGE with the MURSI TRIBE
description:
The Mursi of Ethiopia are known as one of the most dangerous African Tribes.
Living in the Lower Omo Valley, this area has undergone a lot of pressure over the years.

In this video we cover ourselves in a bit of cow dung and scars. We dive deep into Mursi culture and talk about rites of passage, the ethics of lip plates, arranged marriage, and whether this is the most dangerous tribe in the Africa

title: LOST in CONGO and Trading a CROCODILE for a Bed
description:
Sometimes adventures don‚Äôt go as planned‚Ä¶ After being labeled as spies in the heart of the Democratic Republic of Congo, we fled on motorbikes to the border of the province. Along the way, we ran out of food, and had to buy what we could find from the locals. This is Pygmy Tribe territory, and many eat bush meat.

We bought a crocodile before flooding our motorbikes a few kilometers later. The sun was setting, we were stuck, so we went the the nearest village with an offer‚Ä¶ our crocodile for a night stay in their village. They accepted. I learned this tribe knew how to party. We chopped up the croc, showed each other some dance moves, and slept in straw huts over the Congo River. I can‚Äôt make this sh*t up.

You can‚Äôt pay for travel moments like this. They land on your lap, and you make a choice‚Ä¶ Let the experience lead you, trust that the world is kind, and open yourself up to the world. Or close yourself off, pity yourself, and curse your bad luck. It‚Äôs always your choice. üêâ

‚ÄúAn inconvenience is only an adventure wrongly considered.‚Äù - G.K. Chesterton

#congo #travel #fearlessandfar

title: Philippines STRANGEST food! ETAG in Sagada | Travel Philippines Vlog
description:
I'm a huge fan of Filipino food. Street food in the Philippines is some of my favourite because a lot of it is so different interesting, and tasty. 
As a foreigner in the Philippines...Why go to a Filipino restaurant when you can get delicious Pinoy street food, and be eating Balut, Isaw, and other strange foods? Manila especially is great for this!

Just a few days before getting my Kalinga Tattoo from Whang Od in Buscalan we visited an Igorot village elder to get his permission to visit his ancestors at a hanging coffin site in Sagada. He was smoking a very important type of Igorot food called Etag. Etag is used in ceremonies in this part of the Philippines, I was interested in trying it because the traditional way of preserving it, invited maggots, beatles and all other sorts of insects into the process. 

I'm so happy I was able to spend such quality time with Lakay Wa-Ow, try on his ceremonial necklace, and also buy his Etag. 

I'm excited to share the second part at Amir's Birthday Party. Stay tuned!

Inspired by the Best ever food review show and their various interesting Filipino travel vlogs about foods like Catching and eating Wild Tamilok in Palawan.... Is this Philippines Strangest or Scariest Food? 

Where are my Filipino and Filipina subscribers at!? Would you try this?

title: LOST in CONGO and hunting VENOMOUS SNAKES with THE PYGMIES
description:
While in the Democratic Republic of Congo, we were invited into the forest to hunt with a group of Pygmies. This group is an African Tribe that is known for their short stature, and their hunting ability. During our adventure together, we found all sorts of things I didn't know were considered food, and also attacked by a mamba... which y'know... was fun.

This is the second part of the adventure. In the first... we had to escape a governor that labeled us spies. We bought a crocodile before flooding our motorbikes a few kilometers later. The sun was setting, we were stuck, so we went the the nearest village with an offer‚Ä¶ our crocodile for a night stay in their village. They accepted.

title: Cooking SWAMP RATS in Louisiana
description:
We're back in Louisiana! Three years have passed since I met Skeeter Ray and we cooked Crawfish Cajun style with his secret recipe. The original plan was to catch and cook Nutria, also known as Swamp Rats. An invasive species from South America, introduced for their thick valuable fur.
In this episode we finally deliver on the promise, and meet Chalyn Perez of Paloma Lake who hooks us up with a hunting experience we'll never forget.

Watch the Original: https://youtu.be/MhxtC--0_8k

Make sure to visit our friends at Paloma Lake for Hunting and Fishing trips in Louisiana! https://www.palomalakela.com/

description:

My Tanzanian friend Gumbo sent me a few videos of men doing stunts with animals. Some putting them in thier mouths, some dancing, some running... with poisonous snakes. I thought this was one of the craziest things I've ever seen in my life. I had to learn more.

title: Hunting with the Shark-Toothed Tribe of Cameroon
description:
The Baka pygmies of Cameroon are an Indigenous hunter-gatherer community living primarily in the dense rainforests of southeastern Cameroon and neighbouring regions of Central Africa. Renowned for their deep connection to the forest, the Baka sustain their livelihoods through traditional activities such as hunting, fishing, and gathering wild fruits and medicinal plants. They have a rich oral tradition, with music, dance, and storytelling central to their culture. Their polyphonic singing and yodeling are particularly famous and are often used during spiritual rituals and celebrations. Despite their remarkable resilience, the Baka face significant challenges, including deforestation, displacement, and socio-economic marginalization, which threaten their traditional way of life. Efforts to support the Baka often center around recognizing their land rights and preserving their cultural heritage.

title: GOING TO WAR with the Yanomami Tribe
description:
Deep in the rainforest you can find the Yanomami. This Amazon Tribe are an extremely isolated people living on the Border between Brazil and Venezuela. They worship nature, and blow hallucinogenic Yopo powder into their noses to go to war with demons, and cast spells on rival tribes.

I join them for 2 days hunting, fishing, and going to war in our minds.

title: Inside a GHOST TOWN of Abandoned Disney Castles
description:
Here's the Ultimate F&F Location Map!
https://fearlessandfar.mykajabi.com/getthemap

This is Burj al Babas, a ghost town of abandoned Disney castles in Turkey. A $200 Million dollar Village falling to pieces. It's a development project gone wrong.

Starting in the 2014, the ideas was to build 732 Renaissance Style Villas to appeal to rich investors in the Middle East. Originally 350 of the 587 kitsch villas were bought in the first phase. At 500,000 Dollars each (400,000 Euro), these investors were buying into a fantasy life, a Disney Land perfect paradise. Each home with a jacuzzi on each floor, an elevator, and a thermal spa. The complex housing 3 lakes, a shopping mall, mosque, pool, and golf course. The first tenants were expected summer 2020. It sounded too good to be true...

It was. Enter the Turkish real estate crisis. Enter the Cheesiness of it all.
The company went bankrupt. The place fell to ruin. 

And now we're here to explore. The very first group to get inside in years.

#Abandoned #Travel #Turkey

title: I Found REAL Voodoo in AFRICA (unbelievable)
description:
Voodoo is a deeply rooted spiritual tradition in Benin, recognized as an official religion. Originating in West Africa, it involves the worship of spirits and ancestors, rituals, drumming, and trance ceremonies. Voodoo plays a central role in West African culture, influencing art, music, and daily life.

In this adventure we travel through the underbelly of Benin, searching for a real Voodoo ritual... and I think we definitely found it.

Welcome to Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Here, there is movement called The Society of Ambience Makers and Elegant People... also known as La Sap or Sapology.
It's members obsess over style, spending a fortune on premium brands, in a city that's one of the poorest on the planet. Welcome to the world of the Congo Dandies

title: LIVING with the HIMBA TRIBE for 24 HOURS
description:
The Himba of Namibia are a semi-nomadic remote African tribe living in the dry lands off the Skeleton Coast. Like the Maasai tribes of Tanzania and Kenya, the Himba are pastoralists whose life is centred around cattle. 

In this video, we spend 24 hours living with them. A particular question follows me around the entire time... Will you be my husband?

title: SOLO CAMPING in Satan‚Äôs Castle (Gone Horribly Wrong)
description:

title: Ethiopian Raw Meat Restaurant? ü•©
Africa's SCARIEST Breakfast! Tribal Food with the Maasai in Tanzania
description:
The Maasai people are an African tribe that inhabit Tanzania and Kenya.
They have so many unique customs and traditions, and we wanted to experience them first hand.

We team up with Kiliwarrior Expeditions and embark on a 5 day trek through the Ngorongoro Highlands. To finish this experience, we attempt to summit Ol Doinyo Lengai a 3,188 m carbonite volcano.  A 6 hour, massively steep climb to the top of the Maasai Mountain of God.

If you'd like to plan your own trek, check out Kiliwarriors here: https://kiliwarriorexpeditions.com/

Also, Big love to  @Eva zu Beck  for putting up with my crazy ideas, and helping me film this video.

title: We Found a REAL Crystal Skull in Belize
description:
Go to our sponsor https://betterhelp.com/fearlessandfar for 10% off your first month of therapy with BetterHelp and get matched with a therapist who will listen and help.

Belize is famous for it's Great Blue Hole. A near perfect circle far off the coast, but did you know that it has another sinkhole, one that is even more mysterious, it's called the Black Hole.

This cave was used for Mayan Sacrifice about 1000 years ago, and together with a small band of explorers we push into it's depths to find a treasure... A Crystal Skull.

title: Visiting the LAST of the KARO TRIBE (Only 1000 left)
description:
The Karo Tribe of Ethiopia are known for their elaborate body painting. There are only 1000 members left of this African Tribe.
They live along the banks of the Lower Omo Valley, and have had a tough few decades with drought and disease affecting their cattle. They are one of the most unique tribes in Africa, and we were able to spend the day with them.

title: Camping ALONE in an ANCIENT CLIFFSIDE Monastery
description:
Hidden deep in the mountains of the Artvin province of North Eastern Turkey is an abandoned Monastery called Nukas Sakdari. These are ancient Orthodox Christian ruins built over 1000 years ago by Georgians. It's said that there are 13 different monasteries hidden in the mountains here, all connected by secret tunnels, and that Nukas Sakdari was the most important of them all.

We arrive and meet the farmer who lives next to the ruins, and a story unfolds that you'd never expect.

title: KAMB√î: THE FROG POISON RITUAL | TRADITIONAL AMAZON MEDICINE
description:
This experience is one of my favourites since I started travelling 8 years ago. 

A Kambo Cleanse is putting the poison off the back of a bright green frog into small points burned into your skin. Warriors of Amazonian tribes would use Kambo for its many benefits. After applying the poison, you get extremely sick for a short period after. Extreme fever, swelling of the face, terrible headache, vomiting, dizziness, convulsions, these are all the symptoms of Kambo.

After the short allergic reaction your body has to the poison, everything changes. All your senses are heightened. You see more clearly, your hearing improves, you can smell more of your surroundings. Also, your immune system becomes supercharged, making you able to resist infections and disease. Warriors would use Kambo for these purposes, and often apply the poison before war or a hunt.

Psychedelic 

Coming soon is the middle part of the story. The night we had before kambo. What unfolded that night was completely unexpected. I long session with the shaman and his friend, inhaling rap√© (a powder from leaves of the forest), and drinking ayahuasca. It was a warm up before the kambo the next morning, and was equally as intense.

title: SHOCKING FILIPINO BIRTHDAY FOOD | Pinikpikan in Sagada, Philippines
description:
This isn't your ordinary Philippines travel vlog. I continue my trip north of Manila in the Cordillera region of Luzon. Here I meet an Ifugao Igorot family in Sagada, and get invited to try sever tradition dishes, typical for celebrations in this area of the Philippines. Dinuguan, Etag, Pinikpikan, and more. As a foreigner in the Philippines, and a travel vlogger that will eat just about any pinoy street food... This some some of the most shocking filipino food I have come across in the country. 

This episode of my travel Philippines series takes place after meeting Lakay Wa-Ow, a village elder in Sagada. We arrived at his house to ask permission to visit the hanging coffins of his ancestors who have been places on the cliff faces, long, long ago. He granted us permission, and showed us his collection of smoked pork, called Etag. This putrefying smoked pork is covered in mold and insects, and used in ceremonies in the area. 

The next day I arrived at my guides house where I watched him prepare other traditional foods like Pinikpikan. This is a controversial chicken dish where the chicken is beaten before being killed. Its said the noises it makes attracts the spirits to notice the ceremony, and also brings more tenderness to the meat. It wasn't something for the squeamish, and this was all at a filipino birthday party!

#FearlessandFar #Luzon #Sagada

Come check out the deleted scenes, and fight your fears here: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: The Crazy EXPLODING HAMMER FESTIVAL in Guanajuato, Mexico
description:
The exploding hammer festival, or "fiesta del martillo explosivo" in spanish, is an annual festival in San Juan de la Vega, Guanajuato, Mexico. Every February 28th, thousands of people visit this small little down to see locals tape home made explosives to sledgehammers, and slam then into the ground. The explosions are huge, and injuries are very common. It's a strange festival, and one of the most dangerous in the world

This particular date, is day to celebrate San Juan Bautista, aka John the Baptist, which the town was named after. No one can remember exactly how all the exploding started... but at one point it took place inside the city. Those who participated would follow the parade in the honour of the saint, blasting the hammers to celebrate. After a lot of damage to windows, people, and cars, they moved the hammers out into a field. Here, hundreds of men can detonate their explosives slightly more safely.

For travel vloggers like myself, it's the perfect place to be able to film all the action. I was so happy that I brought my GoPro to this event. I almost left it behind in fear that the blasts would destroy it. The little things are tough, and we got some great POV video of some of the locals and their hammers. We spent a lot of our time in the beautiful city of Celaya, which is nearby the festival. Highly recommend you check it out. The tourism board there went to great lengths to help us get the best video possible of the event!

Hope you enjoy this video. I stayed up all night to edit it. I love getting these crazy festival videos up ASAP after they happen. I still have adrenaline in my system! Enjoy the Boom!

title: Feeding a Rain God in Africa
description:
Get an exclusive 15% discount on Saily eSIM data plans! Download Saily app and use code FEARLESS at checkout.

In the far north of Cameroon there is a rare African tribe called the Dupa. This hill tribe rarely gets visitors, and our arrival sparked an adventure that I could have never planned. 

The Dupa tribe, also known as the Nyem-Nyem, is an indigenous ethnic group residing in the Adamawa Region of Cameroon, particularly around the Gashaka and Mambila Plateaus. Known for their rich cultural heritage, the Dupa are skilled farmers and pastoralists, deeply connected to their environment. They cultivate crops such as millet, maize, and sorghum, and their society is structured around age-grade systems and community leadership. The tribe holds vibrant ceremonies featuring traditional music, dance, and storytelling, which serve to preserve their oral history and strengthen communal bonds. Despite modern influences, the Dupa strive to maintain their traditional way of life while navigating contemporary challenges.

title: BAHAMAS: SWIMMING PIGS ISLAND IN EXUMA!
description:
The Swimming Pigs in Exuma, Bahamas.

In the middle of the Caribbean is a tiny island called Big Major Key. On this island you can see something incredible. Swimming Pigs... the recent tv stars from the bachelor.

Cute little farm animal or sinister marine predator? You can decide, these cute little creatures have hit it big recently on the web and on TV, but when I visited Pig Beach in 2011, barely anyone had heard of them. 

We were doing a sailing boat tour of several islands and keys in Exuma. The pigs were a little pit spot because we had extra time to kill. Now people travel across the world to see them. I wonder if all their fame has gotten to their head! 

If you love funny animals, I think I know where you should travel next. This has been one of the best travel experiences of my life. It will be one for you too!

title: Travel Hacks SECRET LEGROOM BUTTON | Airport & Airplane Tips 2018
description:
Of all the travel tips and travel hacks out there, this one has been the most useful. One big problem with air travel is legroom, especially in economy class. Travel advice and flying tips are dime a dozen, but this simple travel hack with save you a lot of discomfort if you end up with a aisle seat. This is one of the best tips I've found, and one I think everyone should know.

Under the arm wrest of the aisle seat there is a secret button. Pressing this switch lifts the armrest up, and allows you to have much more leg room, and leg movement, especially when you need to exit the row. 

80% of airplanes have this feature, but unfortunately not all of them do. It is there for flight attendants to left the armrest to allow for ease of exit during an emergency, and also for the disabled. 

Travelers rejoice, those long haul flights might have gotten a little more comfortable, and air transport a little more enjoyable. It's basically one of my travel essentials now.

As a travel vlogger, this legroom button has saved my life. Enjoy one the top flight attendant secrets

title: Trying to Save a Pangolin in my Hotel Shower
description:
My adventures in The Democratic Republic of Congo went about as expected. We wanted to travel to undiscovered places for 3 weeks, and we ended up being labeled as spies, fled to the jungle, had to trade a crocodile for a bed, and got lost along the way. While in the cities, I tried to visit local markets to get a feel for the place. Near the end of the adventure, we found a Pangolin at a bush meat market. I couldn't handle watching this amazing animal die in a bag, so we tried to save it. This is that story.

Pangolins are endangered creatures, and are the most highly trafficked animals in the world. Hunted mostly for their scales on the black market, this is not what happens here. In this part of Congo, it's primarily just for food.

Maybe I could have made a better decision. Was buying the pangolin right or wrong? Was it better to try and save it, or just leave it? Let's chat in the comments.

#congo #travel #fearlessandfar

title: ONLY in the Philippines! SUNKEN CEMETERY | Camiguin Island vlog 2018
description:
Camiguin Island in the Philippines is beautiful. After making a travel vlog about the Giant Clams Sanctuary with my friend Aitz, I set my sights on the Sunken Cemetery. As a foreigner in the Philippines, this was amazing travel vlog material.

The sunken cemetery fell into the ocean with the 1871 eruption of Mount Vulcan. It was built by the spanish, and has seen a lot of destruction over the years. More eruptions, typhoons, and tsunamis have turned this beautiful graveyard into rubble, leaving only a few relics under water.

This Philippines travel vlog was recorded after leaving my expat friends Kulas of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finnsnow, Bret Maverick, and the fighterboys in Cagayan de Oro, CDO, and continuing for a mini adventure in Northern Mindanao

title: GETTING A FULL SLEEVE SACRED GEOMETRY TATTOO IN MEXICO CITY
description:
I've been thinking about this for years. Getting my first sleeve tattoo is a big step in a direction I've been wanted to take for a while.

When thinking of travel tattoo ideas, I wanted to pass on the airplanes, maps, and compasses. I wanted to think a bit outside the box, and think of something with a deeper meaning to me. I settled on a flower of life inspired, sacred geometry tattoo because I feel it encompasses how I feel about the world. The concept unites us all together. This video is about getting a geometric tattoo design for men.

The big idea behind sacred geometry is that we're all connected on a fundamental level through the same building blocks. After travelling the world for 8 years, I can't agree more. We're born into societies that make us think that a kid from North America is very different from a kid from China. But, when you begin to explore the world, you breakdown the barrier that has been created by language and culture. You see each person as just another human with exactly the same wants and needs as you. We're all in this together. Fighting the same battles, dealing with the same worries, taking pleasure in the same joys.

Travelling makes us realize this, and I wish that more people could realize the world is this way.

What do you guys think? Would you get one? Are tattoos worth it? Are they safe? Let's chat in the comments, let me know if you have any tattoos! Hope you enjoyed this behind the scenes look!

title: [4K Drone] Darvaza Gas Crater (The Door to Hell) Turkmenistan
description:
We captured so much incredible footage on our last trip to Turkmenistan, I thought I'd make a little 4K DJI Drone montage video of the door to hell. The gates of hell. Darvaza Gas Crater. Derweze. Call it what you want.

Turkmenistan is built on natural gas. I mean this literally and figuratively. In the vast arid Karakum desert lies the 4th largest natural gas deposit in the world.

The Darvaza Crater was a mining disaster. So they think. No one really knows, as I don‚Äôt believe there were any survivors. In 1971 a soviet mining operation punctured the eggshell surface and fell into a pit. Years later, someone lit a match, and Bang! Welcome to the door to hell. 

This is the main attraction in Turkmenistan, and our plan was to roast marshmallows over it. If you missed that travel vlog, you'll want to check it out: https://youtu.be/MhkLTUvBlX8

As the president has opened up the country slightly over the years, it is now possible to visit. I'd recommend getting there in 2020. There are still very very few tourists here. 

Also! Free Travel video tips video is here.

title: Inside Nigeria's Dangerous Floating Slum
description:
Makoko is a sprawling, self-built community on stilts, often dubbed the ‚ÄúVenice of Africa.‚Äù Home to an estimated 85,000 to 250,000 people, Makoko is a world apart: a maze of wooden homes, narrow waterways, and dugout canoes, where fishing is the lifeblood and resilience is a way of life.‚Äã

But life here is dangerous. Residents face constant threats of eviction, lack access to clean water and sanitation, and live under the shadow of government demolition efforts. Despite this, Makoko thrives.

In this video, we navigate the canals of Makoko, meet the people who call it home, and explore the challenges and ingenuity that define this remarkable floating slum.‚Äã

title: THE GLOWING BIO BAY IN VIEQUES PUERTO RICO
description:
Mosquito Bay or Bio Bay in Vieques, Puerto Rico is an amazing place. It is the brightest glowing bioluminescent bay in the world. I jumped on a few kayak tours during the night of a new moon and saw this incredible light show.

Honestly, it was more amazing that I imagined. I had read a review or two, but wasn't sure if it was worth the trip to the island. It was. The bay is extremely bright, and until now, it was very hard to capture on camera. I recently picked up a Sony a7s which is a beast in low light, and was impressed with that it could capture. This has rarely ever been caught on Camera. 

The government is doing a good job at keeping this place pristine. In some areas of the world you can jump in, splash around, use gasoline engines, and generally just destroy the ecosystem these little guys live in. Here in Vieques, Puerto Rico, you are not allowed to swim, or use gasoline. Nearby light pollution has to be kept to a minimum, and there give Bio Bay some days off now and again to recover. This is probably why it remains the brightest in the world. High Five for sustainable eco tourism. I wish everywhere was this forward thinking. 

This was one of my best travel experiences. Like I said, it's worth the trip!

More Underwater Adventures: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi386Ue50lt7tcO9RmkgLEQb

title: Overnight in Venezuela's Most Remote Fishing Shack
description:
In this adventure, we're in Venezuela to camp in an abandoned fisherman shack.

Los Roques is an archipelago off the coast of Venezuela, famous for its turquoise waters, pristine beaches, and abundant marine life. Comprising over 300 islands and cays, it's a popular destination for kite surfing, diving, and eco-tourism, drawing adventurers and nature enthusiasts alike. 

The Palafito is a unique stilted lodge located in Los Roques, built over the water in traditional Venezuelan style. It's used as temporary lodging for fishermen during lobster season, and also seems like an epic place to camp.

title: Mexico's INSANE Bulls of Fire Festival (Got Burned)
description:
The Bulls of Fire have many names; ‚ÄúToros de Fuego, ‚ÄúToros de fuegos artificiales‚Äù, or simply ‚ÄúToritos‚Äù aka ‚Äúlittle bulls‚Äù. Tultepec, a small town in the State of Mexico has fully embraced these spinning firework covered paper animals, to the point that over 500 will be lit on fire for this year‚Äôs 2018 Feria Nacional de la Pirotecnia, The Mexican National Pyrotechnic Festival. One of the craziest festivals I have ever been to.

Every year just an hour north of Mexico City, Tultepec has this 10 day festival celebrating the patron saint of Fireworks, Juan de Dios.
This community is known throughout the country for it‚Äôs homemade fireworks. Most families here have ties to the pyrotechnic industry, and it is evident, as many wear the scars of their work proudly.

Originally from Spain, the Fire Bulls can be seen across Latin America under the name Vaca Locas or Crazy Cows. The origin of the bulls is thought to have been a spin off of the actual Bulls of Fire, where wicks are tied to the horns of real animals.

Honestly, I‚Äôm not sure which is more dangerous. Running from a single angry bull with two horns of fire, or from 20 drunk men pushing a paper-made, rocket covered bull the size of a bus‚Ä¶ both I‚Äôm sure get the adrenaline flowing pretty fast. 

Family, neighbourhoods, and friends get together to make these beautiful creations and parade them through the town before the big event later that night. In the video you can see two things, that the festival is quite dangerous, and that the people were incredibly friendly. We felt like family, and were approached countless times for pictures, smiles, and glasses of Pulque (a fermented cactus drink). Mexico knows how to make you feel like home.

Attending this event will be a memory that will be with me for the rest of my life. Enjoy this adventure travel vlog. I sure did!

title: MY FIRST LECHON + Taking a Life üò£| Filipino food vlog | MINDANAO Philippines
description:
Filipino food is very diverse. From the street food in Manila, to the seafood on the coast, there's one food that wins the contest for most filipino of them all. When you travel Philippines, you see Lechon everywhere.

I had never had this Iconic Pinoy food yet, and while travelling Mindanao with the fighter boys, a unique opportunity came our way. 

Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, and Bret Maverick and I were in Marihatag in Surigao del Sur. There was a little local festival happening and a lechon was going to be prepared, and if we wanted, we could slaughter the pig.

This immediately polarized the group. Killing animals for fun is wrong and immoral, no one wants to watch it, let alone do it. 

But... Every time we choose to eat meat. A steak, a piece of fried chicken, a hotdog, an animal dies. Some of these animals live happy lives where they are free to roam, and others live horrible lives inside filthy cages. If we eat fast food, we promote this terrible way of treating life, if we eat lechon (or hunt) we promote the first way, the natural and free way. So then which is worse?

Either way, an animal lives and dies to feed another animal. If you choose to eat meat, shouldn't you understand this? Shouldn't you put the connection of a life to your choice? Bacon is not a vegetable, but it's treated that way when we buy it in the supermarket. Shouldn't we think about it differently?

These were all the questions ringing through my head, and this is why I chose to do it. To understand the consequences of eating meat, and to help guide my future decisions. The question I have for you is, what would you do?

For more behind the scenes, checn out: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: Freight Train Hopping in West Africa (Dangerous)
description:
We're train surfing the longest train in the world. The Mauritania Railway.

The Sahara Freight crosses 700km of desert (430 miles) in West Africa, picking up iron ore from the mining town of Zouerat, and dropping it off at the coastal town of Nouadibou since 1963. This Sahara railway is one of the most extreme in the world. It's been called Africa's Worst Train, and for train surfing, it's the ride of a lifetime. The Mauritania Railway is one of a kind.

Just sneaking into the train was an adventure enough. Taking a public bus to Zouerat and trying to negotiate and navigate to the right location. There is no train schedule, just a rough 2 hour window when people expect to see the train. Also, the journey can take anywhere from 16 to 24 hours to complete. Locals ride in the cars as a fast and easy (yeah, believe that) way to cross into the interior of the country from the coast. While where are no clear rules whether it is legal or not, it is tolerated, and has become a common method of transportation across the county.

Would you ride this crazy train in Africa?

title: THAILAND: VEGETARIAN FESTIVAL PHUKET
description:
The vegetarian festival in Phuket isn't what it sounds like. In fact most vegetarians would stay far away from what happens here. I didn't know what to expect, but this ended up being one of the best travel experiences of my life. 

Apparently it all started a thousand years ago when an opera group from China travelled to Phuket, Thailand for a show. They became sick, and the locals suggested to wear white and eat vegetarian food as a remedy. It worked, and that's how the festival started.

How it cascaded into a piercing, possession, and pain tolerance festival, I don't know, nor could I find much solid information on it. It seems the local Chinese are the ones who take part in the sacred rituals and it's said they do it to be blessed with good fortune.

I'll take their word for it...

If you're travelling in South East Asia, keep an eye out for this crazy festival. There are versions of it in Cambodia, Myanmar, and I believe Singapore. 


Enjoy this special scary halloween travel video!

title: DAY OF THE DEAD PARADE MEXICO CITY
description:
The Day of the Dead Festival in Mexico is an amazing event. In 2016, Mexico City held it's first ever parade. La desfile de Dia de Muertos. There was an insane amount of people there, with the advice from some friends, I tried to get into the press area. The bouncer said a flat "No". I kept asking, and some of the locals began chanting "Let him in, Let him in", the guy opened the gate, and here we are. I was basically in the Parade. This is why I love travel!

Music, Costumes, Floats, Dancing, it was an incredible fiesta.

Personally, I'm used to celebrating Halloween, but they take it to the next level with Day of the Dead. Families from all over Mexico celebrate the lives of those who have passed away, and give offerings to help them in the afterlife. Over the past few years (with the help of Spectre, the James Bond movie) Dia de Muertos has now become an international sensation, with people from all over the world dressing up as the female skeleton La Calavera Catrina for Halloween.

Being able to produce this was a surprise. I rushed to get it posted. This just happened a few hours ago. Enjoy!

title: Living 24 Hours with a Berbers Tribe (North Africa)
description:
The Berbers are nomads, wandering through the dunes of the Sahara, all over North Africa. Common in Morocco, these nomadic people have a unique way of life. I join Eva Zubeck and we join a berber family for 24 hours.

This is my first encounter with Berbers, and I learned a lot... like how a goatskin is a great place to keep milk cool, and you can cook bread in sand. Yum, crunchy.

title: We Found the Keys to an Abandoned Mausoleum in Romania
description:
Today we're exploring an abandoned mausoleum turned cathedral laying in the far west of Romania. It's name is Mausoleul Cs√°vossy.

While it might look very much like a summer home for residents of Dracula's Castle in Transylvania, this old building led us down quite a crazy story. We arrived looking for the keys to get inside. It was locked up tight. Some local ladies said that someone did have a key, an old man who lived with "The Woman who cut Foreheads"... Huh?

This video is the story of that day, twisting and spiralling into an adventure we didn't expect, and making a grave mistake that cost us later.

A massive thanks for my man Ursu (The Bear) for the experience!

title: DEEP Inside the World of VOODOO WRESTLING in Congo
description:
Voodoo wrestling, or Catch F√©tiche is a popular sport in The Democratic Republic of Congo.
It's like the WWE meets Harry Potter, you wrestle each other in a ring with magic spells.
Voodoo is actually a West African term, here it is called Bokoko, and is very similar. It taps into the ancient energy of your ancestors, and often fetishes like skulls and desiccated animals are used in the rituals.

Catch F√©tiche was born when traditional beliefs were fused into Catch Congolais, an American-Wrestling inspired sport adapted to Congo. But when Bokoko became involved, it evolved into something completely different. Enjoy this one! It's a trip. (Bonus points if you spotted Ekeko from the Sapeur video)

The final battle was wayyyy too graphic for YouTube... and while the death of "Zombie" was fake, the guts she ate were very real. Believe me... I was so close I could smell them. 

The full Uncut & Uncensored version is here: https://www.patreon.com/posts/62580318

title: Getting a SAK YANT TATTOO in Chiang Mai, Thailand 2019
description:
Book a Sak Yant Tattoo Tour here: http://bit.ly/FaF-SakYant
Yants are an integral part of Thai culture. You see these magical symbols everywhere; on amulets, in taxis, storefronts, and etched in skin.

Sak means to tap, and Sak Yant tattooing is the process of getting any of the thousands of sacred symbols tapped into your skin with magical ink. In this Thailand travel vlog, a leave from Bangkok to travel north to Chiang Mai to join a Sak Yant Tattoo tour with Where Sidewalks End. This is a special type of traditional tattoo. Why getting a bamboo tattoo done by hand poke style is very common. This is much more sacred.

Previous to this experience, I visited a very famous tattoo temple called Wat Bang Phra just outside of Bangkok, Thailand. Here, the famous Wai Kru Tattoo festival happens every year, Thousands of devotees return to this location to honor their Ajarn, and to recharge the power of their Sak Yants. I received my Gao Yord thai tattoos there.

In Chiang Mai Ajarn Rung gives me the Paed Tidt tattoo, along with the Silver Tongue Magpies. The 8 directions enchantments means many things, but above all, safety while travelling. The magpies, make your speech more influential. Both solid enchantments for any travel vlogger.

title: I WASN'T READY FOR THIS üòµTrying MOMA | Philippines travel vlog
description:
In the Philippines travel vlog, we begin our search for the Hanging Coffins of Sagada. I meet my guide Chris and we make a quick stop to have some Moma before trekking into the forests. My first week in the Philippines has been such an adventure. There is so much to see here!

As a foreigner in the Philippines, I had never heard of this strange combination of plants called Moma. Areca nut can be found in a lot of places in the world. You can usually see the orange smiles on the people, or the stains in the street. While similar to the Betel nut I had once in Indonesia, this was a different leaf and contained tobacco.

I thought I was ready for this experience, but immediately felt hot, sweaty, and shaky. My whole body started to buzz with electricity, and my heart started to race. The locals do this all day long, but I could barely handle myself. I ended up gagging in the bushes and had to lay down. It was INTENSE.

To my Filipino and Filipina fans. Would you try this? Would you make the trip up from Manila Philippines to see the coffins?

title: 24 HOURS WITH REMOTE SIBERIAN TRIBE in Buryatia, Russia
description:
We've finally made it to Siberia on the Trans-Siberian Railway!
Our first adventure was arriving in Ulan-Ude, near Lake Baikal, and driving hundreds of kilometres into the wilderness to meet a remote Siberian tribe in Buryatia, Russia. 

Buryatia is one of Russia's most unique republics. It has a mongol heritage, and the people who live here are descendants of the Golden Horde. The landscape is called The Steppe, a vast sweeping grassland that covers central Asia. Tribes who live here have traditionally been nomadic, making small camps like the one we stay in. This is our documentary of 24 hours with this tribe.

This experience put us outside our comfort zones. We ate some interesting Russian food like raw sheep liver, rode horses, wrestled, and had the time of our lives. While this experience isn't for everyone, it's definitely for me. This was one of my favourite days on the Trans-Siberian Railway. The people we met in this small village made it especially memorable. You can tell by their faces, that they are kind and generous. We felt right at home in this remote part of Russia.

NOTICE: I had to censor and remove a lot of the content in this video. 
If you want to see the unedited scenes, It's all on Patreon üí™üèª
Support F&F - Watch it here: https://www.patreon.com/posts/ive-seen-some-48-30780887

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok.

title: Eating the Spiciest Pepper in the Philippines with the Fighter Boys
description:
The Fighter Boys are back in 2020 for season three in the Philippines!
In the last episode, we breathe fire. In this episode, it's almost the same.
We‚Äôre in the Bicol Region on the search for the spiciest chili in the Philippines. There are many chilies in this part of the country, and I‚Äôm sure you could find some of the hottest in the world like the Carolina Reaper, Habaneros, and many more. But we‚Äôre after the spiciest Native Chili which comes in 2 varieties Sili Labuyo, and Sili Mahaba. The plan is to do a spicy challenge with the Fighter Boys.

Chilies are rated in Scoville units. For comparison 
Jalape√±os are 2000 to 8000 Scoville units of spice.
Sili Labuyo is 80,000 to 100,000 Scoville units.
Habanero is 100,000 to 350,000
Carolina reaper is 1,000,000+

While not the hottest in the world, these spicy chilies definitely pack a punch.

To end the video, we end up trying another spicy challenge at 1st Colonial grill sili chili icecream. I join Bret Maverick, Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, and Finn Snow in this spicy food challenge!

title: HIV from Tattooing? | Is a Traditional Tattoo safe? Philippines travel vlog
description:
The number one comment on my Apo Whang-Od Tattoo video has been about HIV. I've decided to make a video about it. Is Traditional Tattooing safe? Can you get HIV from tattooing?

7 years ago I visited Wat Bang Pra near Bangkok to get a Sak Yant, a traditional Thai Tattoo. Here I met Luang Pi-Nunn and received a Gao Yord, and several other patterns tattooed on my back in a very similar manner to Bamboo Tattoo. I've always heard about the risks of tattooing, and decided to do more research about is tattooing safe.

What was interesting to me was the idea of a "reservoir" inside a needle. A hollow area where blood can stay between users of that needle. In a tattoo gun or a syringe, this exists, and a significant amount of blood can be passed from person to person. In a thorn, bamboo spike, or metal rod, this does not, and drastically reduces the quantity of blood passed from person to person.

This DOES NOT ELIMINATE the risks however, and I strongly recommend you doing your own research before diving into these experiences yourself. I am not a doctor, nor an expert on this matter.

I hope you enjoyed this Behind the Scenes Philippines travel vlog. This was one of my favourite experiences.

title: EATING ISAW (Intestines) | FILIPINO STREET FOOD | Davao City Mindanao
description:
Filipino food is some of the most unique on the planet. Balut especially is a world wide shocker, and a must try if you do travel in the Philippines. However, I noticed quite quickly while traveling through the Roxas Night Market in Davao City, Mindanao. I also saw it while exploring Manila street food. There is another equally strange and common street food in the Philippines, and perhaps it's more widely loved. It's called Isaw AKA BBQ chicken intestines.

Kyle Jennermann of Becomingfilipino told me about Roxas market being a great spot for a Philippines travel vlog, and indeed it was. This was Pinoy street food heaven. Lines and lines of stall all selling a variety of Filipino snacks. Before coming to the Philippines I had made a list of food to try by watching Best Food Review Show Ever and Mark Weins travel videos. I was not disappointed when I saw many of them here.

As a foreigner in the Philippines, I didn't think I would like intestines. It turns out... they are pretty great!

Check out my BTS videos here! https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: RAP√â & AYAHUASCA RITUAL | TRADITIONAL AMAZON MEDICINE
description:
This is part II of our experience in the rainforests of Brazil, experiencing traditional amazon medicine with a shaman of the Marubu tribe.

During this experience we were allowed to try and film 3 types of jungle remedies; Ayahuasca, Kambo, and Rap√©.

Rap√© is an extremely common practice in many types of ceremonies. A hollow bone is used as a type of pipe to blow a complex combination of pulverized jungle plants into the nose. This powder can be many things, but often the base ingredient is a type of tobacco that is 20 times more potent than the one found in cigarettes. It is used to purify the mind. It cleanses the illness and clutter that blocks us from seeing the truth of our intentions. 

Also used in this ceremony was Ayahuasca, which is a concoction of fermented herbs which allows the user to see the fabric of the universe, giving powerful and colourful hallucinations. However in this instance it was a mild version of this psychedelic mixture used to balance the intensity of the Rap√©.

If you haven't seen the other part to this story, please watch the Kambo: Frog Poison Ritual episode. This is where the story picks up after this video ends.

This experience is one of my favourites since I started travelling 8 years ago.

title: UNSEEN HANGING COFFINS (First YouTube Footage) üíÄSagada, Philippines
description:
The final chapter in my Philippines travel vlog series of exploring the mountain province in Cordillera, Northern Luzon. You're going love love what we found.

We're on the search for hanging coffins in Sagada. As a foreigner in the Philippines, I was told I should go to echo valley to see the famous hanging coffins of the Igorot people. This area gets hundreds of Filipino tourists from Manila, Baguio City, and across the country every day. On Fearless & Far, we're always on the search for the next level. The deeper experience. The adventure that challenges us.
I met up with my guide Chris and Angdung and we grabbed our machetes and hiking boots, and dove into the jungle. Looking for other sites that others have not visited in a long long time. We found exactly that.

The unique death rituals of the mountain people of Cordillera are not for the squeamish.In all my philippines travel vlog experiences, this was perhaps the most shocking and interesting topic I have come across.  

While there are hanging coffins in China, and also similar practices in Indonesia, there's nothing quite like what happens here in Sagada, Mountain Province.

#FearlessandFar #Philippines #Sagada

title: Roasting Marshmallows Over the Door to Hell - Darvaza Gas Crater, Turkmenistan
description:
The door to hell. The gates of hell. Darvaza Gas Crater. Derweze.
These are all names for the main attraction in Turkmenistan, and in this travel vlog, we take this adventure to a whole new level.

Turkmenistan is built on methane. I mean this literally and figuratively. In the vast arid deserts of the country lie the 4th largest natural gas deposits in the world, and this is the cash cow that makes the capital Ashgabat, sparkle with gold and marble.

The Darvaza Crater was a mining disaster. So they think. No one really knows, as I don‚Äôt believe there were any survivors. In 1971 a soviet mining operation punctured the eggshell surface of a potential gas deposit in the middle of the Karakum desert, and fell into a pit. Years later, someone lit a match, and Bang! Welcome to the door to hell. 

Put this location on your bucket list for 2020. It's worth the three hour drive north from Ashgabat. The new president Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov has opened up the country much more than it used to be. Getting the VISA wasn't a walk in the park, but our friends at Lupine Travel set everything up for us.. Check out their trips to some of the lesser travelled countries!

For some Behind the Scenes videos about Turkmenistan, check out my Patreon:

https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

#FearlessandFar #Turkmenistan #Travel

title: Burying Myself in Sand for 24h in the Philippines
description:
This is a 24h Challenge that pushed me to my limit. While exploring the Philippines with the Fighterboys (A group of Expat YouTubers) I spent the night buried alive on the beach up to my neck. These types of challenges were made popular by MrBeast, but this one had a bit of a deeper meaning, and unfortunately there was no last one wins $10,000 dollar prize. (this time)
I wanted to try this crazy idea called voluntary discomfort.

By putting yourself through hard times on purpose, so when life comes knocking with a bag of bricks, you're ready.

People have coined this the Beach Challenge.
It was hard. It was painful. And you'll have to see if I made it through.

HELP ME BUY 10,000 BANANAS FOR KIDS IN NEED: https://www.gofundme.com/f/10000-Bananas

If you want to learn a bit more about why I did it, and what happened inside my head, check out this Patreon video I made about it: https://www.patreon.com/posts/34259977

title: Inside a Rare Face-Scarring Ceremony in Cameroon
description:
The Mbororo tribe, a semi-nomadic subgroup of the Fulani people, are pastoralists renowned for their dedication to cattle herding, which is central to their livelihood and culture. Predominantly found in Central and West Africa, they are known for their striking appearance, colorful traditional attire, and unique blend of Islamic faith with animist traditions. Organized into clans, their society emphasizes strong kinship ties, traditional gender roles, and cattle-centered rituals. Despite their rich cultural heritage, the Mbororo face challenges like land disputes, marginalization, and the pressures of modernization, which threaten their traditional way of life.

Big love to Last Places Travel for putting this WILD trip together for us:

title: Spending $20 at a Turkmenistan Market
description:
Ashgabat Turkmenistan is a strange place. I have never seen so much gold and marble in my life, but the streets seemed empty. In this Turkmenistan travel vlog, I join my friend Lexie Alford and make a trip to a local Turkmen market called the Russian Bazaar. Here, we tried street food, interacted with the locals, and witnessed some real culture.

I say real culture, because Turkmenistan is known as the North Korea of Central Asia. The president Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow has a tight grip on the country, and it's very hard to get off the normal tourist path. 

Beside our hotel was a local market, we asked our guide if we could visit, and he said if we really wanted to we could, but not to bring a camera because of police. The locals had been so nice to us, so thought we would take a small chance.

One more thing to note. After I posted the first Turkmenistan travel vlog in Ashgabat, I had said that we had our US dollars exchanged to Turkmen Manat at 1 to 13. Locals commented that it's actually suppose to be 1 to 20. It's funny though, from an atm it's 1 to 3.5.
Very happy we got our money on the black market.

title: MINDANAO'S Best Kept Secret | MATIGOL FALLS | North Cotabato Philippines
description:
MIndanao has been amazing! In this Philippines travel vlog, myself, Finn Snow, Daniel Marsh, Becoming Filipino, and Bret Maverick AKA the Fighter Boys head to North Cotabato in search of waterfalls.

In all my years of a travel vlogger, I've never seen anything like this. 500m meters of falls and pools, with only a few locals there. We were quite sure so one had brought drones and cameras to make a travel vlog or take pictures before. We basically had this amazing filipino waterfall to ourselves.

While we didn't have time to explore everything, a local came to show us how one of the falls can be used as a waterslide. That changed the day. It was a ton of fun. This place was called Matigol Falls.

title: ABANDONED BEACH MANSION | Exploring El Partenon de NEGRO DURAZO Mexico 2018
description:
This is the top spot for urban exploration in Mexico. El parten√≥n de Negro Durazo is an abandoned mansion on the coast of Zihuatanejo, Guerrero, Mexico. This building was the party home of the corrupt police chief, Arturo Durazo Moreno. Nicknamed "The Black" Durazo, he stole millions of taxpayer money to build extravagant homes all over the country. Exploring this abandoned millionaires mansion has been on my to-do list for years. I teamed up with my travel vlogger bro Exploring with Cody, and Actress Mariannela Cata√±o to make this happen. This is one of Mexico's most famous abandoned places!

Negro Durazo was Mexico City's Chief of Police from 1976 to 1982. The beach mansion was constructed in 1979, and abandoned only a few years later. The Partenon was constructed to look similar to the actual Parthenon inside the greek Acropolis in Athens. Negro Durazo only had a couple years of partying before being caught and locked up. He spent 10 years in jail, and then died in the year 2000. The abandoned home has been shut down since 1985. That's 32 years ago. I was it had everything still inside! 

Scary? Creepy? Cool? Let us know what you think about this travel vlog of this abandoned mansion on the coast of Zihuatanejo / Ixtapa!

title: Mexico City WITCHCRAFT Market üíÄ(PART 1) | Mercado Sonora with MARIEL DE VIAJE
description:
Mexico City is filled with markets. Street food especially. But today I teamed up with Mariel de Viaje for something different. A witch craft market named Mercado Sonora. We wanted a special kind of cleanse... one that involved our spirit. Called a "Limpia con Huevo"

Mercado Sonora is in the South East of Mexico City, in a neighbourhood called Merced Balbuena. To the average person, it appears to be a normal place. Food, clowns, toys, clothing, are all lined up in perfect aisles. If you head to the back, and follow your nose, you can find a section that is not for everyone...

This is the Witchcraft market of Mexico City. It's filled with all sorts of magic and medicine. Dried stingrays and armadillos hang from the ceiling. Signs for encapsulated skunk and rattle snake posted on the walls. Hundreds of candles line the walls offering spells to increase your sex drive and break up lovers. 

"Que Buscabas?" Is what you hear from every shopkeeper. "What are you looking for?" they ask.

This is a deeper question than it first appears. It's not cutlery, or vegetables they are offering. Here in mercado sonora they are selling you, happiness, good luck, love... everything you could possibly want in life.

We were on a search for a "Limpia" a cleaning of the soul. A spirit cleanse you could call it. There are many different kinds, but we were looking for one where an egg is rubbed over the body, absorbing the bad energy from your spirit.

This area of CDMX isn't particularly safe, and it is very forbidden to film inside the market. We had to go incognito on our cellphones.

I met up with my travel vlogger friend Mariel de Viaje and we entered. 

It ended with a hilarious surprise. We may need to go back again to Mercado Sonora afterall

title: I Lived With a Reindeer Tribe in Mongolia‚Äôs Frozen North
description:
Want to do your own 4x4 Trip of Mongolia? Check out https://themongoliatour.com/. Love the winter? Do this trip at this link https://themongoliatour.com/tours/mongolia-winter-offroad-tour/

UNCENSORED VERSION HERE: https://www.patreon.com/posts/reindeer-tribe-130039036

We drove over 3,000km across the wild heart of Mongolia in a rugged 4x4 mission to reach the remote Tsaatan reindeer herders of the north. Along the way, we lived with nomadic families, crossed vast steppes, deep river valleys, and endless mountain passes. This wasn‚Äôt just a journey‚Äîit was a raw, immersive experience into one of the last surviving nomadic cultures on Earth.

In the final stretch, deep in the taiga, we were invited to witness and take part in a rare Tsaatan rite of passage‚Äîan honor few outsiders have ever experienced. This is the story of endurance, culture, and connection in one of the most untouched corners of the planet.
Big love to LIQUI MOLY Extreme for hosting us. You can do this trip too. Check the link above!

title: Mexico City Earthquake VLOG September 19 2017 | Magnitude 7.1
description:
Today was a bad day in Mexico City. 32 years after the  deadly earthquake that hit in 1985, a second struck today on September 19th 2017. Many buildings fell today in La Roma, Condesa and Navarte neighborhoods. 

This happened just 2 weeks after the giant 8.2 earthquake off the coast of Oaxaca. That epicenter was roughly 500 kilometers away from this area. The earthquake of today was a magnitude of 7.9, but much closer. Only about 100km away near the states of Cuernavaca and Puebla. 

We were able to record some it in a vlog starting just a few minutes after the quake, and walked around the area seeing if we could help, and observing the damage and aftermath. As a Canadian living in Mexico, I have never experienced anything like this before, and being an eye witness was very scary. Send prayers to the people on this city.

title: FINISHING the SPICIEST Ramen in Tokyo, Japan üî•
description:
One man versus the spiciest ramen in Tokyo. There will never be a winner in this battle.

The soul of Tokyo they call it. This soup is a Japanese Food staple. Ramen fuels Japan. This beautiful dish is made of japanese ramen noodles, cooked in a fish or meat broth. Miso paste is added, with boiled tamago egg, tender Chasu pork, and a whole host of other ingredients. There are 100 ways to make it, and every one a different type of delicious. If you like street food, this is top of the list in Japan. If you‚Äôre on the hunt for a place selling the Best ramen in Tokyo, Kikanbo is a contender for sure.

I saw a travel video from my friend Mark Wiens trying the spiciest ramen in Tokyo, and thought I'd give it a shot myself. 

I'm addicted to spicy food, and thought perhaps I could finish it. It was a war to remember, but I can out in top. 

#Tokyo #Japan #Ramen

title: This is a 500 Year Old Stone AirBNB on a CLIFF in OMAN
description:
I still can't believe we slept here...
Welcome to Oman, one of the least talked about countries in the world. 
I still don't know why, it's an amazing country.

During our roadtrip in Oman, we discovered an AirBNB listing for an abandoned 500 year old stone house on the cliff face of the Akhdar mountains. I booked that room so fast... It was no doubt going to be one of the most epic stays of our life... but next was getting there. Little did Eva Zu Beck and I know, that this was going to be a little more of an adventure than we had expected, and found ourselves pushing ourselves through a 30cm crack in the earth the next day. It was a wild ride.

#FearlessandFar #Oman #Airbnb

title: FIRST DAY IN BASILAN MINDANAO PHILIPPINES Travel Vlog
description:
In this Philippines travel vlog, we explore Basilan Mindanao with Kulas and Kumar of Becoming Filipino. This small island has had a lot of trouble in the past. Muslim extremist groups have damaged its people and its reputation. As a foreigner in the Philippines, everyone told me to stay away from the south. Mindanao was "dangerous" and "no one should go", is what I was told by both filipinos and foreign travelers. After the Mindanao roadtrip with the Fighterboys, I would have to disagree. Love and generosity is what we experienced, an appreciation from the people that I have rarely felt while travelling the world. We met the governor of ARMM, our local contact (always have a local contact) and spent 4 days here. While I wouldn't recommend travelling here on your first day in the Philippines, 

This is Day 1 Part 1 of exploring Basilan Mindano Philippines.

#FearlessandFar #Basilan #Mindanao

title: TRUNYAN BALI: A SHOCKING CEMETERY IN INDONESIA
description:
Trunyan Village Cemetery in Bali was a challenging experience for me. We rarely see dead bodies in the western world, and we have a very finite view on death. Trunyan village is located deep in the centre of Bali, nestled beside a crater lake and mount Batur, and is quite hard to get to. 

Here, they still follow a tradition that was set in place over a thousand years ago. They place their dead under a Terumanyan Tree, supposedly the last of it's kind, to mask it's beautiful scent.

The legend says that the smell of the tree was so sweet, that people from all over the island would come to try and find its source. The village of Trunyan was overrun with travellers. A man arrived and met a woman, he wanted to marry her. She insisted that before they were to be wed, the man has to find a way to stop the smell of the tree. The man found a very unique way to do so, and so began the tradition of placing dead bodies under the tree.

Now, we can visit the cemetery and see death face to face. There are 11 exposed graves beside the famous tree. The people living here are the descendants of the original Balinse people called Aga, and both the village and the tree derive their name from their language. Taru meaning 'tree' and Menyan meaning 'nice smell'.

There are a lot of poor reviews of this place. The locals are having a hard time appropriately managing the travellers that arrive. It's also quite small, and depending if anyone has died recently, there may or may not be a decomposing body. I have Yansu's contact below. I highly recommend you contact him.

title: EATING BETEL NUTS | ADDICTIVE PLANT IN INDONESIA | TRAVEL VLOG
description:
Big thanks to Wonderful Indonesia for hosting us this year on the #TripofWonders. This is a bonus before I release some videos of the unbelievable world we saw underwater. Stay tuned!

Indonesia has some great street food, and I'm always trying to hunt down the weirdest, strangest, most interesting foods I can find. This lead us to chewing on the Betel nut (not Beetle nut, though pronounced the same), a green golfball sized fruit of a Areca Palm, that is suppose to be addictive, and give you sexual prowess. 

I first saw people chew it in Taiwan. There, it was so famous they made a documentary called Betel Nut Girls, which was about the naked girls standing on the side of the road selling them to truck drivers. All throughout Asia though, you can see the orange stains of betelnut juice on the streets, and all over the teeth of people of locals. It is consumed much like chewing tobacco, and slowly turns teeth orange, rots the gums, and causes cancer. Yum. 

The up side of its effects is that it is a stimulant, and it keeps you awake. Also, the word on the street is that an orange smile is attractive. Locals chew away, spitting violently orange mouthfuls of saliva every few minutes, and look like they just took a bite out of someone's jugular vein. Sexy. 

Hope you enjoy this travel vlog in Indonesia! Check out my friends who tried them as well. Links below!

title: TREKKING Fairy Meadows PAKISTAN Vlog & Nanga Parbat Jeep Ride
description:
Fairy Meadows Pakistan! They says it's the most beautiful place in the country. In this Pakistan travel vlog, we continue our roadtrip through Northern Pakistan, and embark on a Jeep to the legendary viewing point of Nanga Parbat, aka "The Killer Mountain"

This trip starts off with a ride along the most dangerous highway in the world. I don't think there was ever an official competition, but by looking at the video footage, you can tell pretty quickly it is definitely a contender. 



This is the second episode in my Pakistan Travel Vlog series, make sure you catch the first where we begin our journey from Islamabad to Skardu in Northern Pakistan. We start out driving from Besham to Chillas, but continue to, Fairy Meadows, Gilgit, Skardu, Hunza Valley, Nanga Parbat, and many other places along the Karakoram highway. 

Pakistan tourism is on the rise. It's often called a dangerous place to travel. Our purpose was to spend our time, as foreigners in Pakistan to disprove this, and show the beauty of the people and the landscape to the world. CPIC global sponsored out trip, but we did so without any security or military escorts. The only trouble we got into was bumpy roads.

While normally I solo travel, I was excited to have so many friends on the trip. Siya Zarabi from Hopscotch the Globe, Lexie Alford from Lexie Limitless, Ryan Riel from Opposite Travellers, Anushae Khan, Brooke Saward, and Alexandrina Cojocaru.

For an email once a month with all my favourite things I've found in the world... Join the Adventure Newsletter
https://fearlessandfar.com/join-our-adventure-newsletter

Also, I post extra videos on my Patreon. Some are not for the faint of heart! It's the best way to support the channel.

title: CORON PALAWAN ( Free diving & Island hopping) Philippines travel vlog
description:
Island hopping in Coron Palawan Philippines!
In this travel vlog I join Exploring with Cody in a Filipino adventure to visit Kayangan Lake, Twin Lagoon, Barracuda lake, and Skeleton Wreck. These incredible islands have been called the most beautiful in the world. If you plan to travel South East Asia, this has to be on your bucket list. It is definitely one of the best places to travel in the Philippines

We had a couple days between scuba diving the shipwrecks of Coron Bay, and exploring El Nido, Palawan. We decided to spend it Island hopping in Coron with our friend Jette. We wanted to do the tour a little bit differently, so we organized a private boat for us three, and left an hour earlier than other boats. This paid off in the end, because these islands are getting very very busy, and we were able to miss most of the crowds.

title: Suspending My Body by Hooks (My Ultimate Test)
description:
Body Suspension. Just a quick warning that this extreme form of body piercing isn‚Äôt for everyone. This video has been edited to remove most of the most graphic scenes. If you‚Äôd like to see the full uncut version it will be available on my Patreon (www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar) very shortly. If you understand the disclaimer, and are ready to learn a bit more about human suspension, and why I would ever want to try it. Let‚Äôs continue.

Each year I try and do something a little bit different for my birthday. I try and challenge myself. I try to explore beyond my boundaries. In past years I‚Äôve gone bungee jumping, free diving, skydiving, lived solo in the woods, and this year. Body Suspension. The art of Hanging by Hooks. I thought I would make a short documentary about it.

Piercing your body is painful, relying on your skin to support your body weight is even more painful, but that‚Äôs part of the process. It‚Äôs been called cathartic, life changing, and unexplainable. To the viewer, it‚Äôs shocking, to the practitioner, cathartic.

While it might seem like a new trend, it‚Äôs been around for 5000 years. Shaivite Hindus used to tread the line of body and spirit through body suspension to pay penance to their god Shiva. Variations of this still happen today in various parts of the world. Thousands of years later in what is now known as North Dakota the North American Mandan Tribe would ritualistically hang themselves by hooks as a right of passage. It was how men became boys.

Two alternate cultures independently birthed this wild tradition without contact with each other.

We‚Äôre doing it again today. You see it at tattoo conventions, and street performances.  It makes me think there might be a bit more to it.

It‚Äôs my birthday, and I like to challenge myself on my birthday. Let‚Äôs find out.

#FearlessandFar #Bodysuspension #piercing

title: LA TOMATINA TOMATO FIGHT FESTIVAL SPAIN
description:
La Tomatina Festival or The Tomato Fight in Spain is an amazing festival that happens in Bunol, near Valencia, at the end of every August. 11 trucks of tomatoes make their way into Bu√±ol city square and a town of 9000 floods to 50 000+. This is La Tomatina, and it's the world's biggest food fight. 

Since it began hundreds of years ago, the festival as grown into a world wide phenomenon. You can see these tomato throwing fights in all corners of the world. Some more famous ones being in Glastonbury and Seattle.

I hooked up with some friends on Couch Surfing and we took the train from Valencia to Bunol. At that time, it was packed. I can't beleive how many people are there now. I would recommend going the day before and booking accommodations far, far, in advance.

It's a helluva a party. Prepare to get soaked, stained, and pushed around. It was only an hour, which was a good thing. Being pelted by tomatoes is fun for about that amount of time, but not much after.

title: AFRICAN KIDS REACT TO FUNNY SNAPCHAT FILTERS
description:
I travelled through Madagascar showing kids snapchat for the first time. Their reaction was priceless. Turning their faces into rabbits, giving them make up, changing their voice was really funny.
Some would react by trying to rub it off their face, some would run away screaming, other would just laugh! Either way, it was pretty hilarious for me. 

We've been filming in Madagascar for 2 weeks, working with Crowdrise to help save a very endangered population of lemurs in Central Eastern Madagascar. I'd love if you could donate, or even just check out the video we made!
https://www.crowdrise.com/86402secondsinmadagascar

I made another video like this one. Kids react to snapchat filters video in Indonesia. This one went viral, so I thought I'd make another. If you're into this kind of Comedy, check out Kids react to Snapchat filters in Indonesia: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E5IO7jt4W-U

title: Travel the World Video: an Epic 80 Day Montage
description:
Click for more info, and check these out as well:

I'm lovin' Snapchat: kickthegrind

My Website is: http://kickthegrind.tv/

Tweet Me Here: http://www.twitter.com/KickTheGrind

My Facebook Fanpage: http://www.facebook.com/KicktheGrindTV

Check some photos here: http://www.instagram.com/kickthegrind

Thanks for watching! and remember...

Experiences are worth more than Possessions. Kick the Grind

- - - - - - - - - - - - -

A dream come true. I've been wanting to travel the world since I was young. The idea of the unknown, the different, and the unexplored has always been an interest of mine. Travelling the world in 80 days was my opportunity to do just that; to push into some of the more daring adventures of our world, camera in hand. This video is a montage of my adventures over the past 3 months, and also a Thank You to everyone who supported me along the way. Thank you for the likes, comments and encouragement. This one goes out to all of you.

13 countries, 35 flights, and one amazing RTW experience that will stick with me forever. You'll see pieces of some videos you've already seen me share (Cormorant fishing,  Pandas, etc.) but has a lot of video of things that are still to come (Yantra Tattooing, Mt. Fuji...) Kick back and enjoy a highlight reel of some of the best memories of my 80 days with Cathay Pacific.

title: Riding the World‚Äôs Lowest Train Class in Bangladesh
description:
This video is the opposite of first class train travel. I hope you're ready for a different ride. This is a train tour of a standing class (let's call it 4th class) ticket. I'm just happy I didn't ride this one overnight.

Trains in Bangladesh can be crazy. It‚Äôs the most densely populated country in the world, and during times of celebration, the public transport system can't handle it. When millions of people flood the trains to leave, or return to Dhaka, many ride on top or on the sides when tickets are not available.

We‚Äôre in Bangladesh during the time of a local festival, and try and see if we can join the locals for this wild train ride.

title: KECAK FIRE DANCE AT ULUWATU TEMPLE
description:
Bali is such a great island. I had the chance to explore it for two weeks, and couldn't believe the diversity. Kuta for parties, Sanur for resorts, Ubud for the spirit, and basically anywhere in the water for diving. We caught this performance of Kecak, and traditional Balinese dance and Uluwatu (or Monkey) Temple. Over the years, it's changed a bit. Now part theatre, part fire, and part culture... It's quite a fun show. I tried to capture some of the craziness, but it left us all saying Chak Chak Chak for days.

Also, shout out to my two back-up singers at the end Stephen (http://www.abackpackerstale.com/) and Kadek (http://www.instagram.com/kadekarini)

This was part of the #tripofwonders put on by Indonesia Travel (http://www.indonesia.travel/)

title: EXPLORING Mindanao's Britania Islands | Philippines Travel Vlog 2018
description:
The first day of my Philippines travel vlog in Mindanao. Myself, Becoming Filipino, Finn Snow, and members of the vlogsquad, Daniel Marsh and Bret Maverick, explore a group of amazing islands (called the Britania Islands) in Surigao del Sur and Marihatag. 

As a foreigner in the Philippines, I was told that Mindanao is dangerous and exploring this island in the Philippines should be off my list. We felt nothing but Pinoy love  from the. filipino and filipina community there, and this was a highlight of my trip.

We spent a few days on the beach before heading to Davao City.

title: DELICIOUS FILIPINO street food in LEYTE | FIGHTER BOYS | Philippines Travel vlog
description:
Filipino street food might not look so great to westerners, but most of it is really tasty! I've had a lot of street food in the Philippines, but mostly in Makati in Manila. Isaw, Balut, Helmut, I've even made a travel vlog about a few of them. But on this adventure, the fighter boys are far from Manila. We're in the small town of Bato on the island of Leyte!

Last year I travelled for 3 months as a foreigner in the Philippines before concluding my filipino travel vlog series with the Fighter Boys trip with Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, Bret Maverick. Nicknamed the Fighter Boys, after our sponsor Fighter Wine. 

Hope you enjoy this filipino street food in Leyte. We had a great time trying all the different meats! Which do you like? Which would you try?

title: Eating Mexican CHICHARR√ìN with Exploring with Cody | Mexico City Street Food 2018
description:
Mexico City street food is some of the best and tastiest around! Exploring with Cody and I found the Mexican specialty of chicharron in Chapultepec Park (Bosque de Chapultepec) and thought we should try it!

Having lived in Mexico City for almost a year, I had surprisingly not tried this Mexican snack, but I had seen it everywhere. Trying it is definitely one of the top things to do in Mexico

There are several different kinds of Chicharr√≥n. Some made with flour, and others made the traditional way of deep frying pig fat.

We tried it 2 different ways. Chicharr√≥n preparada, with avacado, tomato, cueritos, cream, cabbage, and salsas. Also Chicharr√≥n solita, with just some sauces, Tajin, salt and Lime.

After making this video, I learned that maybe we had made a mistake... Are both of these flour? Or is one actually the real one?

I need to stop asking the shop keepers for information, I think they just answer "Yes" to every question so I buy their food üòê

Mexico is so much more than just tacos. There is god level street food here, allowing for some great food videos. Would you give this a taste test?

title: CAMIGUIN ISLAND Volcano Hike | FIGHTER BOYS REUNITED | Philippines travel
description:
The Fighter Boys are back!
Last year I travelled for 3 months as a foreigner in the Philippines before concluding my filipino travel vlog series with the Fighter Boys trip with Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, Bret Maverick. 

The plan was to start in Cagayan de Oro and travel the island of Mindanao for 2 weeks to bring awareness to a misunderstood area of the Philippines. We didn't expect such an amazing experience, and we didn't expect much amazing support from Filipinos across the country. By popular demand, the Fighter Boys are back for a second trip!

This Philippines travel vlog kicks off on Camiguin Island to hike volcano Hibok-Hibok. Last time I was on Camiguin, we explored the Sunken Cemetery, and saw the Giant Clam Sanctuary. I didn't get a chance to visit White Island or hike the volcano. So... Bonus!

A few things to note. Hibok-Hibok is closed right now. El Nido has made it too dry to safely summit without damaging the wildlife. Please check before you come. This was a specially organized trek to open a third trail to the summit. It was a hard one!

Sign up and Check out the 5 Advanced Travel Tips I Wish I Knew When I Started!
