title: Spain's Crazy BABY JUMPING FESTIVAL (EL COLACHO)
description:
We made it. I've been wanting to visit this crazy festival in Spain for years. El Colacho, or the Baby Jumping Festival, has made almost every top 5 or top 10 strangest / weirdest festivals in the world internet list I can find. No where else on this planet can you see a grown man dressed as the devil jump over babies. It's unbelievable, and it all happens in the tiny town of Castrillo de Murcia.

The party itself is so much more than baby jumping, it's actually 4 days long, and the "main event" only the last hour on the last day. What happens is actually quite beautiful, and not as strange, weird, or crazy as you might think. There is a bit of a story line to the whole event, and what they think is that this festival was grandfathered in from before Christianity arrived in the area. It was adopted and modified to fit the new belief system, and here it still stands today.

The full name is El Salto de el Colacho, meaning "The Jump of the Devil", but there's more to the fiesta than that. It's a battle between good an evil. The townspeople pray to god, and the devil comes to interfere. The local children of the town mock him, and he chases them around with a whip. When the final prayers are said, the devil realizes he's lost the battle and flees from the cathedral. Babies are placed on mattresses in the streets, and the Original Sin (from Adam and Eve) and any diseases the babies might have stick to the devil during his retreat. It's like an elaborate baptism of the children. 

There isn't much online about this amazing festival, so I'm hoping I got the information mostly right. Whether you agree or disagree with what happens here it's important to understand is that is local tradition, and for the parents and the children, one of the most important days of their lives. No child has even been hurt during this festival, and what we saw was extreme care, tenderness, and respect. Also the amount of smiling, laughing, and joy was contagious. While looking a bit crazy, reckless, and unbelievable on the outside, all we saw was beauty.

Hope you enjoyed El Colacho!

title: Exploring the Most Dangerous Place in Ethiopia
description:
I hiked into the Afar Desert of Ethiopia to reach Erta Ale, one of the only volcanoes on Earth with a permanent lava lake. For days, I lived on the rim‚Äîsleeping beside boiling rock, breathing smoke, and watching rivers of fire churn below me.

üî• Welcome to the Gateway to Hell.
üåç Deep in one of the harshest environments on the planet.
‚è≥ Few people ever make it here.

Join me as I trek across the desert with local Afar guides, camp under the stars beside molten lava, and witness the raw power of the Earth itself.

title: FULL HAND TATTOO IN THE AMAZON JUNGLE? | ADVENTURE TRAVEL STORIES | PERU
description:
This is the first episode of a new series here on Kick the Grind. It's going to be called travel stories, and I'll be explaining some of the wild adventures behind the videos you see here.

This was all filmed in and around Leticia, Colombia. This part of the country is right on the border between Brazil, and Peru. Here many people take river cruises to the Peruvian Amazon, or wander off into the depths of Brazilian amazon in search for a Shaman.

Kicking it off, is answering the number 1 question I had after posting the amazon jungle adventure challenge videos, and then the experience finding a shaman in the Brazilian rainforest.

In this video I explain a bit more of what happened in the forests of South America, and also explain our encounter with Huito, a seed that creates a blue pigment when mixed with water. It's also called Jagua Tattooing when you use this deep colour to stain your hair, skin, hands, etc. We encountered this strange plant many times while doing our river cruise, and began to apply it shortly after fishing for piranhas. When your Jagua Tattoo is first applied it looks clear. Fast forward a day later, and it looks like you have crazy full hand tattoos. 

We also were painted with Annatto, also known as Achiote or Colorau. It's an orange pigment from the seed of a tree. These seeds produce a bright orange paste that is used to paint ornamental markings on the skin. It is also used as a food colorant in many dishes (and processed foods) around the world.

If you want make it on the hand, just like the video, leave me a nice comment, and end it with the motto "Experiences over Possessions"

title: Dancing ON STAGE at the Naliyagan festival 2018 | MINDANAO Philippines
description:
In this Philippines travel vlog, the fighterboys continue our road trip around the island of Mindanao, but encounter a problem. The plan was to spend a night in Agusan marsh, but we find out all the boats are being used for a local festival. We decide why fight, when you can join it, and we accepted an invitation from the governor to be VIP and celebrate at the Naliyagan festival 2018. 

The festival is famous for it's Street dance. Large groups compete is colourful dances to drum music. Speaking of dancing, the figher boys end up on stage to fight our fears dancing in front of thousands of people.

As a foreigner in the Philippines... It doesn't get much better than this!
Make sure to check out the rest of the crew! Becoming Filipinio, Bret Maverick, Finn Snow, Daniel Marsh. Links are below.

title: FILIPINO SUPERBIKE!? Only in the Philippines üòÇFighter Boys Vlog
description:
In this Philippines travel vlog we arrive on Capul Island!

I have to say, It's a blast being a foreigner in the Philippines. After torpedo boating, waterfall exploring, and meeting some of the friendliest Filipinos yet in Leyte and Samar, we pack up the scooters onto a small ferry and head over to explore this beautiful little island.

Capul island was our home base for a few days while myself, Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Bret Maverick, and Finn Snow explored what it had to offer. In this vlog, we take a quick tour into town, jump on a 6 man Super Bike (Maybe my favourite) and explore a beautiful beach to the north. 

Hope you guys are enjoying the Fighter Boys vlog series!
Lots more to come.

title: BATTLE OF THE ORANGES 2019 | Battaglia delle Arance | Carnevale Ivrea
description:
The battle of the oranges in Ivrea, Italy is one of the biggest food fights in the world. Known as Battaglia delle Arance, or Storico Carnevale Ivrea in Italy, this festival is easily one of the most exciting, and was it's biggest celebration yet in 2019. It is the only orange battle in the world.

Often compared to the tomato fight in Bu√±ol, Spain near Valencia. La Tomatina is a very different experience. Tomatoes are a joke compared to oranges. If you've been to La Tomatina before, expect a much more extreme festival. 

Teams like Scacchi, Picche, Arduini, Tuchini, Diavoli, Pantera Nera, Mercenari, Credendari, Morte, team up in the 5 town squares in Ivrea over 3 days of Battle. While the festival seems to be all about oranges, it's much deeper than that and has a complex and rich history around it. Ivrea, Italia is located just outside of Turino (Torino) and not that far from Milan.

The say it started this way. In medieval times there was an evil king who enforced Ius Primae Noctis, aka "Prima Nocta" on all the new brides. This "rule" meant that the king got to deflower every woman before her husband on her wedding night. The Miller's Daughter called The Mugnaia, was brought to his quarters on her wedding night for this terrible act. She courageously grabbed his sword, and cut off his head. She freed herself, and the people of Ivrea from his tyranny. This carnival is a celebration of freedom, not citrus fruit.

If you'd like to attend the Battle of the Oranges next year. I've made a guide to help you understand how to experience it. Check out the link.
https://fearlessandfar.com/festival-survival-guide-italys-orange-fight

title: ISLAND OF THE DOLLS (ISLA DE LAS MUNECAS) MEXICO'S MOST HAUNTED PLACES
description:
Seen on Ghost Hunters, Ghost Adventures, and many other shows about the scariest places in the world. The terror of this location has stretched across the planet. The story is much more than an island of Mexican Dolls. Isla de las Munecas, or Island of the Dolls is one of the top 10 most haunted places in the country, and is found just south of Mexico City in an area called Xochimilco. 

I hit up my friends Exploring with Josh Exploring with Cody to help me check out this urban legend. Awesome dudes. Also my GF Mariannela helped us out a lot with this. Make sure to check out their links below!

Julian Santana, the creator moved here in the mid 1900s because of heartbreak. He desired to just be alone, he didn't any intention on creating one of the most haunted places in Mexico. Upon arriving he witnessed a girl fall into the river and drown. That night, he heard horrible screams, and believed the ghost of the girl had come to haunt him. He began hanging dolls from trees to keep her spirit happy, he did this for several decades before dying of a heart attack in the exact same place the girl had died. Creepy, I know.

There are lots of things to do in this area of CDMX (or DF), but the main attraction is taking the colourful trajineras for a spin around the chiampas. This probably sounds pretty fancy, but basically it means jumping on a colourful boat, sitting and drinking beer while Mariachi bands pass by. You'd never expect one of the scariest places in Mexico is just around the corner, covered in decapitated dolls, spider webs, and ghost stories.

This was the 4th time I had ventured down to Xochimilco to find doll island. There are a few issues with the adventure if you speak english.
There are three ports you can leave from, make sure you go to EMBARCADERO CUEMANCO, the other two are full of scammers (at least from my experience). Also, keep in mind there are two Isla de las Mu√±ecas. One is a replica, and I believe they built it because the original is much further from the launch point, and pushing a 10m boat through canals for 2 hours each way is a pain.

If you're a fan of horror or paranormal activity, this will be an experience for you. Just make sure not to get fooled!

title: FASCINATING SNAKE HOUSE IN MEXICO CITY | QUETZALCOATL'S NEST
description:
Welcome to one of the coolest homes I've ever stayed in. We first came across this place on Airbnb, and couldn't believe something so amazing was so close to Mexico City. It is a series of 10 apartments build into the back of a giant serpent. It's the coolest house I've ever seen, if you don't mind living in a snake god.

It was created by Javier Senosiain, a Mexican architect specializing in Organic Architecture. This philosophy of construction blends   seamlessly with nature, so they both work together in harmony. This location is called El Nido de Quetzalcoatl (The Nest of Quetzalcoatl) because of the giant snake head that is the centre piece of the location. When Javier first decided to build the park, he came across a giant cave whose opening resembled the gaping mouth of a snake. This inspired him to continue the theme, and great a giant 18 hectare park, with 13 snakes twisting through it. Despite everything he has created here, the valley in which everything is hidden, is vastly untouched. His constructions are guided using the natural shape of the land. 

As far as things to do in Mexico, this is an absolute must. I have never seen anything like this in all of my years as a travel vlogger. It is truly an oasis hidden away in Naucalpan, just outside Mexico City.

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

TO VISIT:

At this time you have two options. A private tour or staying in the apartment. Our contact for both of these is Patricia. Her email: mopacastillo(at)gmail.com

The easiest, and which that allows you the most freedom is to stay there overnight. It is a 10 person apartment, with a recommended minimum of 2 nights. This can sometimes be negotiated depending on the time of year. Get some friends together and split the cost. It is worth it.

The Airbnb Listing is here: https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/10153978

If you don't have an Airbnb account, you can my link to get $35 off your first booking: www.airbnb.com/c/mcorey24

title: DON'T do this in Pakistan (We're Sorry!)
description:
We made a mistake.
In this Pakistan Travel Vlog, we arrive in a beautiful little town in Skardu. After seeing so many smiling faces, I decided to have a little fun. There was a small place making naan bread, we took one to make a mask to make the locals laugh. This had the opposite effect. They all seemed quite offended that I had used bread this way. I learned later bread was sacred. I had taken my love of capturing people's smiles a little too far.

We continue on and have some of the most beautiful encounters with locals I have ever had. You can tell by all the portrait shots. It was one of the friendliest places I have ever been.

After visiting Fairy Meadows, Hunza Valley, Nanga Parbat, the Karakoram Highway, and all out other adventures, this was a nice way to continue of Pakistan Travel Vlog series

Pakistan tourism is on the rise. It's often called a dangerous place to travel. Our purpose was to spend our time, as foreigners in Pakistan to disprove this, and show the beauty of the people and the landscape to the world. CPIC Global sponsored out trip, but we did so without any security or military escorts. The only trouble we got into was bumpy roads.

While normally I solo travel, I was excited to have so many friends on the trip. Siya Zarabi from Hopscotch the Globe, Lexie Alford from Lexie Limitless, Ryan Riel from Opposite Travellers, Anushae Khan, Brooke Saward, and Alexandrina Cojocaru.

For an email once a month with all my favourite things I've found in the world... Join the Adventure Newsletter
https://fearlessandfar.com/join-our-adventure-newsletter

Also, I post extra videos on my Patreon. Some are not for the faint of heart! It's the best way to support the channel.
https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

#FearlessandFar #Pakistan #Travel

title: FILMING IN A BANGKOK STRIP CLUB | ADVENTURE TRAVEL STORIES | THAILAND
description:
Here's a tip... don't film in a strip club or brothel in Bangkok Thailand. In fact, maybe avoid filming anything in Patpong, the red light district. This was a rookie mistake a made several years ago while under pressure for a TV casting in South East Asia. I thought I would share the experience, dig an old travel video out out of my hard drive, and tell you the story of the most scared I've been in 8 years of travelling the world. 

Patpong night life and street markets area a integral part of the things to do in Bangkok. While it is the red light area of Bangkok, it's not particularly dangerous for the average tourist. There is all sorts of strange things to see however... You can buy tazers, see ping pong ball shows, and visit Gogo Bars. Drink cheap beer, find great streetfood, and get a neck massage while you pee at a urinal (this really happened, and was quite a surprise). It's open late, and can be quite a crazy (but fun) experience for people visiting the city.

This particular night I visited the area a bit beyond the scope of a normal tourist. I was out in the streets trying to compete with locals at 3am to prove myself for a casting call. I did not plan on going anywhere near a stripclub, or Patpong, that night. Fate had something different in store for me, and I was desperate. The lesson learned was don't ever film in the red light district of Bangkok Thailand.

 
Here's the original video I had sent for the casting of the TV, I have re-uploaded it to YouTube as unlisted if anyone wants to see ü§£ https://youtu.be/93noljDSEz8

title: EXPLORING ANGEL FALLS üí¶ | E02 | VENEZUELA Travel Vlog 2019
description:
Angel Falls aka Salto Angel in Canaima National Park is the highest waterfall in the world!

In this second episode of our Venezuela 2019 travel vlog, we continue our adventures South America at Canaima National Park. 
For both Lexie and I, visiting Angel Falls was always a travel goal. With the current mess with Nicolas Maduro, the Venezuela crisis hitting a peak in the news, and the massive drop in tourism, we thought we would have to put it off indefinitely. 
Fortunately we had great contacts (Pablo and Sandy), who made this dream trip possible for us. So we flew into Caracas, and the story begins. They say "Don't blame a country by the actions of its government" So we couldn't believe all the bad Venezuela news, we wanted to meet the people, and see its nature and landscape.

The day started with a 3 hour boat ride up Rio Carrao, with a stop at La Poza de Felicidad, or Happiness Pool. When we got to our campsite, we found it abandoned. Angels Falls used to get 500+ tourists a day, and now it was receiving what looked like it's first 2 in a long time. We set up our hammocks and begun to explore. We found a crack in the jungle, and bam... There it was Angel Falls, the highest waterfall in the world, peeking out between the trees.

The next morning we started early and hiked an hour to a viewpoint and pool at the base of the falls. We even managed to get drone video of angel falls. It was the perfect travel day.

Our hearts go out the the Venezuelan people. Myself and my travel companion Lexie Alford visited this beautiful place late 2018, with the mission to show another side of a country in crisis. We planned to show the beauty of the people, and the natural beauty of the country.

This is not a video about the current economical or political situation. This is a Venezeula travel vlog of what we experienced as tourists. 

#FearlessandFar #Venezuela #Angelfalls

Want more videos? Check out my Patreon community here! https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: VENEZUELA ISLAND HOPPING  | Adventure Travel Vlog 2019
description:
Venezuela, a jewel in South America. This travel vlog is episode 4 of our experience as tourists in a country in a pressure cooker.

The Venezuela Crisis has been in the spotlight for quite some time now, and with an invite from a local friend Sandy, we set out to explore this beautiful country despite what it had been saying in the news.

What we found was an incredible country which took our hearts.

We begin this episode landing back in Puerto Ordaz from seeing Angel Falls in Canaima National Park. From there, my Canadian friend Sandy, who has been living in Venezuela for over 3 years, picks us up for a roadtrip.

We drive 4 hours north to the town he is living in called Lecheria, near Barcelona, Venezuela. We then go island hopping to visit Isla Faro, and that's where we encounter our first run in with trouble... Cacti and Snakes.

The outro of this video was re-recorded after the incident when humanitarian aid was stopped by Maduro at the border between Venezuela and Colombia. 

Our hearts go out the the Venezuelan people. Myself and my travel companion Lexie Alford visited this beautiful place late 2018, with the mission to show another side of a country in crisis. We planned to show the beauty of the people, and the natural beauty of the country.

This is not a video about the current economical or political situation. This is a Venezeula travel vlog of what we experienced as tourists. 

#FearlessandFar #Venezuela #Travel

title: Rooftopping in Venezuela (Tallest Tower)
description:
Rooftopping is the art of climbing sky scrapers. We're in Caracas, Venezuela to put it all on the edge and climb 2 of it's tallest towers. The first will be the notorious Torre David. A 45-story building that was never finished because of a financial crisis in the 1990s. Squatters moved in and turned it into a home for thousands of people. It became a symbol of Venezuela‚Äôs struggles and the people's ability to create their own community.

Parque Central is a complex of 5 towers with the tallest tower standing 56 stories high. It was built as a major residential and commercial center. The taller tower became a symbol of modern urban development in Venezuela but also faced challenges like fires and economic decline over the years. The east tower is abandoned from halfway up.

title: Walking the World's Most DANGEROUS Bridge in Pakistan
description:
The Hussaini hanging bridge in Hunza Valley Pakistan is known as one of the most dangerous in the world. In this travel vlog, we walk across it (carefully) and talk to some local Pakistani people along the way.

In the small town of Passu Cones, in the Gojal region of Northern Pakistan lies a suspension bridge unlike any other. Built by local farmers, the purpose of the bridge over the Hunza river is to keep their livestock away from their crops. I'm not sure if it's by design that this bridge has more empty space than wood, but it takes some serious nerves to walk across it. 

No safety harnesses, no guidance. It's become a bit of a tourist attraction for people traveling through the Hunza valley in Gilgit Baltistan. It's a suspension bridge attached by cables bolted into the towering mountains on either side. It's a adventure I recommend to everyone, just watch your step.

Pakistan tourism is on the rise. It's often called a dangerous place to travel. Our purpose was to spend our time, as foreigners in Pakistan to disprove this, and show the beauty of the people and the landscape to the world. CPIC Global sponsored out trip, but we did so without any security or military escorts. The only trouble we got into was bumpy roads.

While normally I solo travel, I was excited to have so many friends on the trip. Siya Zarabi from Hopscotch the Globe, Lexie Alford from Lexie Limitless, Ryan Riel from Opposite Travellers, Anushae Khan, Brooke Saward, and Alexandrina Cojocaru.

title: BASILAN MINDANAO PARADISE |  PHILIPPINES Travel Vlog
description:
Episode 2 of Discovering Basilan with Becoming Filipino. In this Philippines travel vlog we explore more of the island of Basilan in Mindanao Philippines. 

During day 1 part two I horribly lose a dunk competition to a bunch of locals in Maluso, we find paradise on Langgas Island, and I sit down and talk about what the first day was actually like. 

This small island has had a lot of trouble in the past. Muslim extremist groups have damaged its people and its reputation. As a foreigner in the Philippines, everyone told me to stay away from the south. Mindanao was "dangerous" and "no one should go", is what I was told by both filipinos and foreign travelers. After the Mindanao roadtrip with the Fighterboys, I would have to disagree. Love and generosity is what we experienced, an appreciation from the people that I have rarely felt while travelling the world. We met the governor of ARMM, our local contact (always have a local contact) and spent 4 days here. While I wouldn't recommend travelling here on your first day in the Philippines, 

This is Day 1 Part 2 of exploring Basilan Mindano Philippines.

#FearlessandFar #Basilan #Mindanao

title: BIOLUMINESCENCE IN HOLBOX, MEXICO | PUNTA COCOS BEACH
description:
On the western tip of Holbox Island, just a few hours from Cancun, is a beautiful beach called Punta Cocos. This beach is one of the most photographed around Cancun during sunset because it is facing west (rare for a beach in Riviera Maya), and also is home to the beach hammocks that make for great silhouette pictures.

Long after the sun sets, this beach still remains popular, not for parties, but for another attraction entirely; Bioluminescence. It becomes a glowing beach, and it's amazing to see.

Bioluminescent plankton are found here in one of the highest concentrations in Mexico. The water is very shallow, and even 20 meters or so away from shore, it's still below your knees. This allows these little glowing animals go accumulate in large numbers during the summer.

We visited in May, but were told the best season to see this phenomenon was in July or August after they have had a couple months of summer heat to reproduce. It is really incredible to see. These animals use light to scare away predators. In the ocean, there's usually always something bigger that can eat you, and by lighting up whoever is trying to eat them, they can attract an even larger fish to scare their attacker away. 

There are lots of beautiful islands around the Yucatan peninsula, Cozumel, Isla Mujeres, But Isla Holbox, is just beginning to get popular. Come visit now, or preferably in July or August, and see one of the best light shows in Mexico.

Many of the locations I feature on this channel are undiscovered. If you go, remember to take care of these places. Respect the animals and people who live there, don't throw your trash, and have a great time.

title: SAINT MARTIN: AIRPORT TAKE OFFS AND LANDINGS
description:
The landings and take offs at the Saint Martin Airport or Sint Maarten Airport in the Caribbean are really close to the shore. It's called SXM or Julian, and it has it's roots as a military base. You'd never build and airport this close to a road under normal circumstances. Right beside the landing strip is Maho Beach. Here you can get blasted by the Boeing 747 jet and Large Airbus and other planes as they land and take off. 

Particularly seeing the large KLM planes landing just a few meters overhead is wild. We didn't feel like we were in danger, but there are many signs saying it's dangerous to stand next to the fence. For us, that was half the fun. It's kind of funny to watch all the Bros and Bikini girls on the beach fleeing from the amount of sand and rocks shot back onto the beach with everyone sunbathing. If you hold the fence and close your eyes, you can get blown dry from the jet engines as they take off.

I actually shot this video in HD on my iPhone of all things. My camera had been stolen and it was all I had left. Regardless, Not my worst travel experience. It all turned out pretty great!

title: THAILAND: MAGICAL MONK TATTOOS AT WAT BANG PHRA
description:
A Sak Yant is a sacred geometrical design. These symbols are seen everywhere in South East Asia, and can protect their owners from all sorts of things. 

I heard of Sak Yant AKA Yantra tattooing from a friend. It's primarily done by Buddhist monks in Cambodia and Thailand. They truly believe that these enchantments can do everything from deflecting bullets to protecting your farm from mice. 

It's pretty common to see Muy Thai fighters with Yantra Tattoos on their backs. If you take a close look a many thai amulets, the designs are the same. My tattoos were done by Luang Pi Nunn.

title: MOST EFFICIENT TRAVEL CAMERA SET-UP FOR VIDEO | WHAT'S IN MY BACKPACK
description:
It's about time I show you what's in my backpack. In over 100 videos we have never spoken about cameras.

I did this on purpose, as it's not the camera that makes the vlogger, it's the vlogger that makes the camera (that doesn't make any sense). What I mean is... Give any professional travel vlogger a smart phone and an internet connection and they could make an successful channel. 

That being said, knowing the best cameras, and the best lenses for what you're trying to do IS important. Once you understand the basics of travel vlogging or travel filmmaking, you can maximize your creativity by getting the right camera equipment. 

I've been filming my travels for about 6 years, and the first 4 were spent on big budget projects. These were just myself, or a small team of people. I begun to focus on this YouTube channel, and during this whole adventure, have tried a lot of brands and models of cameras, lenses, drones, backpacks, etc. I've realized the most important thing when shooting travel videos is 
minimizing down time (switching lenses, unzipping pouches, screwing on filters). It doesn't matter what you're shooting with if you miss the shot. 

I'm confident that with this set up, you are ready for just about anything. You spend very little time messing around with gear, and much more time being ready to capture the moment

Efficiency and effectiveness are the most important parts of a camera kit. The problem is that most people forget to pack those. This video is about having what you need, and keeping as streamlined as possible

title: FILIPINO TORPEDO BOATS? | FIGHTER BOYS | Samar Philippines Travel Vlog
description:
In this Philippines Travel vlog we visit Samar and try this wild new filipino tourist attraction, torpedo boat rides!

These tippy boats were once used for the illegal logging industry in the Philippines. About a decade ago, the idea was presented to the local community to use them for tourism instead, it would be better for the environment, and more lucrative.

Now you can jump in one of these water rockets, get soaked, narrowly miss rocks, and fly through rapids. It's quite a ride!

Last year I travelled for 3 months as a foreigner in the Philippines before concluding my filipino travel vlog series with the Fighter Boys trip with Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, Bret Maverick. Nicknamed the Fighter Boys, after our sponsor Fighter Wine. 

Hope you enjoyed this wild video! Would you try these boats too?

Support my channel on Patreon ;)
https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

To celebrate 3 million subscribers and 1 BILLION views, we headed deep into the heart of Mongolia for an unforgettable ice fishing adventure on frozen Ugii Lake.

title: I Broke My Brain on Ayahuasca (don't do this)
description:
Let our sponsor BetterHelp connect you to a therapist who can support you - all fromthe comfort of your own home. Visit https://betterhelp.com/fearlessandfar and enjoy a specialdiscount on your first month.If you have any questions about the brand relating to how the therapists are licensed,their privacy policy, or therapist compensation model, check out this FAQ:https://www.betterhelp.com/your-questions-answered/

After a wild trip on Ayahuasca, I felt like I was still high months later. I felt brain fog. I felt my life was a movie, like it wasn't real. I made this video to hopefully help anyone who is currently stuck in the same spot. If you're are, you're totally fine, your brain isn't broken. The solution is simple.
Anxiety feeds off fear. The more you fear that something is wrong, the worse it gets. The solution is simply replacing the thoughts of fear in your head with ones of love like "I love this feeling, it's just my body trying to help". 
Hope this sets some scared people straight. Ask away in the comments.

title: WE FOUND AN ABANDONED SOVIET MILITARY BARRACKS IN RUSSIA
description:
In this Episode of our Adventure along the Trans-Siberian Railway in Russia, we arrive in Vladivostok in Primorsky Krai after 80 hours on the train from Ulan-Ude, and head out into the deep green wilderness.

Here, we meet some friends and explore Russia's beautiful landscape. While doing so, we encountered an abandoned military barracks. I had heard a lot about the abandoned Soviet Military Bases in eastern Europe, and even went urban exploring a military bunker once, but nothing like this. 

After we returned to the camp, and caught fresh seafood with our hands, made a pasta, and drank around a campfire. The perfect day.

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok. 

A big thank you to the sponsors of the #TransSibChallenge
- Russian Geographical Organization - https://www.rgo.ru/en

title: HAUNTED ABANDONED HOTEL IN MEXICO CITY (POSADA DEL SOL)
description:
Check out my friends!

Exploring with Josh: https://www.youtube.com/user/theartofrealitycrew

Exploring with Cody:
https://www.youtube.com/user/SirCodyBuffinton

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

Mexico City (or DF) is full of abandoned buildings. There a quite a few haunted places I had my eye on to check out, so I called up my friends Exploring with Josh and Exploring with Cody. Urban exploration is pretty new for me, I started sneaking into creepy places just about a year ago, and now I'm hooked.

Posada del Sol is over 100 years old. It's original owner and founder was an architect, and the detail he put into creating this hotel was incredible. He wanted to make the most beautiful hotel in the country, and he did... you have to see this place to believe it.

The hotel in CDMX was only open for 8 months, before closing. Rumours of a girl dying in the basement, family members killing them selves, and political issues with the Freemasons forced it's closure. After it became abandoned, Negro Durazo an infamously corrupt police chief tortured people in the basement.

Now, this abandoned building is a treasure trove for urban exploration, and paranormal activity . It looks like a set from a movie. Ivy twisting up the cracked walls, crumbling statues of saints, murals chipping away on the walls.

This was a special adventure, a creepy one, I hope you like a bit of horror, because that's exactly what this adventure was. I shot most of it on my new Gimbal the Zhiyun-Tech Crane. 

You can check it out here: http://geni.us/NewGimbal

Enjoy!

title: RAINBOW MOUNTAIN of the Philippines | Blue Soil Hills of Sagada vlog
description:
https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

There are a couple places in the world where you can see Rainbow Mountains. Rainbow Mountain in Peru is a tough hike at over 4000m, and also the Zhangye Danxia Landform Geological Park in China. There is something a little bit similar, and my first day in the Philippines lead me to this strange place. 

In this travel Philippines vlog, we head 12h north of Manila to Sagada. Home of the hanging coffins, Marlboro Country and Blue Soil Hills.

If you're a fan of beautiful nature, adventure, or seeing strange places, the blue soil hills and Marlboro County sunrise hike are epic.

Most people head to Kiltepan for sunrise. Don't do that. Instead book this hike. I was one of only a few people there. Sunrise at Kiltepan is PACKED. After seeing this amazing show, you hike another 2 hours to Blue Soil Hills.

Erosion has revealed a section of crumbling blue stone in the forest. Copper is responsible for this phenomenon. The copper in the soil reacts with the air and develops a patina. The fancy word for the green/blue coating you see on copper pennies or church roofs. This gives the soil a very unique appearance! You need to visit this place!

If you're filipina or filipino, let me know where I should go next. I've just wrapped up my first week, and I'll be here for a month!

title: SECRET ABANDONED CENOTE & RESORT | XPU HA BEACH RIVIERA MAYA MEXICO
description:
Along the coast of Riviera Maya in Mexico, there are hundreds of resorts. Xpu ha beach club (or Xpu-H√°) is a very popular "off the beaten path" spot for tourists to go to get away from the craziness of Cancun, Playa del Carmen, and Tulum... because of this, the place has become a bit of a tourist trap itself. 

In 2005, Hurricane Wilma, a category 5 monster destroyed much of Caribbean coast. 12 years later, you can still see the remains of resorts that were not rebuilt. Xpu-Ha Palace was one of those places. 

Some interesting features of this particular Riviera Maya resort was it's natural coral lagoon, which connected underground to a beautiful cenote which sat in the middle of the resort. This made it easily one of the most beautiful places to stay in Mexico, especially on this coast.

Now, there is a surprising amount of it still standing. Much of the wooden structures have fallen, but the shell of the resort still remains, and is just a 20 minute walk down the beach from Xpu-Ha Beach.

title: Buying 10,000 Bananas For Kids in Bangladesh
description:
Today we're buying 10,000 Bananas...
We've been travelling in Bangladesh for a week, cooking up one of the most interesting projects yet. While searching for Dhaka street food, we came across Karwan Bazaar, a large market in Dhaka with just about everything, Including a whole lot of Bananas.

In Bangladesh over 6 million kids wake up hungry, so we all came together to make a travel vlog with a purpose: raise enough money to buy 10,000 bananas for hungry kids in Bangladesh. To make this happen, I opened a GoFundMe, and reached out to Thrive, a local NGO specializing in delivering food to schools. We raised enough money for 18,800 bananas and this video is about delivering a few thousand of them to schools.

So, to address a few things here in the description. In total, we raised about 1,600 USD (including my personal donation to purchase bananas on the shoot day) They are about 3 cents per banana without shipping and delivery. For this video, we factored that in to our final sum. The shelf life of Bananas is only a few days, so we bought about 10,000 on that day, and the rest will be purchased later in the week so nothing gets spoiled. Cool? Cool!

Together we did this! Let's do more in 2020!

title: I woke up at 4:30AM to end laziness forever
description:
Listen, I've always had trouble waking up early. I'm not a morning person. My morning routine has been hit and miss. I was stuck in a bit of a rut, sleeping in late, eating junk food, and feeling sloppy. I was lazy, and I wanted to end my laziness forever.

Jocko Willink is an American retired officer of the United States Navy, who served in the Navy SEAL teams. He is also a podcaster and author of Disipline equals Freedom and Extreme Ownership. He is also a complete badass.

I came across his Jocko Podcast on YouTube, then dove in. He is an advocate of waking up at 4:30am, planning your day out the night before, doing the things you hate, and to go ‚ÄúGet After It‚Äù This video is about the ups and downs of trying this lifestyle, and my thoughts after.

Here's the free fear I talk about at the end: www.fearlessandfar.com/fear

And the song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8uxL0xhRQBk

title: EXPLORING AN ABANDONED CONDO IN MEXICO CITY (INSURGENTES 300)
description:
Check out my friends!

Exploring with Josh: https://www.youtube.com/user/theartofrealitycrew

Exploring with Cody:
https://www.youtube.com/user/SirCodyBuffinton
He gave me the drone footage too!

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

I'm in love with Mexico City. I moved here 2 months ago a noticed a huge abandoned building close to my house. It's a towering 17 stories, and it's crumbling concrete and smashed windows seem out of place in one of the best neighbourhoods in the city. 

Urban Exploration is something I can't get enough of, so I started to ask questions. The story was much more complicated and interesting than I thought. It was so much more can just an abandoned apartment building. It was quite famous in CDMX,  I had also seen a post by Vice Mexico about it in Spanish. I wanted to solve the mystery.

Insurgentes 300 is it's name. That comes from the name of the busy street it's located on, and also it's number on that street. This 500 room tower was built to be the biggest and most beautiful Condo in Latin America. Housing Doctors, Lawyers, and people of high class. In 1985, and earthquake of unprecedented magnitude rocked the city, toppling many building very similar to Insurgentes 300, thousands of people were trapped under the rubble. Our famous tower did not fall.

Unfortunately, it's foundation was badly damaged. The Mexican Government deemed it unsafe, it was evacuated, and condemned. No one was allowed to live there any longer.

Seizing the opportunity for free housing in a busy part of town, the filth of Mexico City ruled this abandoned building for the 30 years. Drug Dealers, Mafia, Criminals infested the building until very recently.  Scary People. The word was that it was more dangerous inside the building, than out. The Police entered and purged the place only 4 years ago. 

Now a brave group have begun renovating the building, floor by floor, trying to repair it enough to have the ban lifted. They want to return it to it's former glory. It will be a lot of work, and it will be a war to have the ban lifted.

I called up my friends Exploring with Josh and Exploring with Cody. We spoke to the caretakers, and they allowed us in for a tour. It was an amazing experience. We did our best to capture it. These are the reasons I travel.

title: SCUBA DIVING BELIZE | Ambergris Caye and Placencia | travel vlog 2019
description:
SCUBA diving in Belize in a highlight of both the Caribbean and tourism in Central America. While the jungles attract a lot of tourists, Belize is also home to the second largest barrier reef in the world. It has so many incredible experiences for those who love to dive or snorkel. For this SCUBA diving adventure travel vlog I teamed up with PADI, a world famous diver training organization, and William Drumm, a talented underwater photographer. 

We started the trip by taking a small plane from Belize City to San Pedro in Ambergris Caye. Here, we met up with Ramon's Village Resort and dove Hol Chan Marine Park, as well as many of the beautiful coral channels that snake through the reef. Highlights here for us were Nurse Sharks, Loggerhead Sea Turtles, and even an Octopus

Unfortunately our dive to The Great Blue Hole was cancelled due to weather, but ended up seeing a Bottlenose dolphin underwater close to the reef. Not a bad replacement.

Next was taking another plane from San Pedro to Placencia to meet Patricia at SPLASH dive centre to dive at Silk Caye. We island hopped, saw the underwater goddess statue, and trekked through Cockscomb Basin.

Hope you Enjoyed this SCUBA diving travel vlog in Belize!

For my Behind the Scenes Content: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

#Fearlessandfar #Belize #SCUBA

title: AMAZING FIREFLY SANCTUARY [THOUSANDS] | TLAXCALA MEXICO
description:
And the gold medal of 2017 goes to! 
Visiting the Firefly sanctuary near Nanacamilpa, Tlaxcala, Mexico was completely unbelievable. Thousands of them, and spinning and swirling around us and into the tree tops. Lighting up IN SYNC with each other like a coordinated light show. It didn't feel like planet earth, it felt like I stood up to fast and was seeing stars, it felt like I stepped into fantasy.

I drove 2 hours to stay at the eco lodge Piedra Canteada, deep in the pine forests of Oyamel. These insects show their faces for just a month every year to breed. This story might sound a little bit like the Monarch Butterfly Migration that we saw earlier in the year, but instead of flying from Canada, the fireflies are here all year round; you just can't see them.

The firefly we know, isn't even a fly, it's a beetle. All beetles have a larval stage called a grub, and fireflies live in the dirt without wings for 20 months before erupting out of a pupae (a bit like a cocoon) for one single month to have a giant sex party.

This show is easily one of the top 5 most amazing natural phenomena I have seen so far in my travels, and I can't believe it's not more popular. Bioluminescence continues to blow my mind. Glowing plankton, fireflies, mushrooms... I think it is incredible.

Enjoy this quick video of the Firefly Sanctuary in Tlaxcala, I don't think anyone has filmed it yet on Youtube. I needed special equipment, and It was a bit tricky to capture this for you guys.

title: CHURCH DESTROYED BY VOLCANO | EXPLORING VOLCAN PARICUT√çN
description:
This is one of Mexico's best kept secrets!
An abandoned church in the middle of a volcanic rock field. 60 years ago a whole town was destroyed by this volcano, and now just the church remains. A total adventure, and an explorer's dream. I teamed up with my urbex vlogging friends Exploring with Josh and Exploring with Cody to discover this amazing tourist attraction in Michoacan, Mexico. It was easily one of the most unbelievable locations I've visited in 2017. If you travel, it has to go on your bucket list.
 
La ciudad de San Juan and Volcan Paricutin have an amazing story.
In 1943 a crack opened up in a farmer's field, little did they know that a phenomenon brand new to science was about to be born. I'm no expert, but it's safe to say there have been hundreds of thousands of volcanos erupt while humans walked on two feet. This volcano however, was special. No volcano had ever been studied from birth to death. Every previous volcano had erupted some time in the past, formed a mountain, went dormant, then re-erupted. Volc√°n Par√≠cutin attracted scientists from around the world.

Besides the fact that exploring this place was amazing... being able to climb onto the towers (a bit scary), and get into the basement Altar... We had it to ourselves for 4 hours. There was no admission fee, there were no tourists. At the end a school group came, but that was it. It really felt like a genuine experience. This place should be much more famous.

Not featured in this video was the town of Angahuan, the launching point to see the volcano and the church. There, they speak Purepecha, not spanish. Also, there are loud speakers that blast prayers during the day. A very unique experience in Mexico.

Always happy to explore with Josh and Cody. Make sure to check out their channels

Exploring with Josh: https://www.youtube.com/user/theartofrealitycrew

title: SURVIVING a Russian Banya Ritual | Trans-Siberian Railway
description:
The Russian Banya (don't call it a Russian Sauna, I made that mistake) is the experience of alternating heat and cold exposure, mixed with being whipped with birch branches. While on the Trans-Siberian Railway, we make a stop in Yekaterinburg, in the Ural Mountains of Russia, and get an introduction to this important Russian ritual. The felt hats are used to prevent the head and hair from overheating, and are an interesting touch to the adventure!

This is glimpse in the real Russia, and I'd love to know if you'd give this bath house a shot!

title: Top 10 places you MISSED in the Philippines | Travel Vlog 2019
description:
Top 10 Philippines Locations on Trover: http://bit.ly/Philippines_Secret_Locations

After travelling as a foreigner in the Philippines for many months, I've been all over the country making travel vlogs. It really is a dream destination, but there's so much more to see than the beaches!

While I have been island hopping in Coron to visit kayangan lake, twin lagoon, and nacpan beach by el nido in Palawan. My mission was always to find what else was there.

I've avoided places like Siargao and Boracay. I'm sure they are some of the most beautiful places in the Philippines, but I've always felt they were not the best places to se Filipino culture.

This is a sort of Travel Guide for the Philippines. For people who like to get off the beaten path, and love adventure travel. 

These are my top 10 favourite destinations in the Philippines so far.

1. Apo Whang-Od 
The last mambabatok doing traditional Kalinga tattoos. Shes 102 years old and a legend in the Philippines. https://youtu.be/Ivn4-GzrETM

2. Blue Soil Hills
The rainbow mountain of the Philippines. There is blue soil just outside of Sagada in Northern Luzon. It's incredible to see. https://youtu.be/h1rfNMyUG0Q

3. The Hanging Coffins
Echo Valley is a very famous place to see the Hanging coffins. There are many better places however, you just have to ask.
https://youtu.be/p9vyz_HYKZM

4. The Sunken Cemetery
Just off the coast of Camiguin island there is a Giant Cross standing out in the ocean. Surrounding it is a cemetery sunk by a volcano. Only in the Philippines... https://youtu.be/lPCnUCvh-pg

5. Warship Graveyard of Coron
While many go island hopping in Coron, there is another adventure under the waves. Giant Japanese warships are sunk, and ready to explore for advanced Scuba Divers.
https://youtu.be/ZVa1bOwyprA

6. Britania Islands
Just below Siargao in Mindanao, in Surigao del Sur, you can find these magnificent islands. Very few people venture this far. https://youtu.be/CgyE2DyVppg

7. Matigol Falls
Easily one of the most amazing waterfalls in the Philippines, and unknown to tourism outside of Mindanao. This waterfall was "The one that got away" https://youtu.be/FDre4ptJPiU

8. Bulingan Falls
A stepping stone Columnar Basalt waterfall on Basilan, Mindanao. There can't be very many of these on planet earth. https://youtu.be/A8UANZdETHU

9. Torpedo Boats
Illegal logging boats are now being used to shoot thrill seeking tourists up rivers in Northen Samar.
https://youtu.be/K03sxDaJSHU

10. Filipino Food.
Food in the Philippines has a bad repuatation. Most of it is quite tasty, even if it doesn't appeal to the western Palette. Especially the street food! https://youtu.be/PVEeScXdSVU

I hope you enjoyed this video! Did I miss anything you think I should have included?

Make sure to check out the community on Patreon!
I post extra videos there for my supporters. 

https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar


#FearlessandFar #Philippines #Travel #Travelvlog

title: Diving MASSIVE Japanese Shipwrecks in Coron Philippines
description:
Coron Palawan Philippines is becoming legendary. World class island hopping and beautiful blue water is reason enough to visit. It's already paradise for adventure travel, but the Scuba diving in Coron is a hidden secret. Not many know that it is home to some of the best wreck diving in the world.

Just north of Palawan Island, and about 30 meters below the surface in Coron Bay is a fleet of Japanese warships, sunk by American bombers in 1944 as they were fleeing the Philippines. These ships are massive. Some are over 150 meters long, and almost completely intact. 

In this Philippines travel vlog, I team up with Exploring with Cody, and we tag team this incredible location. This was one of my favourite adventures in the Philippines. Let's go back!

#FearlessandFar #Coron #Palawan #Philippines

title: PIAYNEMO Island Hopping | RAJA AMPAT | travel Indonesia vlog
description:
In this Indonesia travel vlog we visit Pianemo Raja Ampat. This beautiful part of Eastern Indonesia is very close to Papua, and  famous the large schools of fish seen diving and snorkeling. Besides this, huge karst islands rise out of the turquoise ocean like teeth and form incredible lagoons. This makes the island hopping experience here in Raja Ampat some of the best in the world as well.

In this vlog we hike up to the top of the Piaynemo view point, race back down to get a shot in the lagoon, have lunch with sharks, and then end up at a Rainy Batu Pencil to end the day.

Big love to Wonderful Indonesia for hosting this trip!
This was part of the #TripOfWonders, and annual influencer trip where creators get together and explore Wonderful Indonesia

#FearlessandFar #Tripofwonders #RajaAmpat

title: Eva Zu Beck vs. The Deep Ocean | Chase Your Fears Ep. 1
description:
Eva Zu Beck is a solo female adventure travel YouTuber and TV Host with notable series in Pakistan, Socotra island, and Syria. After a traumatic experience when she was younger, she has a phobia of being adrift in the open ocean. This is called Thalassophobia, and it's very common.

I connect with Yahya, a Master Freediving instructor in Muscat, Oman. Through his dive shop, Divers Planet, he agrees to teach Eva how to Freedive. The art of apnea; breath holding underwater.

Over the course of a week, we slowly re-introduce Eva to the Open Ocean again, in a fun and more informed way. Will she conquer her fear and become a mermaid? Or disappear forever in the deep blue ocean... (She's still here) But did she succeed?

@Eva Zu Beck's Channel: https://www.youtube.com/evazubeckofficial

title: What is this SOUP? | Davao City Street Food Vlog | Becoming Filipino
description:
In this Philippines travel vlog, I team up with Becoming Filipino to take on a strange Filipino street food in Bankerohan Public Market, Davao City, Mindanao.

Being a foreigner in the Philippines, Bulcachong took me a bit by surprise. It's a specialty in Davao City, and you can definitely see why. It's a unique street food, and quite interesting to look at. Perfect for a travel vlogger who likes adventurous eating.

Made from Water Buffalo or Beef, this soup is actually pretty tasty. The meat is boiled for 4 or 5 hours until (mostly) tender. However the meat wasn't exactly what I was used to. Even after 2 months of eating and making travel vlogs of street food in the Philippines I had not seen anything like it before. Even in my entire career as a travel YouTuber, I have not seen this part of the animal before.

Some was identifiable, some wasn't, a few bits were tender, most was chewy, but either way... this soup was delicious. I still don't know what half of the animal parts were but it doesn't matter. I would 100% have it again! And I would 100% recommend Davao City travel as well. Mindanao is amazing.

#FearlessandFar #DavaoCity #Streetfood

More videos here: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: A WEIRD DAY in the Philippines üòÇ| Fighter Boys Travel vlog 2019
description:
This Philippines Travel vlog almost kicks off with a disaster. On our Fighter Boys road trip through Northern Samar, our Drive Shaft breaks. This is a serious problem, as in some cases this can launch a truck into the air. Luckily this time all we had to do is wait for the local mechanics to fix it, we rewarded them with a giant box of Fighter Wine.

We then visit the beautiful Bangon falls. A cool cascading waterfall in the heart of the jungle. The Fighter Boys were very ready for a quick shower after all day in the sun waiting for the bus to be fixed.

Last year I travelled for 3 months as a foreigner in the Philippines before concluding my filipino travel vlog series with the Fighter Boys trip with Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, Bret Maverick. Nicknamed the Fighter Boys, after our sponsor Fighter Wine. 

Hope you enjoyed this wild video! Would you jump in the falls too?

title: LAS COLORADAS YUCATAN - THE RAINBOW SALT FLATS OF MEXICO
description:
This is Las Coloradas Yucatan, the rainbow salt flats of Rio Lagartos Mexico. It took us 4 trips to get this one right, and finally we got a our quadcopter the DJI Inspire 1 drone flight in! You can find pools of green, orange, and pink here. These are ancient drying beds for salt, the more pink the water, the higher the concentration. This place is in the middle of nowhere, and is a helluva thing to see! It's similar to Salar de Uyuni in Bolivia, just add a little bit more color ;)

In our 4 visits to Las Coloradas, we only saw about 5 other people visiting. It's basically unheard of, and you can spend the whole day by yourself there. The drive from Merida or Cancun is about 3 hours, but it's worth it as there's lots of other things to see up there as well. Flamingos, Mud Baths, Dolphins, etc.

If Mexico is on your travel list, and you find yourself in the Yucatan Peninsula, make the trip to Las Coloradas.

More Amazing Places: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi3Job3GlVKyxD3UUaTWJ-Ad

title: MEXICO: LAS POZAS DE XILITLA
description:
Welcome to the surreal gardens of Las Pozas de Edward James.
It's a fantasy world tucked away in the Jungles of Xilitla, a Pueblo Magico of Mexico. Built by an eccentric Millionaire, and slowly being reclaimed by the forest, Las Pozas is one of the secrets of San Luis Potosi. It's an amazing place we only heard about by chance, but happy we could add it in... cause damn... I've never seen anything like it.

Walking in the doors of Las Pozas, you begin to see a sculpture park being taken over by nature. During the hours we spent there, we didn't see very many other tours or tourists. Perhaps it's because of the labyrinth like design, but there was a lot of time we were just relaxing by the pools all by ourselves

Getting to San Luis Potos√≠ took us a little while. We drove up from Mexico City to see Las Pozas de Xilitla and Cascada Tamul. We didn't realize how much there is to see here. Puente de Dios, Sotano de Golondrinas, and much more... As a Canadian visiting Mexico, I'm not used to so much density of cool things to do. 

More Adventures: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi2f1i420TZR68ie5HJF9-V7

title: COOLEST AIRBNB IN MEXICO | INSIDE QUETZALCOATL'S NEST SNAKE HOUSE
description:
This the coolest airbnb I've ever stayed in. There are some amazing things to do in Mexico City, and if you want to travel just a short distance outside of it, you'll find the Nido de Quetzalcoatl or Quetzalcoatl's Nest tucked inside the valleys of Naucalpan.

It is a series of 10 apartments build into the back of a giant serpent. It's the coolest house I've ever seen, if you don't mind living in a snake god.

This park was created by Javier Senosiain, a Mexican architect specializing in Organic Architecture. This philosophy of construction blends seamlessly with nature, so they both work together in harmony. When Javier first decided to build the park, he came across a giant cave whose opening resembled the gaping mouth of a snake. This inspired him to continue the theme, and great a giant 18 hectare park, with 13 snakes twisting through it. Despite everything he has created here, the valley in which everything is hidden, is vastly untouched. His constructions are guided using the natural shape of the land. 

As far as things to do in Mexico, this is an absolute must. I have never seen anything like this in all of my years as a travel vlogger. It is truly an oasis hidden away from the bustle of Mexico City

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

TO VISIT:

At this time you have two options. A private tour or staying in the apartment. Our contact for both of these is Patricia. Her email: mopacastillo(at)gmail.com

The easiest, and which that allows you the most freedom is to stay there overnight. It is a 8-10 person apartment, with a recommended minimum of 2 nights. This can sometimes be negotiated depending on the time of year. Get some friends together and split the cost. It is worth it.

The Airbnb Listing is here: https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/10153978

If you don't have an Airbnb account, you can my link to get $35 off your first booking: www.airbnb.com/c/mcorey24

title: How I got My Own Travel TV Show  - UNCHARTED ADVENTURE
description:
My new TV Show UNCHARTED ADVENTURE Premieres TONIGHT!
Sunday November 7th 9pm Eastern on @TheWeatherChannel in the USA.

This was the reason I was a little quiet this summer on YouTube. I was filming the biggest project so far.

Listen. For most of my of my life I was afraid to speak, now I have my own network TV show‚Ä¶ Let‚Äôs talk about something quick, watch this video.

title: Racing GOKARTS in Venezuela's Most Dangerous Slum
description:
Petare, located on the eastern outskirts of Caracas, is one of the largest and most densely populated slums in Latin America. Known for its vibrant culture and resilience, Petare is also infamous for its high crime rates and extreme poverty. Violence is a daily reality, with armed gangs, drug trafficking, and kidnappings shaping the lives of many residents. Even locals must navigate the streets with caution, as petty crime and violent confrontations can erupt without warning. Security forces are often outnumbered or compromised, making it a challenging environment for law enforcement. For travelers, entering Petare without a trusted guide or local knowledge is highly discouraged, as the risks of robbery or worse are significant. Despite these dangers, Petare is also home to a community striving for change, with grassroots organizations working tirelessly to offer hope and opportunity in one of Venezuela‚Äôs most perilous regions.

Support Petare and donate to Unos Venezolanos! 
https://www.unosvenezolanos.com/apoyo-monetario

title: EATING DORILOCOS IN MEXICO CITY | STRANGE MEXICAN STREET FOOD
description:
There are so many kinds of strange Mexican Street Food. Mexico City especially has great things to eat, you call walk all through the streets eating much more than just tacos. If you like doing a taste test of local street food in any culture. This country has some of the best!

We hit a street market just beside Chapultepec Castle. Here you can find all kinds of interesting Mexican street foods and candies. In particular we were searching for a weird one called DoriLocos. This is when you take a bag of Doritos, cut it open, and add all sorts of typical Mexican Salsas and spices. It starts with carrots and cucumbers, then Cueritos (pig skin fat), Valentina, Miguelito, Chamoy, peanuts (Cacuates Japones), and you top it off with lime. 

While maybe not that traditional, this snack is very common in the street. Myself and Davidsbeenhere had never tried it before, so here you can see our real reaction to this crazy Mexican dish.

title: This View üòÆ| Baltit Fort, Attabad Lake & Karimabad in HUNZA Pakistan
description:
In this Pakistan Travel Vlog we visit Baltit Fort, Attabad Lake & Karimabad in Hunza Valley. This is right after some epic hiking to fairy meadows to get a view of Nanga Parbat.

Northern Pakistan is beautiful, and we discover all sorts of interesting things in this episode.

We start off in Karimabad where we try on some tardition Pakistani clothing from the area. There was even a rock tea! I'll have it next time. After we hike up the steep hills to Baltit Fort. From the top you can really see howe incredible the valley is. There are towers of stone in every direction.

We continue our road trip to Attabad lake which was created by an avalanche which blocked a river. It's vibrant blue, and somewhere below the surface there is a drowned town. That's an adventure for another day.

Pakistan tourism is on the rise. It's often called a dangerous place to travel. Our purpose was to spend our time, as foreigners in Pakistan to disprove this, and show the beauty of the people and the landscape to the world. CPIC Global sponsored out trip, but we did so without any security or military escorts. The only trouble we got into was bumpy roads.

While normally I solo travel, I was excited to have so many friends on the trip. Siya Zarabi from Hopscotch the Globe, Lexie Alford from Lexie Limitless, Ryan Riel from Opposite Travellers, Anushae Khan, Brooke Saward, and Alexandrina Cojocaru.

For an email once a month with all my favourite things I've found in the world... Join the Adventure Newsletter

title: MEXICO‚ÄôS STRANGEST DRINK | PULQUERIA TEMPLO DE DIANA
description:
This place is easily my favorite to drink in Mexico City. If you‚Äôre a fan of weird, unusual, or strange street food. This is a traditional Mexican drink you need to try. drink Templo de Diana is a Pulqueria in Xochimilco, CDMX. It serves a drink you probably haven‚Äôt heard of before.

Here you can try an ancient Aztec drink called Pulque, the fermented sap of a kind of cactus called Maguey.

Both agave and maguey have been extremely important in the history of Mexico. These two kinds of plant have been distilled, fermented, dried, twisted, and cut into all sorts of useful things. Everything from alcohol to rope.

Pulque itself has a very interesting history. It was the drink of choice for hundreds of years by the Aztecs. When the beer brands arrived they saw this slimy white drink dominating their niche, and spread rumors about it being Fermented in the same barrels as human feces. This killed Pulque, and the beer companies won.

We set out to try the strangest flavors they had. Celery, beet, and Oyster. Would you give it a shot?

title: Philippines CRAZIEST food? SOUP #5 in MINDANAO | Filipino Travel Vlog
description:
This Filipino street food is one of the strangest and most exotic you can find in the country. As a foreigner in the Philippines I was shocked this soup even existed. I teamed up with Kyle Jennermann (Kulas) of Becoming Filipino to create a Philippines travel vlog about this bull penis and testicle dish in Cagayan de Oro, Mindanao.

I had first heard of this Pinoy delicacy in while researching Manila street food. Soup number 5, RM Soup, Remember Me are all names for this dish. It is often eaten as a hangover food and aphrodisiac (why do weird foods always increase your sex drive?)

 It turns out it a bit hard to find. I know the Best Ever Food Review Show had some false leads in Manila, but Kulas had a great place, called RM Station in Cagayan de Oro. We got lucky, they have full penis and testicles that had not been cut up into soup. I never thought I would have to type that sentence. 

Have you guys checked out the Fighterboys series yet?
Make sure to check out my boys, Bret Maverick, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, and last but definitely not least Kyle Jennermann who helped me create this video. Links are below!

title: A STEPPING STONE WATERFALL?! üí¶BASILAN Mindanao Philippines travel vlog 2018
description:
This is Episode 3 of Discovering Basilan Mindanao Philippines with Becoming Filipino. In this Philippines travel vlog we experience Filipino hospitality at its finest. Starting off our day, we visit Lamitan City, home of the weavers, here we are given beautiful headbands as a gify from the village elder, and I try my hardest to crack a coconut. After we grab a lunch and I somehow find myself trying Betel Nut again, (Called Apo here), and we explore a columnar basalt waterfall called Bulingan Falls... and I can tell you, it's one of the best waterfalls in the Philippines. While visiting this island might not be at the top of Foreigner tourist list of the top things to do in the Philippines, we hope that soon people will begin to return to this beautiful island.

A bit more backstory on Basilan, and this series.
This small island has had a lot of trouble in the past. Muslim extremist groups have damaged its people and its reputation. As a foreigner in the Philippines, everyone told me to stay away from the south. Mindanao was "dangerous" and "no one should go", is what I was told by both filipinos and foreign travelers. After the Mindanao roadtrip with the Fighterboys, I would have to disagree. Love and generosity is what we experienced, an appreciation from the people that I have rarely felt while travelling the world. We met the governor of ARMM, our local contact (always have a local contact) and spent 4 days here. While I wouldn't recommend travelling here on your first day in the Philippines, 

This is Day 2 of exploring Basilan Mindanao Philippines.

#FearlessandFar #Basilan #Mindanao

title: Why Tribes have Straight White Teeth pt. 2 ü¶∑ #tribe #travel #dentistry
description: You all got so mad at me, so here‚Äôs more facts.

title: Camiguin Island CLAM SANCTUARY | Philippines Travel Vlog 2018
description:
In this Philippines travel vlog, we visit Camiguin Island in Northern Mindanao. I've been wanting to visit ever since some filipino subscribers told me about the sunken cemetery on the island. My expat friend Kyle Jennermann (Becoming Filipino), and his buddy Kumar connected me with Aitz, a local who own a place on the island called Hayahay Cafe.

In this travel video, we visit the Kibila Giant Clams Sanctuary, and another smaller coral and clam sanctuary. One day was spent free diving, and the other SCUBA diving. 

I learned a lot about giant clams that day. There are 9 species in the world, 6 of which can be found in the Philippines. The are much like coral; a symbiotic relationship between an animal and a plant, where each feeds the other. Giant clams are colourful because of the algae that live inside their mantle. This algae uses photosynthesis to create food from the sun. The clam sucks in water and filters out the plankton. Teamwork for the win.

This also means, like coral, giant clams can bleach. When the algae living inside the clams skin (or mantle) doesn't like the water conditions, it leaves. Since this algae gives coral and clams their colour, the animal turns white. This does not mean it's dead, but it does mean that it's in trouble.

https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

#FearlessandFar #Camiguin

title: EXPLORING CHOCOLATE HILLS BOHOL | Fighter boys | Philippines travel vlog
description:
The fighter boys take on the Chocolate Hills in Bohol! 

Last year I travelled for 3 months as a foreigner in the Philippines before concluding my filipino travel vlog series with the Fighter Boys trip with Kyle Jennermann of Becoming Filipino, Daniel Marsh, Finn Snow, Bret Maverick. Nicknamed the Fighter Boys, after our sponsor Fighter Wine. We did a 2 week road trip through Mindanao

This year our sights were set on some different islands. Our first in this series was Camiguin Island, and now we've landed in Bohol.

The Chocolate hills in Bohol are definitely a mainstream attraction in Bohol. However, we all enjoy carving our own path in life and travel, and soon found ourselves on a dirt path trying to find our own private experience. 

We found exactly that. This place was special, and I hope you can see that in this Philippines travel vlog.

title: UNDERWATER MUSEUM SCUBA DIVING IN CANCUN MEXICO
description:
The MUSA Underwater Museum. Between Cancun and the island of Isla Mujeres in Mexico, there is an incredible place to Scuba dive. It's an underwater sculpture park, acting as a coral reef for all of the incredible animals underwater.

Jason Decaires Taylor a British scultor created the very first park of this kind in 2009. Now it attracts Scuba divers and snorkelers from all over the world. A diving highlight of Riviera Maya and the Yucatan Peninsula, it's really easy to get to from Cancun. I hopped on the ferry from Puerto Juarez to Isla Mujeres and found myself a hostel called PocNa. We did a few dives together. 3 on the museum to shoot this video, another few on the nearby Manchones reef, which has a few more sculptures and an incredible amount of fish.

We also did a dive at the nearby wreck called GunBoat 58 during eagle ray mating season. That.... was a show.

If you're not Scuba Certified, you need to join the club. There are a lot of PADI dive centres down there that can hook you up. The earth is 70% water, and we only explore the 30% that is land. Go and Get Wet!

title: USAT LIBERTY SHIPWRECK IN TULAMBEN BALI
description:
The Tulamben USAT Liberty Shipwreck is some of best scuba diving in Bali Indonesia. It's quite famous actually, the diving here is very unique. In very few places on this planet is there a wreck this big, or this close to the shore. The wreck acts as a pseudo coral reef, and attracts animals big and small to hide in it's crevices. The beautiful thing about the USAT Liberty wreck is that you can snorkel or free dive it. The bow is only a couple meters from the surface, and you can just walk in from the shore. Normally dive sites like this are far beneath the surface, way too deep for anything but scuba equipment.

It's a beautiful place, and totally worth checking out.

 I did a special birthday trip after a great few weeks on the #tripofwonders with Travel Indonesia. Enjoy!

title: MEXICO: CENOTE ANGELITA SCUBA DIVING IN POISON
description:
This scuba dive, wow. Cenote Angelita in Tulum, Mexico was amazing. First off, it's a deep one at 34m (100ft). Secondly,  there is a 10 foot thick layer of Hydrogen Sulfide at 30m you are able to pass through. Hydrogen Sulfide is poisonous, and heavily smells of rotten eggs. (I couldn't show you that part in the video). Once through, it turns into a night dive, and you need to use your torches. You only have a few minutes beyond the layer before you have to start ascending again. It's a murky landscape, with petrified trees sticking out of the cloud. Mayans believed that cenotoes were the gateway to the underworld, and yeah, after visiting this one in particular, I can see why.

This was probably one of the most advanced dives I've done. It's not technically difficult, but it is a mental challenge. It's not uncommon for divers to panic a little bit and have difficulty passing the layer. Like always in diving, keeping a calm mind is the most important thing. Anyone can do this dive, it's just remembering to breathe, and realizing you'll be fine.

There are a lot of cenote cave dives scattered all through Riviera Maya, Quintanaroo and Yucatan. I was lucky do quite a few during my travels here. I thought that I wanted to get my Cave Diving cerification, but realized that "Cavern" diving (when you can still see ambient light) is all I really wanted. You just need to have an advanced cert.

It was the most exhilarating dive I've done yet, I'm not sure if there is anything else like it on the planet. Go in and get wet.

title: FILIPINO CULTURE OVERLOAD üáµüá≠ | COTABATO CITY VLOG Mindanao Philippines
description:
Welcome to Cotabato City Mindanao Philippines!
In this filipino travel vlog, we leave the island of Basilan to investigate the 5 cultural villages set up in Cotabato City. Here, you can see many example of Filipino Culture. Specifically the regions of ARMM the Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao; Basilan, Sulu, Lanao del Sur, Maguindanao, and Tawi-Tawi

We found some strange Filipino food, A tuntungan instrument, kris blades, and some awesome people to party with. As a foreigner in the Philippines, it was a very warm welcome ‚ù§Ô∏è

A bit more backstory on Basilan, and this series.
This small island has had a lot of trouble in the past. Muslim extremist groups have damaged its people and its reputation. As a foreigner in the Philippines, everyone told me to stay away from the south. Mindanao was "dangerous" and "no one should go", is what I was told by both filipinos and foreign travelers. After the Mindanao roadtrip with the Fighterboys, I would have to disagree. Love and generosity is what we experienced, an appreciation from the people that I have rarely felt while travelling the world. We met the governor of ARMM, our local contact (always have a local contact) and spent 4 days here. While I wouldn't recommend travelling here on your first day in the Philippines, 

This is Day 3 of exploring Basilan Mindanao Philippines.

#FearlessandFar #Basilan #Mindanao

title: NIGHT OF THE RADISHES | STRANGE FESTIVAL OAXACA CITY MEXICO
description:
While looking for things to do in Oaxaca City over Christmas, I found this strange and unique festival that happens every 23rd of December called Noche de Los Rabanos, or Night of the Radishes.

It all started over 100 years ago when farmers would bring their vegetables to be sold at the Christmas Market in the Zocalo, also known as the main square. There were many Mexicans selling their goods there, and the competition was tough. One day one of the farmers thought "How can I get people to stop at my vegetable stand?
" He began carving radishes to attract customers. The other saw this, and began to copy him. Each year they build larger and more extravagant sculptures and "Night of the Radishes" was born. 

These days, it has become quite a attraction in Oaxaca City. Thousands of people, mostly locals, wait hours in line to see over 100 exhibits. The event starts in the afternoon, and goes until midnight.

Big thanks to Enjoy Oaxaca for hooking us up with a press pass to get a closer look into the festival! They can organize your time in the state very well if you're looking for tours. Check them out here: http://www.enjoyoaxaca.mx/

title: It‚Äôs IMPOSSIBLE to Eat $10 of Street Food Here
description:
Bangladesh Street food is delicious and cheap. It's a great budget travel destination. After spending 2 weeks in the country, riding on the front of trains and buying 10,000 bananas... we realized we hadn't spend much time eating... which was a shame. I teamed up with Eva Zu Beck and Cholo Bangadesh Tours to take a deep dive into Dhaka Street Food, but I wanted to try something a little bit different.
Knowing how inexpensive it was to eat on the street, I wanted to know if it was even possible to eat 10 USD of the best street food in Bangladesh. We skipped breakfast and lunch to do this food challenge. 
Do you think we made it through?

Dhaka street food we tried in this video:

Kola bhorta
Fuchka 
Chotpoti
Payesh
Bakorkhani 
Bananas
Bhapa pitha
Beef chaap

agun Paan (fire paan)

title: The city where DOGS ARE ILLEGAL | Ashgabat, Turkmenistan
description:
Ashgabat Turkmenistan is one of the strangest cities I have ever made a travel vlog about.

Recently brought to the attention of the world through John Oliver's popular program Last Week Tonight, Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov, Turkmenistan's Dictator/President is quite a character.

However the craziness it didn't all start with him. Turkmenistan's first president, Turkmenbashi, set quite a powerful precedent. 

He instated many strange rules for the country, and for the city of Ashgabat. No opera, it's too noisy, no makeup on television, the natural beauty of the Turkmen people is enough, and no dogs. Dogs were not allowed in the Capital city of Ashgabat due to their "foul odor".... what?

We only had a short day in Ashgabat before continuing our trip to Merv, and eventually to roast marshmallows over the door to hell. We were able to do some sightseeing to the Arc of Neutrality, which is topped with a golden rotating statue of Turkmenbashi, also the wedding palace of happiness, and the world's largest indoor Ferris Wheel, which is the next vlog üëåüèª

We visited in early 2019, but it's worth putting on your radar for 2020. The new president Gurbanguly has opened up the country much more than it used to be. Getting the VISA wasn't a walk in the park, but our friends at Lupine Travel set everything up for us.. Check out their trips to some of the lesser travelled countries!

https://lupinetravel.co.uk/central-asia-five-stans-holidays-and-tours/
