title: TOP 5 DEMONETIZED ‚õîÔ∏è Travel Videos on FEARLESS & FAR
description:
See the shots too raw for YouTube, and support Fearless & Far on Patreon üêâhttps://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

We film some strange stuff on Fearless & Far. In this video we talk about the Top 5 demonetized travel videos I've posted so far, no doubt there is more to come. It's quite common for my vlogs to get flagged.

When watching videos on my channel, you know you are signing up for a special kind of travel vlog. I'm a travel vlogger that is not for everybody, some travel videos are only for those who wish to see the strange, unique, and undiscovered places on our planet.

From Hanging Coffins, to soup number 5, the vegetarian festival and La Tomatina, some of the festivals, events and destinations are rightfully demonetized, and others maybe not. At this point I'm just happy I'm not banned.

Here's a break down of some of the content that has been demonetized on my channel.

La Tomatina is the biggest food fight in the world. 50,000 people all show up to the sleepy little town of Bu√±ol, Spain once a year in August to throw Tomatoes at each other for an hour. The travel video I made was demonetized about a year later. While it might look like I‚Äôm in the middle of a massacre, it seems like everyone but YouTube can realize that it‚Äôs only thousands of mashed tomatoes. Even after appealing the flag over and over, they have not let me monetize it again, and it‚Äôs deemed ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù https://youtu.be/DtA8zS3nlrc

The Vegetarian Festival sounds like a harmless celebration. It's not. Happening in many locations in South East Asia, with many different names. This festival is about pain tolerance and possession. Practitioners pierce their skin with all sorts of items to show their devotion to the gods. It was rightfully demonetized. Ouch.
https://youtu.be/JFyfjCx3EEQ

Soup Number 5 seems like a harmless item on this list. It's a delicacy in the Philippines. Also called Remember Me Soup or RM Soup it's the cut up manhood of a bull, sliced in a beautifully delicious broth. The Philippines is not short of strange but surprisingly delicious food. A big shout out to my Filipino subscribers for finding some great ones for me.
https://youtu.be/T--Z_ZI83Bc

The Trunyan Cemetery was rightfully demonetized, and I still can‚Äôt believe this really exists. On an island in a small lake in Northen Bali, there is a strange cemetery, and an even more strange tradition around death. There is a tree on this small island that is suppose to be the only one in existence. This tree releases one of the most beautiful scents in the world. So much so, that it begun to cause a problem to the residents of the small town of Trunyan. Long story short, love makes people do crazy things. To win the heart of a woman, a man discovered that placing the deceased around this tree cancelled out the smell. Now for a thousand years later, there is a pile of skulls, and 11 bodies laying open face next to the tree. The practice still continues. https://youtu.be/5M5HHWLOMeQ

The Botfly experience was a recent adventure that many of you probably saw. While travelling in Belize, a small fly landed on my skin and laid an egg. There really wasn‚Äôt anything I could do to stop this from happening. It‚Äôs just bad luck. Fast forward 5 weeks later and I‚Äôm on the other side of the world travelling with a friend, and discover that the strange pimple on my wrist has a dark secret‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs the home of a skin parasite. A developing larva. I‚Äôm a parasitic host to a Botfly.
https://youtu.be/rs-Uifguu2w

The Day of the Dead festival in Mexico was a surprise. https://youtu.be/MWwT-r2uBv4

Another Travel Vlog that was unexpectedly demonetized was ‚ÄúToques Electricos‚Äù.https://youtu.be/vbok03kDy1o

Hope you enjoyed this video! Which deserved it, and which didn't?

#FearlessandFar #Demonetized #Travel

title: Pakistan DANCE PARTY in Khaplu Gilgit Baltistan
description:
Khaplu in Gilgit-Baltistan in Northern Pakistan in Beautiful.

In this travel vlog we start out at Khaplu palace, where we had previously spent the night. Here we‚Äôre invited to a high tea in a balcony overlooking the towering mountains surrounding the area.

While driving along the Karakoram Highway, we saw some kids playing soccer in the Cold Desert.
We stopped to go film this incredible game in the blowing sand, when returning to the road a traveling troop of musicians had pulled over as well, they saw us with cameras, came down from the top of the van and started a party. We all joined!

Pakistan tourism is on the rise. It's often called a dangerous place to travel. Our purpose was to spend our time, as foreigners in Pakistan to disprove this, and show the beauty of the people and the landscape to the world. CPIC Global sponsored out trip, but we did so without any security or military escorts. The only trouble we got into was bumpy roads.

While normally I solo travel, I was excited to have so many friends on the trip. Siya Zarabi from Hopscotch the Globe, Lexie Alford from Lexie Limitless, Ryan Riel from Opposite Travellers, Anushae Khan, Brooke Saward, and Alexandrina Cojocaru.


Also, I post extra videos on my Patreon. Some are not for the faint of heart! It's the best way to support the channel.

title: Eating PANCITA MEXICANA?! üò≥Street Food in Coyoacan Mexico City | Exploring with Cody
description:
Pancita Mexicana or Menudo. Cow Stomach Soup for you english speakers... is a Mexican Street Food I have seen in a lot of Mexico City markets. This country has some strange, weird, and crazy things to eat, and this one is not too hard to find.

From what I heard, people either love it or hate it. It's history goes all the way back to the Spanish conquest, where the locals were given the scraps of left over meat to eat. They decided to make the best of it, and that was the birth of a lot of these stranger street foods in Mexico.

Exploring with Cody and I found this Mexican specialty in the Mercado de Coyoacan, or Coyoacan food market. Here, you can find everything... street tacos, garnachas, pozole, pancita de res, and even sesos (brians) which we ate on Cody's channel.

Having lived in Mexico City for almost a year, I had surprisingly not tried this Mexican snack, but I had seen it everywhere. Trying it is definitely one of the top things to do in Mexico.

After making this video, I learned that maybe we had made a mistake... Are both of these flour? Or is one actually the real one?

Mexico is so much more than just tacos. There is god level street food here, allowing for some great food videos. Would you give this a taste test? Did we eat pancita right? Did we do something wrong in the preparation? let us know!

title: Living the Russian Stereotype üòÇ
description:
In this episode, we visit Novosibirsk and Yekaterinburg on the Trans Siberian Railway.
Most of this Russia travel vlog is spent in the Ural Mountains, the barrier between Western Russia, and Siberia. We join with TOCHKA 4x4 a local adventure group for some serious off roading. 

While we realize that happened next is not an accurate depiction of everyday Russia, we were surprised with some traditional music, and guns. We were offered the opportunity my birthday by firing off a few rounds in the forest, we had never done this before. Though, I admit we wanted to. This small part of Russian culture is definitely the Russian stereotype, and it was a lot of fun to join the locals celebrating this way for a night.

Next we met a group of pagans living simply in the forest. Here, we helped them create trinkets with molten metal, another first for me.

Lastly we were invited to dinner at the house of a Russian Oligarch (Who had a tank in his front yard), and drank vodka while being served some incredible Russian Food.

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok. 

A big thank you to the sponsors of the #TransSibChallenge

title: PICKPOCKET HIDDEN CAMERA | Khaosan Road Bangkok Thailand Nightlife
description:
Join the Adventure Newsletter üêâ
https://fearlessandfar.com/join-our-adventure-newsletter

In this Thailand travel vlog I test if it really is that easy to get pickpocketed while travelling. Armed with a hidden camera and a baited wallet, do you think I can catfish a pickpocket, and catch them red handed? I walked along Khaosan road for hours. Here's what I caught on camera.

Bangkok Thailand is backpacking paradise with so many things to do. 
While definitely not off the beaten path, Bangkok nightlife, thai food, temples, and thai culture, attract tourists from all over the world.

Thailand is called the land of smiles, but due to all the tourists that flock there, it's also the land of scams. Khao San Road is the Backpacker area. It's a walking street and it's crazy. Scorpions on sticks, laughing gas, ping pong shows, and a large amount of thai street food. It's an easy area to potentially find scams and trouble.

Listen, the last thing I want to do is to scare anyone away from travelling. The point of this series it to see if it is really that easy to get pickpocketed abroad. 

Support the channel, and get access to the footage to graphic for YouTube: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

#FearlessandFar #Thailand #Bangkok #Pickpocket #Scams

title: EATING THE WORLD'S SPICIEST BURGER | 50K SUBSCRIBERS CHALLENGE
description:
MARIANNELA'S VIDEO TOMORROW 2/11/17

50k Subscribers! You're all the best. I have a food challenge for you today to celebrate. Eating the spiciest burger in the world!

There's this great American style burger place on Alvaro Obregon in Colonia Roma, Mexico City. We went there for the first time a few months ago, and I saw a challenge on the menu "Eat the hottest burger in the world, with fries and a litre of beer in 3 minutes" I bookmarked that for later and here we are today,... both about eat one of the spiciest creations in Mexico (they say the world).

While this particular challenge didn't have the spiciest pepper in the world, the naga chilli (or ghost pepper) it did have a tower of Serrano and Habaneros peppers. Serranos being 5 times hotter than Jalape√±os and Habaneros 30 times hotter. It wasn't a joke.

For real though, It felt like a speed eating competition. My spice tolerance is high, so the burn really only hit me midway. To feel the full heat you have to sit back, but there was no time for that in this challenge. This was a true man vs food scenario, and while it might not stack up to furious pete or hot ones on first we feast... this thing was straight fire!

title: HOW TO LIGHT PAINT IN AN ABANDONED FACTORY (PHOTOGRAPHY TUTORIAL)
description:
MY INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/kickthegrind/

In the beginning, I had no interest in photography. It seemed complicated, and video was much more attractive. I came across a night photography and light painting tutorial video, and then that all changed. Learning photography is the secret to making beautiful videos. Most of what you learn transfers over directly. It's the key to making art with a camera.

When taking photos, the best way to learn is to play. Getting ideas by watching videos about tips, tricks, hacks, how-to's, then going out and make your version of the idea. It's not stealing, it's inspiration, and it's how creatives get creative.

We filmed this video in Harinera Nacional, and abandoned flour factory in the north of Mexico City. This place has an interesting history, it exploded about 15 years ago, and now has become a bit of a haven for graffiti artists, and urban exploring.

Some important things to keep in mind when light painting:
- You need a tripod to stabilize the camera
- The camera cannot move.
- You'll probably need to manual focus due to the darkness
- Use light like a paintbrush. Paint the areas you want to show. 
- Use a long shutter speed (we did 30s)
- Have fun. It usually takes a couple tries.

Make sure to check out my friends Raul & Ale (links below) Both YouTubers here in CDMX.
They also made vlogs here. We had an interesting end of the night.

title: Am I Cursed? RIP WALLET üíÄ(PART 2) Mexico City Witchcraft 2018
description:
It's unbelievable. Not even 24h after my iPhone X was stolen in an Uber, my wallet disappears. After visiting the Mexico City Witchcraft market (Mercado Sonora) last week, I have been asked many times.. Have I been cursed? Did the witch that did the Limpia, the spiritual cleaning... actually do the opposite?

I had to go back and watch the footage again. I didn't understand everything the witch was saying the first time. When we wanted to film, she insisted no. We kept pushing and she eventually said that she would do a fake limpia spell but "It will not do him good" We clarified that it didn't necessarily mean it was going to do me bad... it just mean't it wouldn't do anything. She responded again "It won't do him good"

She then proceeded to channel her invisible assassins, terrorists, and body guards (her words) to put a cleaning spell on me. We later heard this witch was an imposter, and not who she said she was. So what did you use on me Black Magic, or White Magic?

I honestly don't believe too much in these things, but I have to wonder why so many problems happened right after? Coincidence? It's just so strange.

We are hoping to find a mystery man to fix this problem, and clean my bad luck. Stay tuned for part 3.

title: MINDANAO Travel Vlog | A Sacrifice to the Spirits üò• | Talaandig Tribe
description:
This Mindanao road trip has been amazing. In this Philippines travel vlog, myself and the rest of the fighter boys end up in Bukidnon after having visited Davao City.

We meet the Talaandig. A tribe in north central Mindano known for their soil paintings, music, dance, and their history as the peace keepers of the island.

The Talaandig have a very elaborate initiation ceremonies in which all new visitors must participate. Tabacco and Betelnut is chewed, prayers are said, and a chicken is sacrificed. This is to please their ancestor's spirits before guests enter and potentially "eat their food, and walk on their heads". Datu, the tribe leader guided us through this ceremony when we first arrived.

As a foreigner in the Philippines, this was an amazing experience for me. The best moments are the ones that challenge you, and this adventure was full of music, food, and pushing my boundaries. I couldn't help keep this travel vlog under 20 minutes. Too much Filipino love and good vibes. I hope you enjoy!

title: Removing the CURSE üíÄ(PART 3) | Coyoacan Mexico City Limpia & Tarot Reading
description:
We found him. After visiting the Mercado Sonora Witchcraft Market in Mexico City for a Limpia, or spiritual cleaning... a string of bad luck had every asking me... Am I cursed?

We decided to ask our friends in Mexico City if they knew anyone that could dive a bit deeper into why I was having such bad luck. Ever the skeptic about these things, I was hesitant to pursue another witch, or to push too far into the realm of White and Black Magic.

We were directed to a man named Don Carlos. Who was a master of the Tarot, and was apparently quite gifted. He only appeared in the evenings on a particular bench in Coyoacan, an ancient part of Mexico City. 

We didn't have much to go by. We just knew the location of the bench, we had no idea what he looked like. 

Later that evening, he showed himself, and we were able to speak with him... this is the video of that experience. Trying to see if this mysterious man could heal this supposed curse.

I teamed up with Mariannela Catano and Exploring with Cody to tackle this one

title: FINAL THOUGHTS of BASILAN | Mindanao Philippines Travel Vlog
description:
In this last episode of Discovering Basilian, I'm with Kulas of Becoming Filipino and we finish off in Cotabato City Mindanao Philippines!
In this filipino travel vlog, we start the day visiting the Grand Mosque. 
Unbelievably enough, I had never set foot in a Mosque before this. All my years of travel have taken me to the depths of jungles, the tops of mountains, the bottom of the ocean, but for some reason never into a mosque. After, we visit a crab farm for breakfast. Here we try pastel, and start cracking shells. My reputation precedes me, and they prepare a special surprise for me.

A bit more backstory on Basilan, and this series.
This small island has had a lot of trouble in the past. Muslim extremist groups have damaged its people and its reputation. As a foreigner in the Philippines, everyone told me to stay away from the south. Mindanao was "dangerous" and "no one should go", is what I was told by both filipinos and foreign travelers. After the Mindanao roadtrip with the Fighterboys, I would have to disagree. Love and generosity is what we experienced, an appreciation from the people that I have rarely felt while travelling the world. We met the governor of ARMM, our local contact (always have a local contact) and spent 4 days here. While I wouldn't recommend travelling here on your first day in the Philippines, 

This is Day 4 of exploring Basilan Mindanao Philippines.

#FearlessandFar #Basilan #Mindanao

title: BURNING OF JUDAS FESTIVAL | TULTEPEC, MEXICO | QUEMA DE JUDAS 2018
description:
Tultepec is famous for it's fireworks. After the 2017 fireworks explosions, the festivals have not stopped in this tiny mexican town in Estado de Mexico.

Known as the national fireworks capital of the country, Tultepec has many celebrations year round involving explosions.

The most famous would be the national pyrotechnics festival that I attended in March 2018. It's a 10 day event with fireworks towers (called castillos), piromusicales (fireworks to music), as well as the burning bulls, (toros de fuego) where locals cover paper mache bulls with explosives.

The latter is a bit like the quema de judas in Tultepec. Instead of bulls, figures are covered in fireworks, and hung from a rope. These spin, eventually catch fire, and explode violently. Originally from Spain, this tradition was done during easter to burn an effigy resembling Judas, the man who betrayed Jesus. Now Mexico has taken it's on interpretation and began to burn Alebrijes, beautiful fantasy creatures from Oaxaca, as well as not so traditional effigies... Like Goku and Spongebob Squarepants. 

I hope you enjoy this Mexico travel vlog with my friend Exploring with Cody, Mariannela, and Dave on Arrival experiencing La Quema de Judas Tultepec 2018!

title: The World's Most BIZARRE Building? | Ashgabat Turkmenistan vlog
description:
Welcome to Ashgabat, capital of one of the strangest countries I've been to. This is the second travel vlog in our Turkmenistan series!

While travelling through Ashgabat, things seem strange. Everything is vibrantly white and gold, and there is no one around... If you're looking for the strangest and most bizarre places to visit in 2020, Turkmenistan might be it.

The presidents of this country have taken a liking to collecting Guinness World Records. Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov, Turkmenistan's Dictator/President and the former (now deceased) president Turkmenbashi have decorated the capital of this closed republic with white marble, and buildings built to break records.

Highest density of white marble clad buildings, largest architectural star, and this... the largest indoor Ferris Wheel, and many many more.

We were able to take a few hours to experience this giant space compass for ourselves, and even take if for a ride. 

We visited in early 2019, but it's worth putting on your radar for 2020. The new president Gurbanguly has opened up the country much more than it used to be. Getting the VISA wasn't a walk in the park, but our friends at Lupine Travel set everything up for us.. Check out their trips to some of the lesser travelled countries!

https://lupinetravel.co.uk/central-asia-five-stans-holidays-and-tours/

Some more links to check out:

title: THE PIT CENOTE: DEEP CAVE SCUBA DIVING IN TULUM
description:
This is a cool scuba dive. The Pit Cenote, or El Pit is one of the many amazing things to see near Tulum. The Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico is like a giant ant colony of Cenotes, underground rivers, and sink holes. It's a diving and snorkeling playground, and you could spend weeks here just seeing the sights underwater. While there are hundreds of cenotes scattered across Yucatan and Quintana Roo, this particular hole cuts deeper into the ground than most. It's called The Pit for a reason, and for myself, it was my very first Cavern Dive.

I arrived here with the expectation of getting my Cave Diving certification, it turns out there is a type of diving called Cavern Diving. This means you never leave the guide line, and you always are able to see ambient light. This was enough for me, as on several of these dives we were well underground, with only a faint glow in the distance of sunlight. You have to be an advanced scuba diver to be allowed to participate in this type of dive. I highly recommend you get certified that high!

title: Soviet Artillery on NORTH KOREAN Border - Trans-Siberian Railway
description:
We found an abandoned artillery on border between North Korea and Russia. While exploring the outside, a local man came over with a rusty key into the only door. We took urban exploration to a whole new level that day.

This area of Primorsky Krai was of extreme military importance to Soviet Russia. While, North Korea is just a handful of kilometres away, It's also the front line to China and Japan.
This canon battery was built in the early 1900s to fortify the area from a foreign navy. Apparently the explosion from a fired round was so powerful, it would knock vehicles down the cliffs if they were parked too close to the artillery. Wow.

This is the final episode of our Trans-Siberian Railway adventure, and what a wild experience it was. 

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok. 

A big thank you to the sponsors of the #TransSibChallenge

title: STOLEN iPhone X (In the STUPIDEST way) Mexico City 2018
description:
I can't believe I had my iPhone X stolen from the back of an Uber in Mexico City. 

Surprisingly few things of mine have been stolen while travelling. Safety and street sense is something I always pride myself on, but in this case, I wasn't ready for this scenario. 

I was finishing up playing some old school games with a friend at a place called Taco Game, and took an uber back with a cool driver through a sketchy part of town. 

We were talking about minimum wage in Mexico, and how people work very hard and receive very little money. As we were driving through Calle Nuevo Leon in Condesa Neighbourhood, we say many prostitutes on the side of the road, and the conversation drifted towards whether that is a lurative job than say, working in a restaurant or a little corner store. We stopped to ask, that was a mistake.

To be honest, I was quite impressed with the system apple has set up to deal with lost or stolen iphones. We immediately tried Find my iPhone on the Uber driver's phone, but she had turned it off. When I returned to my apartment I could put the iPhone 10 on "Lost Mode" where we could program a phone number and a custom message to appear on the lock screen. Also, I was given the option to Erase it completely, making it unusable to anybody without my unique apple ID in the future. Wiping it however, removes the tracking feature from the phone.

All this only can happen if they iPhone if turned on and connected to the internet again. A new user would need to connect to the internet to be able to use it.

As of 48 hours later. The phone has still not been turned on. If there is a need to make a part 2. I will do that and make a video about the tracked iPhone, and potentially confront the iphone thief / thieves

title: Blowing Hallucinogens with the Yanomami Tribe in Venezuela üáªüá™
MONARCH BUTTERFLY SANCTUARY EL ROSARIO AND SIERRA CHINCUA
description:
Millions and millions of Monarch butterflies. It was one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. We're living in Mexico City, and I had heard a lot about the annual migration of these insects from Canada and USA to the Mexican state of Michoacan. We thought we'd make a video showing you how to go, and also highlight 2 different sanctuaries.

I had thought there was a single viewing zone in the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve, but it turns out there are many sanctuaries. We visited these two: Santuario Sierra Chincua, and Santuario El Rosario. They are suppose to have the most butterflies, and are both near the town on Angangueo in Michoacan. A two day trip seemed like fun, and we headed to the beautiful Pueblo Magico Angangueo

It was incredible. I had never seen so many in my life. The whole story is quite remarkable actually. Normally a Monarch butterfly only lives 4 weeks, however the Migration takes 6-8 months. How does that work?
The generation that has to migrate lives 8 times longer than the others. They fly over 4500 km south to the same place in Mexico. No one knows how they do this, it's one of natures great secrets.

Once in Michoac√°n, they breed and clump themselves on a special kind of pine called the Oyamel. It's not as warm as you think here, the elevation is quite high (3500m) and it can get down to almost 0C at night. After a while they travel to Texas to lay their eggs. The food the caterpillars eat is called Milk Weed, and it doesn't exist in Mexico. 
As Northern North America warms up, they return for the summer. The whole process is 4 generations of butterflies. This means no butterflies make the trip back. It's one way.

Enjoy the vlog!

title: ELECTRIC SHOCK CHALLENGE (TOQUES ELECTRICOS) IN MEXICO W/ EXPLORING WITH JOSH & CODY
description:
Exploring Round 2 with:

Exploring with Josh: https://www.youtube.com/user/theartofrealitycrew

Exploring with Cody:
https://www.youtube.com/user/SirCodyBuffinton

La Catapixia:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0ObSthjbDAFOuLV-JjZIXw

My friends are back for a second trip around Mexico City checking out Abandoned Places. Mexico is full of haunted, creepy, and forgotten buildings, happy to have them back for some urbex! 

On our first night we went to Plaza Garibaldi, one of the most famous places in CDMX to see Mariachis. All through this area you can see hundreds of men dressed up in fancy clothing, serenading groups with traditional music. It's great place to eat, dance, and drink. It's full of locals, and it's very popular. I had a special challenge here for them. It was a surprise. I wasn't sure if everyone would think it was fun, but I know it was going to be a good travel vlog so... It would be worth it.

In Plaza Garibaldi there is a drinking game called Los Toques Electricos. When you arrive there, you have to listen. You can hear a man walking around with two metal handles, clinking them together. 
This man has a box around his neck with cigars, gum, and a device that can deliver a 100V current to anyone brave enough to try. This is Los Toques. You hold the metal handles and he turns the dial to 10V, the skull ornament glows red, and the game begins. 

He told me tourists typically make it to 50V, but Mexicans often make it to 70V. You can try the game solo, or all hold hands in a circle, the shock delivered is the same. The point is to one-up your friends, and set the high score. 

Was it painful? Actually, I wouldn't describe it as pain. The feeling was similar to when your arm or leg falls asleep in the beginning, an aggressive tingle. One it hits about 40, it feels like you arms are two cans of compressed air, and are about to burst open. You cannot let go at this point, all your muscles in your arms are contracting as hard as they can. You are at the mercy of the operator.

I would do this again. It was an amazing amount of fun. Just another unbelievable thing to film in country so full of unbelievable things. Excited to share more.

title: ABANDONED WATER PARK IN MEXICO CITY (ATLANTIS) w/ EXPLORING WITH JOSH & CODY
description:
This abandoned water park in Mexico City is one of the most requested locations I visit here in Mexico. I teamed up with my urbex friends Exploring with Josh and Exploring with Cody, and we headed to Bosque Chapultepec, a park (more like a forest) in the heart of CDMX to vlog the adventure together. This abandoned theme park has a dark history, and we wanted to learn more about it.

It doesn‚Äôt look like it, but Atlantis was recently closed. It‚Äôs been less than 10 years since it shut it‚Äôs doors, yet it looks like a war zone. Being in the middle of such a big city, there have been lots of people come to do graffiti and explore, how it became so thrashed, I have no idea. It looks like it was half demolished. It was good to see the waterslides where still there, as well as some resemblance of what the wave pool used to be like, I had heard you could find tickets, but I didn't come across any. Too much garbage on the ground.

A couple years ago news stories started circulating about seals and dolphins being kept in bad conditions inside the forgotten park. Helicopter footage (shown in the beginning of the video) shows green water, and live animals still living inside after the doors had closed. This rumour still circulates though Mexico City, and this was one of the prime reasons we wanted to explore. Would we still find animals there? Are the rumours true? It was scary to think that they might be.

title: Inside a Abandoned LUXURY JUNGLE RESORT in BALI
description:
Just beside one of the main highways heading north in Bali Indonesia, there is a beautiful abandoned resort now laying almost forgotten. The locals call it Penampakan Hotel Megah Berhantu
 which translates into The Ghost Palace Hotel.

My friends Exploring with Josh and Cody Buffinton paid this creepy building a visit last year, and I thought I would do the same. I would rank this as one of the top things to see on the island, it really is one of the coolest and most beautiful things to see.

The most common ghost story, the ones all told by the locals, is that on opening night, all of the guests and staff disappeared, and the building was left abandoned because the spirits of these people come back at night. Another is that many of the people involved in the construction were worked to death, and the ghosts play tricks on anyone who goes inside. A third story, is that the owner was the youngest son of a former Indonesian President, and when the building was opened to the public, he was accused and put on trial for corruption. He then sentenced the death of the judge, was caught, and spent the rest of his life in jail. It‚Äôs original name was PI Bedugul Taman Rekreasi Hotel and Resort, though that is mostly forgotten now‚Ä¶ the rumours and legends have taken over, and it‚Äôs the now the Ghost Palace, one of the most haunted places in Indonesia

No matter the story, this urbex adventure was wild. Myself, Jackson, and Cody made a travel blog about it. Check out their Instagram accounts, both take amazing shots!

We also had a snake encounter in the dark always of the basement. He wasn‚Äôt big, but he was angry and was attacking everything in sight. Play safe with snakes! I had one as a pet for 10 years so I‚Äôm comfortable around them, but they can be unpredictable. Don‚Äôt go close unless you are absolutely sure you are safe. Don't be a victim of a snake attack. 

There, now I feel better.

title: R.I.P. KICK THE GRIND (I NEED YOUR HELP)
description:
New community is here: https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

Big News! It's time to break open a new chapter. Kick the Grind is the past, Fearless and Far is the future. 

Here's why.
 
My story was never one of kicking the grind. I didn't have a dramatic "I Quit" moment, and then left the 9 to 5, I didn't make content about helping people how to do this either. My content was always about the strange places and events in our world. It was about challenging myself (and all of you) with the wilder experiences our planet has to offer. It was about fighting fears and becoming the best version of yourself. That was my style of travel, that idea is what we built our community around.

After 7 years it feels like a fresh beginning. Mike Corey of Kick the Grind, is now Fearlessandfar. I thought i would make a travel vlog in my own style to let you know.

title: Finally FREE from the Curse? üíÄ(PART 4) | Mexico City Witchcraft 2018
description:
After visiting the Mexico City Witchcraft market, receiving a string of horrible luck, dealing with a potential curse, and finding a mysterious man in Coyoacan, we return to receive a magical belt and lotion.

We searched for hours but he was not on his bench, right when we were about to give up, he appeared and gave us his gift.

This is part 4 in a series about dealing with the question "Am I Cursed?" in Mexico City.

This adventure was eye opening, insightful, and an experience I could have never paid a tour guide for. We dove deep into a side of the world that I haven't never explored, and I have to say, it was incredible.

Whether you believe in curses or not, I hope you enjoyed the journey through these 4 videos. This was not staged, rehearsed, or planned. We took this adventure together. I appreciated all of the advice, the concern, and the support. You all made this a powerful experience for me, and I'm happy to have had you all along for the ride.

Experiences over Possessions.

title: Becoming a Russian Walrus in KAZAN | Trans-Siberian Railway
description:
In this episode of our Russia travel vlog series riding the Trans Siberian Railway, we arrive in the Capital of Tartarstan, Kazan!

scuba

On this leg of our great trip across Russia, we stop at The Blue Lake, a freezing pit of freshwater. Here, we learn about the famous Russian Walrus, or –º–æ—Ä–∂. These legendary beasts are brave men (or women) who polar dip in freezing water. While there is no snow this time of year, this lake is fed from ground water deep in the earth, and is a constant 5C.

After unthawing, we explore Kazan, and try traditional Tartarstan cuisine. This includes Chak-Chak, a famous dessert (so famous that there is a museum... we went.)

We end the day at the Kazan Kremlin, a beautiful complex featuring one of the nicest mosques I've ever seen.

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok.

title: EXPLORING ANCIENT HERMITAGE FROM GAME OF THRONES | GAZTELUGATXE, SPAIN
description:
I love having my expectations blown away. I had seen some photos of Gaztelugatxe and couldn't believe something like this could be built. A tiny stone church on the top of an island mountain, with a zigzagging bridge connecting it to the northern coast of Spain. It seemed like a scene from a movie... or maybe season 7 episode 4 of an HBO hit series called Game of Thrones. Yeah, maybe more like that. DRAGONSTONE!

Gaztelugatxe is an islet (small island) on the coast of the Spanish province of Biscay in Basque Country. At it's peak, there is a hermitage called San Juan de Gaztelugatxe which was build to honour John the Baptist. This church is 1000 years old, and with its winding staircase, makes you feel you're approaching a medieval castle. Exploring it was a highlight of my travel life. We arrived to see an amazing sunrise beginning to peek over the coast. We had it to ourselves at this time, and recommend you visit then too.

Mariannela and I made this travel vlog earlier this year during our 1 month road trip through northern Spain. We grabbed a camper van from Indie Campers, and spent the majority of our time in Basque Country,  and all the videos we made are a bit of a different style as the others. We also had a lot of fun with the MAVIC PRO drone from DJI. Some of the best views I've seen yet. This place was unbelievable. 

Also, I came across a lot of great videos of Basque Country through my friends Alex and Marko Ayling from the Vagabrothers. Make sure to check them out as well.

If you're a fan of urbex or exploring abandoned places, this needs to be on your bucket list.

title: VENEZUELA TRAVEL VLOG | E01 | Salto Sapo & Canaima National Park 2019
description:
The Venezuela crisis is is breaking news today in 2019.

With Nicolas Maduro getting almost as attention as Donald Trump, and Juan Guaido being recognized as the new president, people are speaking of protests, upheavals, and even an upcoming coup.

Our hearts go out the the Venezuelan people. Myself and my travel companion Lexie Alford visited this beautiful place late 2018, with the mission to show another side of a country in crisis. We planned to show the beauty of the people, and the natural beauty of the country.

This is not a video about the current econimical or political situation. This is a Venezuela travel vlog of what we experienced as tourists.

We begin our adventure from flying from Miami to Caracas. Arrival at the airport was not filmed, we wanted to keep to ourselves until we could understand the real risks involved. He has expected everything to be much better than the news portrayed, and it seemed true. The next morning we take a small prop plane from Caracas to Canaima National Park, home of Angel Falls. Upon arriving we saw nobody, it was deserted except for a few staff who directed us to the hotel.
That afternoon we booked a tour to a waterfall known as Salto Sapo, known as Frog Falls, and fell in love immedialtely. This was going to be an incredible trip.

title: ABANDONED SKULL SCULPTURE PARK | PARQUE DE LOS DESVELADOS, SPAIN
description:
Parque de los Desvelados or Park of the Sleepless is an abandoned sculpture park South West of Pamplona, Spain. 

Exploring this place has been on my mind for a while, I came across a list of top 5 creepiest locations in the world, and have been hoping to visit ever since. 

This field of skulls was built as a Momento Mori for visitors. It's a reminder that at some point, whether we are rich or poor, famous or forgotten, we all come to the same end. The creator wanted us to wanted the park to think about life, and also death.

Luis Garcia Vidal built these giant skeletons in the Spanish country side for 30 years starting in 1971. There are approximately 7 here, but they are getting increasing had to find due to how they were created. Luis twisted the branched of sumac trees together, then wrapped these in chicken wire and metal screen. Then, he coated these with a thick layer of white chalky lime paint. It's been 10 years since his death, and many more decades since their creation, many are being consumed by the forest, the wire becoming undone, and the twisted sumac taking life again.

Why did he build them this way? Maybe he thought that these sculptures, like life, should eventually return to the earth.

Mariannela and I really loved exploring this place. We were completely alone until the very end (watch the outro, a bit scary). Hope you enjoy the Park of the Sleepless!

title: COTTON CANDY ART Sombrero, Umbrella, Flower | Mexican Candy Street Food 2018
description:
Mexican Street Food is some of the most delicious and interesting around. We found a man in Coyoacan, Mexico City making Cotton Candy Art on a busy weekend. Called arte con algod√≥n de az√∫car in spanish, and he was making figuras for cheap. We asked for a cotton candy flower, a sombrero, and a umbrella, though he had so much more on his list! He was a true cotton candy art pro.

What other kinds of Mexican Candy do you like? Have have you seen any other kinds of candy art? Is finding a giant cotton candy flower common where you live? I think sugar art in China and Japan is common too!

This country has so much more to offer than tacos, burritos, and nachos. Most Mexican food we think of is actually TexMex and not popular here. Mexico has one of the most diverse food cultures in the world, and you have to travel here to see it. The desserts especially!

I hope you enjoyed this street food travel vlog!
Make sure to check out my friends Exploring with Cody and Mariannela!

title: First Tourist to Europe during COVID-19 | 12 BIG Differences
description:
With all the travel restrictions and bans in place, flying during Covid19 is controversial. But when a country opens for tourism, what is right and what is wrong? In this video I travel from Canada to Europe during the 2020 pandemic, and show you some of the main differences along the way. The EU had just opened non-essential travel to select nations around the world, and I took advantage of my Canadian citizenship to be one of the very first tourists to arrive in Europe during the coronavirus pandemic.

Upon landing in the European Union, I was only asked where I was going. There were no questionnaires, no temperature checks, or swabs. I wasn't even expected to self quarantine, or isolate myself upon arrival. (even though I chose to). I was a free man.

I hope this video can be useful to those who are planning to travel during Covid19. Let's Chat in the comments.

To watch the other episodes on Covid-19 Travel, click here:

title: HIERVE EL AGUA | PETRIFIED STONE WATERFALL OF OAXACA MEXICO
description:
Hierve el Agua, AKA the Petrified Waterfall of Oaxaca, Mexico, is a very strange place to visit. Located about a 90 minute drive from Oaxaca City, this natural wonder is one of the top things to see in Mexico.

This adventure kicked off a giant roadtrip with some YouTuber friends of mine. Backpacker Steve, Brendan van Son, Jodie Dewberry, and I jumped in a rental car and drove through Oaxaca to Chiapas in search of waterfalls in Mexico. This particular Mexican Waterfall was very special

This wonder of nature was high on our list. We arrived early on a Monday morning in the offseason (December), and barely saw anybody until midday.

Although appearing similar to a hot spring, the water is actually cold. The bubbling of the water comes from trapped gasses under the ground that bubble up with the mineral rich groundwater. This process is why the location is named The Water Boils in Spanish, even though it not actually boiling.

From a distance, these giant rock formations look like cascading waterfalls frozen in time. In photos, it's actually not apparent that it isn't water. There are several of these giant petrified waterfalls at the location, and walking trails connecting them all together.

title: MEXICAN MUMMY MUSEUM | LAS MOMIAS DE GUANAJUATO
description:
The Museo de Momias de Guanajuato caught me by surprise. I had heard from my Mexican friends that they all visited as kids, so how creepy and shocking could the Mummy Museum be? Very actually... This is one of the most intense and scary things I've seen, and I'm not generally shy to check out haunted, abandoned, or freaky places.

In the 1970‚Äôs, a Mexican wrestler/celebrity called ‚ÄúEl Santo‚Äù fought these Mexican Mummies off with his side kick the Blue Demon making them famous across the country. These are the cut scenes in the beginning and end of the video of this movie. Since, there has been many other spin offs like the animated La Leyenda De Las Momias

Unlike most other mummies, these bodies are naturally mummified. What's the difference? In ancient Egypt the deceased were disembowelled, their skin treated with different solutions, and body positions set into less fightening poses. Here in the Mexican state of Guanajuato, nature did it's thing without any human intervention.  It's actually a pretty simple phenomenon. Unique in Mexico, the dry salty earth in this area acts like a giant desiccator, perserving the bodies before they can properly decompose.
Really, it's not too far off the process of making Beef Jerky; add salt, remove the moisture quickly, and the meat doesn't rot. Morbid, but the science is the same.

If you're part of the crew that loves horror, the paranormal, or ghost stories, this one's for you... except this is real life... and there are hundreds of these scattered across the state in 2 different museums. We happened to visit the one in Celaya because of it's proximity to the exploding hammer festival. If you haven't seen that video yet.... wow, make sure to check it out. It's linked at the end.

I'd thought I'd throw this scary movie together to see what you think. Creepy or cool? Would you go?

title: EXPLORING AN ABANDONED THEATRE IN MEXICO CITY | CINE OPERA
description:
Cine Opera was one of the most beautiful theatres in Mexico City. Now it's falling to pieces, and is one the most difficult abandoned buildings to enter in CDMX. It has been on my top 5 list for a long time, and it finally were able to vlog it and go exploring.

It was opened in 1949 as a movie theatre to show films from around the world to the rich, and for 40 years it did that. In 1985 a giant earthquake rocked the city, destroying hundreds of buildings, and cracking the main screen of the theatre. After, it was a music venue for concerts for 15 years before an "Altercation" on stage with the English Gothic Rock band Bauhaus closed it permanently. There is no more information I can find about what happened. How can a band close a place this beautiful permanently?

This place has 24 hour security, steel bar fences, and locks on all the doors.... I never thought I'd get in.

I had met some friends, La Catapixia who also do urban exploration in Mexico City. We had seen each others videos of other cool locations like the abandoned condominium, Insurgentes 300, and Acropolis the abandoned shopping mall. They got us into to the abandoned cinema, and we went exploring together.

We were surprised to see that they have cleaned the interior quite a bit. The movie theatre seats were all cleared out, as well as most of the trash. There are plans to renovate it into a cultural centre, and I hope they do. Abandoned or not, it's still a beautiful place.

title: EPIC GOPRO MONTAGE OF DANGEROUS FESTIVAL | EXPLODING HAMMERS
description:
I thought I'd make an epic GoPro Montage of some of the best POV shots I recorded during the exploding hammer festival in Guanajuato, Mexico. 

I was told that BBC had tried to use an action camera a couple years ago and it didn't survive the blasts, and that I would be insane to try it too. I thought my old HERO 3 would make it through the explosions if I positioned it right on the hammer, and hey, if it didn't... wouldn't that be an epic way to say goodbye, and I'd go out and buy the new Hero 5 Black, and get that delicious 4k. The Hero 3 plus lived, and I was stoaked with the results

This is one of the world's most dangerous festivals. The exploding hammer festival, or "fiesta del martillo explosivo" in spanish, is an annual festival in San Juan de la Vega, Guanajuato, Mexico. Every February 28th, thousands of people visit this small little down to see locals tape home made explosives to sledgehammers, and slam then into the ground. The explosions are huge, and injuries are very common. It's a strange festival, and one of the most dangerous in the world

This particular date, is day to celebrate San Juan Bautista, aka John the Baptist, which the town was named after. No one can remember exactly how all the exploding started... but at one point it took place inside the city. Those who participated would follow the parade in the honour of the saint, blasting the hammers to celebrate. After a lot of damage to windows, people, and cars, they moved the hammers out into a field. Here, hundreds of men can detonate their explosives slightly more safely.

We spent a lot of our time in the beautiful city of Celaya, which is nearby the festival. Highly recommend you check it out. The tourism board there went to great lengths to help us get the best video possible of the event!

These are the best GoPro shots from the festival. The full video, and full story is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vB9IdhcFAvY

title: BOTFLY EXTRACTION TRAVEL VLOG | Is it a zit, cyst, or blackhead? Worse...
description:
For those of you who love pimple popping, blackheads, whiteheads and acne on YouTube... this botfly extraction vlog is for you üòÇ 

While travelling in Central America, a little pimple popped up on my wrist. I honestly didn't think anything of it, and continued my travels to Bangkok Thailand. 5 weeks later, and after many attempts at popping it myself, I thought I would head to the hospital to see a dermatologist and see if it really was a blackhead, cyst, zit, pimple, or what. 

It wasn't. Any of those. It was a botfly larvae. Fun!

This parasitic fly lays a small egg on a little cut on your skin. If you travel in the jungle, you know that you are always covered in cuts. This then hatches very shortly after, and a little maggot burrows in your skin. 2 to 3 months later, you birth a fully grown botfly out of the wound, who going on to repeat the process in someone else. No amount of preventative skin care can save you. 

Would you have trusted my master extractor Lexie to cut me open in a hotel room? This is a true travel vlog not for the squeamish! Who here likes Dr. Pimple Popper?

Check out my BTS content here... if you can handle it! https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: RAINBOW MOUNTAINS HIKE IN CUSCO PERU
description:
The Rainbow mountains or Montania de Siete Colores in Peru " are a few hours drive outside of Cusco, and it has a bit of a wild story. 

As far as travel attractions go, it's brand new. You might ask "how can a mountain be brand new?" Well, it was covered with snow all year round until 2015. The climate has warmed enough to uncover the beautiful Rainbow underneath. There are several mountains there with these colours, and they say it matches the Cusco flag, which is also a rainbow. 

It's hard to miss it when you walk through the town. It seems like every second tour shop offering hiking, has a Rainbow Mountain trek poster on the outside of the shop offering 1 day tours, 3 day tours, and everything in between.

We found a freelance guide through a friend. His name was Santos and we locked in a one day trip. That meant a 3am wake up, and a 3 hour drive to the trail head.

It's quite a hike to the top. It took us about 4 hours to reach the summit and we froze our asses off up there. It's well over 5000m above sea level, which is about double Machu Picchu and Cusco. I had never been at that altitude and you really feel it when you try to walk and talk.

Hey, it was all worth it though. It was a unbelievable thing to see, even if I have some mixed feelings about the whole climate change issue. It's not the Peruvians causing problems.

title: Inside Japan's HORROR CAFE in Shinjuku (Better than Robot Cafe)
description:
The Shinjuku district of Tokyo in Japan is a highlight of any trip to the city. It's home to the Robot Cafe or robot restaurant, one of the top things to do in Tokyo... but just around the corner is a darker attraction. A Horror Cafe called "The Lock Up"

This isn't even the weirdest cafe in the city. There is a Maid Cafe, An Owl Cafe, a Ninja Cafe... and the list goes on. Tokyo cafes have become a bit of a trend, and if you're looking for things to do in Tokyo, book yourself into any of the above experiences.

The horror cafe experience starts with a normal elevator ride to the 3rd floor. You want in, and then things gets weird (not a strange occurrence in Japan). It all took a surprise turn in the end right as we were about to leave, we almost missed the whole point of the experience. They don't tell you want to expect when you enter inside. Big love to my Tokyo vlog homies Josh and Fighters! Check their channels below.

description:
Of all the lost places in Germany, Bagger 258 aka the "Blue Wonder" is unique. It's a mechanical monstrosity, an evil looking machine, used to harvest Brown Coal during the Cold War. Abandoned places explored is an ongoing theme here on Fearless & Far, and I hope you enjoy this special urbex episode today.

This industrial monstrosity known as Bagger 258 is a colossal mining machine built in the DDR - but now left for dead in a German field.

MAKING MY GIRLFRIEND EAT THE HOTTEST BURGER IN THE WORLD
description:
I made my girlfriend cry today, I wasn't proud of it, but it was hilarious.

We just 50k Subscribers and thought a great way to celebrate would be an extreme eating challenge! Just up the street from us in Mexico City, there is the hottest burger in the world at a place called the Burger Bar Joint. They serve a hamburger that is a tower of habanero and serrano peppers.

I am a veteran of spicy food, and was a little bit scared to take on this hot pepper challenge. You have 3 minutes to consume a 2 patty burger, with fries and a litre of beer. It turned out to be more of a speed eating contest

My girlfriend is a champ. She's Mexican, and eats a decent amount of chili too, however her Canadian boyfriend has a bit of a higher tolerance. 

This wasn't exactly boyfriend vs. girlfriend, or a prank (she accepted to do it, but I did have to lay on the peer pressure thick.)

Can she eat a tower of beef and habaneros, then finish it off with a litre of beer and fries in 3 minutes? 

Let's find out¬†üòà

description:
It's true! I'm one of 5 presenters on The Travel Show on BBC. We explore the planet and aim to give a unique insight into the world of travel. If you're a subscriber to my channel, you may already be familiar with that!

It aires every week on BBC World News, BBC News, and BBC Two
This new opportunity is a perfect fit for my YouTube channel. I'll be sent places, and The Travel Show team will meet me places, and we'll create content together. It's flexible, it's fun, and I always have the option to extend my stay and continue to make travel content for my travel channel here on YouTube.

Being a TV Host has always been a goal of mine, and the BBC has been at the top of my list as a broadcaster I would love to work with.

We're just starting on the BBC Travel Show together, though the show has been running since 2014. The show is split into several segments, and these are split among several presenters. We're filmed in Mexico, Philippines, and a will be travelling together much more this year.

Thank you all for the love! Don't worry though, lots of videos still to come, and if anything, this new opportunity will help us get places we wouldn't have been able to otherwise. There will still be videos every week, I'm not going anywhere!

title: Camping Alone in an Abandoned Monastery üíÄ
EATING PINECONE PANCAKES IN RUSSIA | Trans-Siberian Railway
description:
In this chapter of our Russian adventure along the Trans-Siberian Railway, we stop in Novosibirsk and Krasnoyarsk and try some unique Russian food!

We're finally in Siberia after about a week on the train. Our first adventure is hiking The Columns. These beautiful magma pillars were formed when lava spurted up from an ancient seabed and cooled as they came in contact with the water. The seabed washed away, turned into a forest, and voila. The perfect place for a Russian travel vlog.

We also found a Siberian specialty food in Krasnoyarsk. Pinecones. Being Canadian, I didn't know you could eat these things. We have snack on a few on top of pancakes during this journey as well. 

A bit of a background story. This is a train journey of 10,000 km across Russia, the biggest country in the world. 25 days to visit Saint Petersburg, Moscow, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, Krasnoyarsk, Ulan-Ude, and Vladivostok. 

A big thank you to the sponsors of the #TransSibChallenge

title: (WE GOT CAUGHT) EXPLORING AN ABANDONED MALL IN MEXICO
description:
Mexico City is full of abandoned places. I keep on finding cooler and creepier buildings to explore. It's urbex heaven here. This time I was told about an abandoned shopping mall called "The Acropolis" in Lomas Verdes, an area in the the western part of CDMX.

It was a beautiful and creepy adventure. The shopping mall had been abandoned for 20 years, and was beginning to fall into ruins. 
There are a few place that make this shopping centre different than most malls. First, it was a Middle-Eastern Bazaar style market. There were thousands of shops inside, each one only taking up a few square meters. Second, in the middle of the entire building, the roof opened up into a giant star. At noon it would cast a giant shape in the very middle of the mall. It's an incredible thing to see.

They modelled the building off the Acropolis in Athens, Greece. Giant carved stone pillars, the triangular archways, and the fact it was perched overlooking the rest of the surrounding city. 

There are a few rumours as to why they abandoned the building. Some conspiracy theories say it was built as a giant money laundering scheme, others suggest that it's strange style didn't catch on. Also, around the same time, a larger mall opened up nearby called Centro Comercial Satelite. This probably didn't help either.

I jumped on this urban exploration with some friends in Mexico City. It was barely boarded up, which made exploring easy. We arrived early in the morning, and didn't see anyone until much later when we were caught by the police. Which... turned out to be not as bad as I thought... We were lucky.

Also, to you guys who kick seriously ass and read this far. 
I put one frame of the new KtG logo in the video. Message in the comments what second you saw it and I'll send you a surprise.

title: COZUMEL SCUBA DIVING - PALANCAR CORAL REEF
description:
Mexico is a beautiful place to Scuba Dive, and Cozumel is one of the top scuba diving and snorkeling destinations in the Riviera Maya the Caribbean. It's unique for its drift diving, marine life, and beautiful dive sites. There are a few in particular, called Palancar Bricks, Palancar Gardens, and Palancar Caves. These sites are all part of Palancar coral reef, and are like swimming through a cathedral. Towers and caves of coral rise over you, and run beneath you. 

Cozumel is a special island. During the day the big cruise ships, especially Carnival Cruises, unload thousands of people looking for Cozumel excursions. Most go shopping, but the smart few find a local dive shop and get on a boat. If you travel all this way and don't see underwater, you're missing the biggest draw to the island. 

I ended up doing a lot of dives here over the past couple years. When editing this video, it was hard for me to cut it into a few minutes for youtube. I settled on just cutting together the dive of Palancar Gardens. That's the dive site if you're curious!

Shout out to all my divers out there. Message me below if you wish you were in the water right now!

title: ABANDONED STRIP CLUB | EXPLORING PLAYA DEL CARMEN MEXICO | URBAN DECAY
description:
Every time I saw this place on the side of the highway between Playa del Carmen and Tulum, I always thought it was a resort. I had put it on my list of places to go exploring in the future. When we finally had a free day to check it out, I was shocked. No fences, no guards, no tape. It was an abandoned Gentlemen's Club... aka a strip club... right beside the busiest highway in Quintana Roo, Mexico. It had Urban Exploration written all over it.

I always try to do my research before we do an adventure. The history is half the fun of the place. Every abandoned building has a story, and  love sharing it. However, there was nothing about this place online. I would guess it's over 30 years old, before the days of facebook pages and yelp reviews. It's condition is pretty great actually. Normally when you go urban exploring there is a ton of graffiti on these places. Not the case here. Hareem Gentlemen's Club by Playa del Carmen, Mexico does not exist on the web.

Because of it's proximity to big nightlife hubs like Cancun, Playa del Carmen and Tulum, I had a suspicion there could have bee people living inside. Hunch confirmed.... but why the roof??

title: DOS OJOS CENOTE SCUBA DIVING IN TULUM MEXICO
description:
Dos Ojos Cenote is a magical place for scuba diving just outside of Tulum. It's one of the many Cenotes in the Yucatan Peninsula, and has a reputation for beautiful diving and snorkeling. Mexico is an incredible country and the entire Riviera Maya has so many unique and amazing dive sites. If you're not certified you're missing out. Half of the appeal of this part of the world is Underwater!

Tulum is not too far from Cancun or Playa del Carmen, you can take a collectivo (a local taxi van) for very cheap to travel along the coast. Once you're there, you can see a lot around the town, and there are several cenotes to visit. Taxi's aren't too bad once your there, and there are a lot of dive shops that will take you to the cenotes. I went with Infinity2diving, their info is a little bit lower on the list!

I arrived here with the expectation of getting my Cave Diving certification, it turns out there is a type of diving called Cavern Diving. This means you never leave the guide line, and you always are able to see ambient light. This was enough for me, as on several of these dives we were well underground, with only a faint glow in the distance of sunlight. You have to be an advanced scuba diver to be allowed to participate in this type of dive. I highly recommend you get certified that high!

title: ALCOHOLIC Ice Cream with KINETIC KENNONS | Helado Obscuro Mexico City
description:
Yes alcoholic ice cream exists. I didn't know this strange dessert existed until I was looking for Mexico City street food, and stumbled across this crazy ice cream shop in Colonia Roma Norte, CMDX. I invited my YouTuber friends, the gringos in Mexico themselves, the Kinetic Kennons, to join me at Helado Obscuro (Dark Ice Cream) to try a few of their wild flavours at 10am on a Friday!

One thing I love about this country is the amount of amazing things to see and things to eat. Every corner has something unique if you are an adventurous eater. As far as food capitals of the world goes, Mexico City has to be top 10.

Big love to Romy, the owner of Helado Obscuro for hooking us up with a tasting a little tour! 

What do you think? Cool or Crazy? Which flavour looked best? Let us know in the comments.

title: Top 5 Best HIDDEN Secrets of Bali, Indonesia (What to see in Bali 2019)
description:
This Top 5 list of things to do in Bali, isn't your normal list of tourist attractions. These are for hardcore travellers, ones that aren't afraid to dive deep into the cracks, and see things that I guarentee aren't in any other bali vlog in 2019.

As tourists flock to Kelingking beach, Nusa Penida, the Bali swing, and Canggu, there is a whole other side to this magical island in Indonesia. One that would satisfy even the wildest adventurer, and treads the line of Dark Tourism.

HERE'S THE GEOTAGGED LIST ON TROVER:
https://www.trover.com/l/6nRP2-bali%e2%80%99s-secrets

The app is free, and it's great to find hidden gems near your location. Check it out and give me a follow ;)

1. The Sunken Temple Garden (Devata Vishnu)
Rumoured to be thousands of years old (it's not) these beautiful dive site is an artificial reef made to resemble a Hindu temple. It's located in the far west of Bali. I recommend visiting with Reef Seen Divers, the creators of the attraction.

2.The Ghost Palace Hotel (Bedugul Taman Rekreasi Hotel)
An enourmous abandoned hotel right by the highway in the central part of Bali. For a sneaky dollar you can get in and explore this incredible place yourself. The view and intricately caved Naga statues make this place a wild adventure.

3. USAT Liberty Shipwreck (Tulamben, Bali)
Torpedoed by the Japanese, and sunk by a volcano in North Eastern Bali, this shipwreck is laying in shallow water. Very few places to you find ships this size, this close to shore. Even snorkelers can enjoy this massive steel cathedral. I've never seen anything like it.

4. Goa Gajah (The Elephant Temple)
Just a short distance from Ubud, Bali, this strange temple doesn't get many visitors. Its giant gaping mouth doorway is the main attraction. The photos are amazing.

5. Trunyan Cemetery (Kuburan Terunyan)
For hundreds of years, the deceased of the nearby town of Trunyan have been laid open face at the base of a sweet smelling tree. Its said both smells cancel each other out. It's one of the most shocking things I've ever seen.

title: INCREDIBLE ABANDONED CATHEDRALS IN BELCHITE | TRAVEL VLOG SPAIN
description:
Exploring the ruined town of Belchite in Spain was one of the best memories I have of our travels through the country. Two towering abandoned cathedrals scarred with the bullet holes of a war long past. We arrived not knowing what to expect, but my mind was blown. It was an absolutely incredible adventure.

Belchite means beautiful city, and it was one of the many casualties of the Spanish Civil war in 1937. This city was one of the very first to suffer the effects of an air raid, this type of warfare and just begun to see use, and you can see the results in the cathedrals. They are crumbling.

Losing this town was hard for many people. It's beauty was remarkable. However, instead of repairing the city to its former glory, an new Belchite was built beside it, and the ruins continue to lay abandoned as a war memorial. Because of the thousands of lives that were lost here, it is considered one of the most haunted places in Spain, and they say the echos of war can still be heard in the walls. Scary stuff!

It turns out there are guided tours here. We just showed up and went with the flow. You can organize them at the local tourism office in New Belchite

This travel vlog was a lot of fun. The day was perfect for exploration, and the sunset was epic. We hope you enjoy this place. It was quite special!

title: Thing to do in ZIHUANTANEJO Mexico | Alternative Travel Guide 2018
description:
Guerrero Mexico has always been on my list of places to go and things to see. The state is beautiful, and doesn't get too many visitors besides Acapulco. We spent a weekend exploring this area, and here is our list of top things to do in Zihuantanejo. 

The Fish Market
Every morning at 7:30am down by the basketball court on Paseo del Pescador street, the fishermen lay our their catch for local restaurant owners to purchase for the day. It's a pretty busy spot that early in the morning, and makes for a great way to grab some good photos and start your day.

The Christ Statue
Playa las Gatas is one of the most famous beaches in Zihuatanejo. Here, you come relax and take in the setting sun over the Pacific, and enjoy a drink at any of the beach bars that line the coast. Just off the break water there is a hidden underwater statue of Jesus, with arms outstretched just a few meters below the surface. You can rent snorkels, masks, and fins. Swim out to the buoy attached to his arm and get a view of this interesting attraction 

Pozoleria Santa Prisca

Every Thursday this restaurant opens to serve this extremely traditional soup to whoever is brave enough to wait in line. Even if you've tried it before... you have to try it here. This is some of the best Pozole I've had in Mexico. Chili, corn, chicken, it's delicious. You can make reservations to beat the line. We recommend doing it.

El Partenon de Negro Durazo

This abandoned party house was owned by a corrupt police chief who used tax dollars to build it. He picked a beautiful location overlooking Playa la Ropa, contructed a greek style mansion, called it El Partenon, and then went to jail a few years later. It is now in incredible shape after been abandoned for several decades, and worth checking out (by appointment). It really is a special and unique attraction

Mezcalerias
One of my absolute favourite drinks world wide is Mezcal. With thousands of varieties, a very interesting history, and lots of establishments devoted solely to it... You have to spend some time in one of the many mezcalerias in Zihuatanejo, Mexico.

Hope you enjoyed this video of the alternative things to do in Zihuatanejo

title: EXPLORING A BRITISH CEMETERY IN MEXICO (PANTEON INGLES, HIDALGO)
description:
Exploring Mexico is one of my new hobbies. The Panteon Ingles in Real del Monte, Hidalgo is an old British Cemetery... in Mexico. 200 years ago, there was a very famous British Mine nearby, many miners came from their home country to work here, and a special graveyard was built to accommodate them. There are many stories surrounding this place, and symbolism is scattered throughout. It's a great adventure for people who love urbex, or abandoned places.

My friend Lola told me about this location, and I visited with her and another of her friends. We had heard there was a caretaker we could speak to, and we did end up finding her there. Maria del Carmen Hern√°ndez Skewes (which... I had a hard time remembering) is now in charge of the Panteon, but her father was the one who received most of the fame. Don Chencho was made an official citizen of Britain by Queen Elizabeth II for his outstanding work taking care of the Cemetery during the time the mine was active, and now he is buried facing Britain (like all the other miners) in the Graveyard.

If you're wondering what some of the best things to do are around Pachuca, and urban exploration is interesting for you... this place is worth checking out. It's placed high on a hill looking over Real de Monte, with tall cedar and pine trees scattered throughout. It was really quite beautiful, in a slightly creepy way. I imagine it would be absolutely stunning at sunrise or sunset. I'd recommend to visit then, as you probably won't see a ghost ;)

title: EATING INSECTS with The New Travel  | Traditional Mexican food 2018
description:
Eating insects in Mexico? In this video, Dan of the New Travel and I, visit a restaurant called Tlacoyotitlan and try their Huarache Ancestral. A large corn tortilla filled with beans, topped with Chapulines (grasshoppers), Cocopaches (beetles), Gusano de Maguey (big worms), Chiliquiles (little worms), escamoles (ant larvae) and a tasty little scorpion on top.

Mexican street food, especially the typical ones are very delicious. This restaurant is famous for using organic corn straight from the farmers, and you can taste the difference. Their Mexican cuisine is the best food around.

Tlacoyotitlan is a restaurant in colonia Santa Maria la Ribera in CDMX. In the centre of this neighbourhood there is a beautiful Kiosko where locals usually dance in the afternoon. This amazing restaurant in Mexico City is right beside this plaza and has some of the best Garnachas (Mexican street food), and best insect dishes I have had in the city.

Would you give this a taste test? Have you tried bugs before? Let us know what you think!

title: TANJUNG PUTING NATIONAL PARK: ORANGUTANS IN INDONESIA
description:
Tanjung Puting National Park. Perhaps the best place to see Orangutans in the wild. Borneo aka Kalimantan is one of only two islands in the world you can see these animals. They are not actually monkeys like many people believe, they belong to the ape family, and share a lot of their biology with us.

We spent 2 days cruising the rivers of Tanjung Puting National Park to see these animals. Many of them are rescues, taken back from the illegal pet trade. This allows us to see them up close, as they still have to be fed by humans. Indonesia is a paradise for nature geeks. These animals are basically like celebrities, and seeing them like this was an incredible experience. You need to check out Wonderful Indonesia!

title: HIGHS & LOWS & LESSONS | YEAR RECAP 2018 | Fearless and Far
description:
In 2018, I travelled to 11 different countries, got 12 million views and 100k subscribers on YouTube, changed the name of my brand, was hung by hooks, cursed by a witch, ate maggots, and ended a relationship with a long term girlfriend. It was an emotional rollercoaster with highs and lows,, but it was one of the best years of my life. As an adventure travel vlogger, I wouldn't expect it any other way.

Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Bulgaria, Venezuela, Philippines... so many vlogs made and so my stories to tell.

This is the first year end recap I've ever done. I'm ashamed. I always sit down and the end of year and analyze all that's happened, but this is the first time I've set up the camera to talk about it. Let's make it a yearly event.

Thank you all so much for joining me on this ride. Big things happened in 2018, and I'll be taking it up a notch in 2019. 

#FearlessandFar #YearReview #2018

title: KIDS SEE THE OCEAN FOR THE FIRST TIME IN COZUMEL
description:
I teamed up with some friends to take 3 kids to Cozumel to see the ocean for the very first time. Yael, Nohemi, and Gabriel are autistic youth from Mexico City. Neither they, or their mothers who accompanied them had ever been on an airplane, or seen the ocean before. 

The sea has always been at the centre of my life. I spent my childhood exploring it, I went to school to study it, and now I travel to film it. I can't imagine a life without ever seeing the ocean. Watching the kids react was absolutely amazing. They took fascination in how the sand fell out of their hands, how the waves curled into the shore, how salty the water was, and so many other things we just don't pay attention to as we grow up. 

This was a special project for me, and it's part of the #todospodemosviajar (Everyone can travel) project. 

Thanks for watching, and take a peek below at some of the resources!

title: Hunting with the Yanomami Tribe #amazon #tribe
PARTYING with the VENEZUELA AIRFORCE | Canaima Travel Vlog 2019
description:
With all the talk of in the news of a Venezuela crisis, Nicolas Maduro, and a devastated economy in 2019 ... we wanted to show a different side of this beautiful country. 
In this episode we travel back from Angel Falls in Canaima National Park to our basecamp. Along the way we make a quick pit stop to try some Cachiri, a local fermented alcoholic beverage using Casava. Upon arriving at basecamp, we find a surprise.

The Venezuela Airforce was doing a tour of the small communities, at was at our lodge. A concert had been organized, and emotions were running high. Unfortunately we couldn't capture all the magic of this moment on camera, but you could feel the tension. People were sad and frustrated with the situation in Venezuela, and wanted the mess to end. The music provided hope and positivity to the group, and the speeches ended with "This is my Venezuela" the one with music, dance, and laughing. So it continued, and we were invited to join. 

South America knows how to party. Latino culture is one of my favourites, and the Venezuelans do it right. They were teaching us Reggaton, Salsa, Bachata... it was a crazy night, and a highlight for Lexie and I.

Our hearts go out the the Venezuelan people. Myself and my travel companion Lexie Alford visited this beautiful place late 2018, with the mission to show another side of a country in crisis. We planned to show the beauty of the people, and the natural beauty of the country.

This is not a video about the current economical or political situation. This is a Venezeula travel vlog of what we experienced as tourists. 

#FearlessandFar #Venezuela #Angelfalls

Want more videos? Check out my Patreon community here! https://www.patreon.com/fearlessandfar

title: Reading my WORST YouTube Comments #haters #youtube #funny
STINGLESS Jellyfish lake | KAKABAN Berau Borneo TRAVEL VLOG
description:
In this Indonesia Travel Vlog we visit Kakaban. A stingless jellyfish lake in Berau Regency, Derawan, off of the island of Borneo (aka Kalimantan).

This isn't the only stingless jellyfish lake in the world. The most famous being in Palau and Siargao, Philippines. The jellies in all of these lakes are called stingless because there are no natural predators here, and they do not have the need for protection. The reality is though, they do in fact sting, but the stingers on their tentacles (called nematocysts) are too small to pierce the skin of people. If you're a small fish, or other creature... you're lunch.

There are 4 species of Jellies in this lake, and in this Indonesia Travel Vlog, we go exploring to find each of them.

Big love to Wonderful Indonesia for hosting this trip!
This was part of the #TripOfWonders, and annual influencer trip where creators get together and explore Wonderful Indonesia

#FearlessandFar #WonderfulIndonesia

title: LIFE IN SCOTLAND | SCALLOP DIVING WITH GUY GRIEVE | TRAVEL VLOG
description:
Aaaand we're back!
Check out this epic adventure. I teamed up with Visit Scotland, and Wild about Argyll to live a day in the life of a Scot. 

After a plane ride to Glasgow, a camper van to Argyll, a boat to the Isle of Mull, and a long drive to a little white house on a Loch, I met Guy Grieve.

This man is amazing. He spent a year solo in the Alaskan Wilderness, another year sailing around the world, and now dives to the bottom of the North Atlantic Ocean several times a day, hand gathering scallops for his baby, the Ethical Shellfish Company.

My assignment was to join him on a typical day out at sea, SCUBA diving in very cold water, with very strong currents. We would be 

I was tested to the MAX, and left with a serious appreciation and attraction for this style of fishing. Our hands were the fishing equipment, and we did no damage to the ocean because of this. This is such a better way of doing things than the mass harvest of shellfish.

Join us as we jump in the cold north Atlantic in search for treasure!

Learn more about this area of Scotland: http://bit.ly/KtG_Scotland

title: ABANDONED TRAIN STATION IN MEXICO CITY (WITH MARIEL DE VIAJE)
description:
More exploring abandoned places! I teamed up with my friend Mariel de Viaje to visit some of the less known attractions in Chapultepec Park in Mexico City. This forest is huge. One of the biggest city parks in the Western Hemisphere, and has many many secrets.

I had heard about the abandoned train station from before. Officially called "El Tren Panoramico de Chapultepec" it was abandoned in 2006 for unknown reasons. There are stories that there was an accident, there are also stories there was budget issues. Either way, these trains are just sitting there, rusting next to the highway very close to the Museum of Natural History. There is no fence, no signs, anyone can walk down and see them.

That being said, we tried that. 2 guards approached us and said we needed a permit to be there, and that wild dogs would attack us if we came back. So naturally, we rescheduled our visit for sunrise, to visit again. It worked.

The train station was creepy enough, not the most terrifying of all my urban exploration, but I couldn't deny it. What made the experience even more spooky was the pile of chicken heads on a burnt piece of grass, and the chicken organ next to the cross and saint inside.

Why was there here? The guard related it to the dogs, but we didn't see any. Also, none of the heads were chewed. It definitely doesn't explain the organs next to the photo inside either. Strange stuff. We made jokes about a Satanic Ritual, and summoning daemons from the underworld. Who knows though, something about it didn't add up. To me, It definitely looked like a sacrifice.

A big thank you to Mariel's Husband Adrian as well, he helped us a lot these days!

Hope you enjoyed the video. Travel safe!
