title: CROCODILE NIGHT SCUBA DIVING | Crazy things to do in Tulum, Mexico
description:
Scuba diving in Mexico is an endless adventure. In this Tulum travel vlog I join my from Jordan from Drenched, and Sarah from Girls that Scuba, and night dive a cenote in search for crocodiles. Definitely one of the craziest things to do in Tulum, Quintana Roo!

If you are scuba diving in Tulum, Playa del Carmen, Cancun, Isla Mujeres, Cozumel or anywhere else in Rivera Maya, you'll be surprised by the diversity you can find on this coast. The reef diving is quite nice, especially in Cozumel, but in my opinion, the highlight is the many cenotes the dot the Yucatan Peninsula. 

The freshwater sink holes have long been rumoured by the Mayan people to be the gateway to the Underworld. I'm not sure if that's true, but I know they are the gateway to phenomenal diving. KOOX diving offers an interesting tour if you're not faint of heart. Night scuba diving with crocodiles. How's that for wild things to do in Tulum!

The trick is that crocodiles, and other animals that can see at night, have reflective eyes. If you shine a flashlight in the dark, they reflect back some of that light towards you. This allows you to spot them immediately, where as in the day, they would remain heavily camouflaged. Hope you enjoy this travel vlog of scuba diving in Mexico!

#FearlessandFar #Tulum #SCUBA

title: MEXICO: SCUBA DIVING MANCHONES REEF CANCUN
description:
Scuba Diving in Riviera Maya Mexico is beautiful. Cancun, Tulum, Playa del Carmen, all have beautiful opportunities for diving and snorkeling, all quite close to shore. This particular coral reef is right beside MUSA, the Underwater Museum and in between the Cancun and Isla Mujeres. It's called Manchones Reef, and it's quite easy to travel to.

The amount of fish we saw at this place was crazy. There are some sculptures to see down there too. Especially the Cruz de la Bahia, or Cross of the Bay featured in the Thumbnail. We hopped on a ferry from Puerto Juarez in Cancun, and headed over to Isla Mujeres to dive with a dive shop called PocNa. They took us out on a few dive boats to see the best of the area. Scubadiving is one of the best things to do in the Yucatan Peninsula. Cenotes, Coral Reefs, Sharks, it has some of the best underwater experiences in the world

A quick video of my experience visiting Preah Vihear Temple on the border of Cambodia and Thailand in South East Asia. This off the path Angkor temple is not touched by tourism. There has been an ongoing turf war between Thai and Khmer soldiers for ownership, and it currently belongs to Cambodia. I was lucky to be able to visit during a peaceful time.

title: TEUFELSBERG: GRAFFITI IN BERLIN'S DEVIL MOUNTAIN
description:
Teufelsberg in Berlin is an abandoned United States NSA Listening Station just outside the German capital. After World War 2, thousands of tons of rubble had to be moved out of the city. They created a manmade hill, and named it Devil's Mountain. During the Cold War, the USA built a spy base on it's summit to listen to the radio communications of the Soviet occupied East Berlin, and surrounding Eastern Germany. Since the wall fell, it's been left in ruins and has become a haven for Graffiti Artists. At one time, you were able to just go. However now, there are people who tend to the area and fend off trespassers. There are still ways to visit Teufelsberg, make sure to check online first.

If you like graffiti, abandoned places, street art, or James Bond Moon Bases.... then put this on your bucket list. It's one of the most incredible things to do in Berlin, and there really isn't much else like it anywhere in the world. You can get there by taking the Bahn to Grunewald Forest in the West, you can also see the domes when flying to Berlin Airport.
Going to Teufelsberg, or already been? Message below and let's chat. I want to know if you made it in! Enjoy Deutschland!

title: NEPTUNE MEMORIAL REEF | SCUBADIVING IN MIAMI FLORIDA
description:
Scuba diving Neptune Memorial Reef was at the top of my list of things to do when I landed in Miami, Florida. It's an underwater cemetery just off the coast, and a very cool and creepy dive site. If you'd like a burial at sea, you can have your ashes mixed with concrete. Then, you are formed into a small statue and sunk in the Atlantic Ocean to be part of the artificial reef. 

By chance, I was in the area around Halloween, and jumped on a boat to experience one of the most unique dives of my life. Tarpoon Lagoon and Ocean Safari (Both PADI dive centres) were running a night dive on Neptune Memorial Reef to carve pumpkins. Spooky, Epic, Beautiful. It was amazing.

Florida state has some very impressive SCUBA diving, I wish I had more time to explore while I was there. I only had time for this experience, and Manatees further north. Florida is worth the travel time if you're a diver, so much to see!

title: KICK THE GRIND TRAILER 2017 | MIKE COREY ADVENTURE TRAVEL VLOGGER
description:
The content has evolved, the channel has evolved, I have evolved. Here's version 2.0 of my YouTube Channel trailer.

I'm a Canadian Travel Youtuber and Filmmaker, specializing in extreme adventure travel, and capturing things most people haven't seen before. I search the world for those experiences that make us say "Whoa, that actually exists??", and dive heard first into them, full well knowing that many of them will be uncomfortable.

The goal of Kick the Grind is to experience the challenging things in life, and to grow. Kicking the Grind doesn't necessarily mean travel, it's challenging the monotony in your life, realizing the bad routines you go through, and choosing to take a new path. A better path.

Come with me, and let's Kick the Grind!

title: DIVING WANGI IN THE WAKATOBI ISLANDS
description:
The Wakatobi Islands have some of the best Scuba Diving in Indonesia. It was amazing to be back in this place. I did my first big trip here 8 years ago! The name of the island chain comes the first two letters of each of the four islands. Wangi, Kaledupa, Tomia, and Binongko. We dove off the jetty in the island of Wangi, the "Wa" in Wakatobi. 

These islands are in the middle of the Coral Sea, on of the three coral hotspots in the world. (The other two being the Caribbean and the Red Sea) Here, you can see an amazing amount of ocean life. The diversity and density is unmatched around the world. I'd recommend staying with a dive resort or live aboard and spending a few days here. It's incredible.

Would love to go back and spend time diving some more sites!
This was taken on the #TripofWonders. A great project, with some great people!

And guys, don't freedive after you dive. You can get bent. This was shot over two days.

More Underwater Adventures: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi386Ue50lt7tcO9RmkgLEQb

title: Snowboarding FAILS in UZBEKISTAN Travel vlog with Lexie Limitless
description:
When looking up things to do in Uzbekistan, I came across a small article about a little ski lift about 45 minutes outside of Tashkent. Lexie Alford and I only had a couple days here before continuing to Turkmenistan, and I thought this would be a hilarious Fearless and Far journey to make my first and only Uzbekistan Travel Vlog. 

We start off in Tashkent, the capital city of Uzbekistan, and drove to Beldersay, a tiny resort on the side of Mount Chimgan. We didn't know what to expect when we arrived there, but we found CHEAP rental prices and very little english.

We went to go Snowboarding in Uzbekistan, but my highlight was the group of middle age Uzbek women illegally sliding on plastic bags at the top. That and the view... the view was incredible.

Lexie and I got wrecked on the icy off-season slopes, snowboarding fails everywhere, but it was a helluva lot of fun.

title: PRISMAS BASALTICOS IN HUASCA DE OCAMPO MEXICO
description:
The more I travel through Mexico, the more I love it. This is a small adventure just a few hours from CDMX. These are called the Prismas Basalticos and they are a series of waterfalls near the Pueblo Magico of Huasca de Ocampo in the state of Hidalgo. In English, they are called Basaltic Prisms of Santa Mar√≠a Regla, but I'm guessing that doesn't come up very often, because there can't be too many English Speakers that visit this place.

This type of rock is called Columnar Basalt, and it‚Äôs really rare. Some other famous locations with this type of stone is the Giant's Causeway in Ireland, and Fingal's Cave in Scotland. It‚Äôs caused when Lava cools very quickly and fractures. The phenomenon is called Columnar Jointing, and it's pretty damn cool.
Here, a river eroded into a small canyon and revealed this hidden attraction underneath. It might not be at the top of the Must See list, but it's very beautiful. Especially if you into Geology, Landscape Photography, or Waterfalls. This is a unique combination of a lot of things.

We paid about 50 pesos each for an entrance fee, and you can see the whole place in about an hour, it‚Äôs not that big. I‚Äôd also recommend arriving really early or really late in the day. It was busy even though it was cloudy, but we basically had it to ourselves at 4pm

This is one of many things to do in this area. We also checked out a really cool viewpoint called Pena del Cuervo that was nearby:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=twXYS_duaWo

Like I said above, I‚Äôm constantly amazing by the wonderful, strange, beautiful places and things Mexico keeps surprising me with. Here‚Äôs a playlist of our adventures so far:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NFlwMRkyiXw&list=PLW_NNmw_ILi1lnVzIaqXEO0t4MkkTK-Z1

title: MEXICO: CANCUN BUNGEE JUMP
description:

title: MEXICO: COZUMEL NIGHT SCUBA DIVE
description:
In episode two of #ChallengeMike we jump into the darkness off Cozumel for a night time SCUBA dive. The world underwater changes once the sun sets. We crashed at the Presidente InterContinental Cozumel, and dove with their dive shop Scubadu. Great guys, and the dive site was called Paradise!

title: EXPLORING AN EXPLODED FLOUR FACTORY IN MEXICO CITY
description:
This abandoned flour factory in Mexico City was sent to a Urbex friend of mine, La Catapixia, by one of his subscribers. We jumped at the chance to explore this place. On google maps it looked amazing, but we didn't know how to enter. The plan would be to show up and find out. It would be an adventure.

The story of this abandoned building is that it exploded. Pretty dramatic right? If you think about what a flour factory does, it would receive bulk shipments of wheat, and then use a grinder to pulverize it into powder for your baking pleasure! If the building had poor ventilation, this powder would hang in the air. Why is that a problem? Google "Flour Explosion" and you'll find out. Kaboom.

The history of this place is a bit confusing. We were told by a few sources it had been abandoned for 50 years, but found paperwork inside dated as recently as 2003. The guard there didn't know too much about the place, his job was to just chill and keep people out who didn't have permission. There's a lot of abandoned places around CDMX, this one seems to get very little attention despite being absolutely beautiful. The grain silos especially, so happy we brought the drone (DJI MAVIC) along to shoot them from the air. 

It's been a while since I've posted an exploring vlog, but we've been doing a lot of filming as we travel around Mexico. Expect some more fun stuff soon. I love this country.

title: SOLO EXPLORING MAYAN TEMPLES AT NIGHT: YAXUNAH, MEXICO
description:
I wanted to exlpore a Mayan Temple at night, all by myself. I found one in between Cancun and Merida. One that rarely get any visitors, especially not after dark. After finishing the "Challenge Mike in Mexico' project in early 2016, I was left with an extra week to explore Yucatan. There are TONS of temples there. Some are excavated, polished up, and touristy... others empty and still claimed by the jungle.

title: INDONESIAN KIDS REACT TO FUNNY SNAPCHAT FILTERS
description:
I travelled through Indonesia showing kids snapchat for the first time. Their reaction was priceless. Turning their faces into rabbits, giving them make up, changing their voice was really funny
Some would react by trying to rub it off their face, some would run away screaming, other would just laugh! Either way, it was pretty hilarious for me. 

I was here with 29 other bloggers, travelling across the country for #Tripofwonders .Check it out on Instagram and twitter. I decided to make a sequel to my kids react to snapchat video in Madagascar. The first one was a hit and went viral, so I thought I'd make another. 

This was filmed on Kalimantan, Komodo, Bajo Sampela, Wangi Wangi, and Bali. 

If you're into this kind of Comedy, check out Kids react to Snapchat filters in Madagascar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HzQreRUhqpM

title: CANADIAN FOOD CHALLENGE WITH ALE IVANOVA, EXPLORING WITH JOSH AND EXPLORING WITH CODY
description:
The Canadian Food Challenge!

My homies Exploring with Josh and Exploring with Cody were in Mexico City (my new stomping ground) so I thought I'd surprise them with a Eating Canadian Food Challenge. We met up with my friend Ale Ivanova, and I pulled all the East Coast Canada treats out of my closet for this special occasion. Not all of them are delicious, which made it a bit funny. That's the point of a challenge!

I'm from the province of New Brunswick, and some of these are specialties from that area of the country. We call it the Maritimes, or Atlantic Canada. Here are the things we ate:

Chicken Bones - A Cinnamon and chocolate candy that people eat during Christmas.

Bloody Caesar - A Hangover drink with Clamato Juice (Clam+Tomato), vokda, and a bunch of other spices.

Dulse - A famous red seaweed that is dried on the shores of the ocean. Very salty, very fishy.

Maple Cream - A block of maple sugar, which is usually soft. This one is expired.

Poutine - aka Fat Salad. Maybe Canada's most famous dish. French Fries, Gravy, Cheese.... mmmmMmmmm

Did I forget some Canadian Specialties? Did we like some that you don't? Let's chat in the comments!

title: DISGUSTING TACO CHALLENGE (EYE, HEART, FACE TACOS) WITH EXPLORING WITH JOSH
description:
I've been living in CDMX for almost a year now, and am constantly impressed with Mexican street food. I knew Exploring with Josh wouldn't be shy to make a gross food challenge video, so we went to the local taqueria, and loaded up on some of the most weird and disgusting tacos we could find.

We came home with some crazy ones... heart, brain, face, fat, ear, heart... and more. We decided to eat 4 on his channel, and 4 on mine. It was a lot of organ meat, more than I've had in my life, and we barely got it down.

Josh's video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rCP6ihfzCEI

It ended up pretty funny, we almost threw up eating a couple them. We had planned to eat the tacos for dinner, but ended up getting stuck in Mexico City traffic and returned home too late, we lost the daylight. We made the decision to film in the morning, I'm not sure if that was the best idea. Our reactions might have been a bit different.

Also, Josh had to get on a plane 2 hours later. We were betting he was going to end up puking in the airplane bathroom. He was all good though! I've done some spicy food challenges before, so I thought we'd try something a bit different in this vlog. What do you think? Would you try any of these nasty taco flavours? How would you react?

title: PUERTO RICO: ABANDONED PIER SCUBA DIVE WITH TURTLES
description:
Mosquito Pier off Vieques, Puerto Rico is a kickass site for Scuba diving or snorkeling. People usually travel here for Mosquito Bay and it's bioluminescent water, but this particular dive site should be put on the list too. Turtles everywhere, and really unique! I was there early 2016 and loved it.

If you're looking for tours, activities, or things to do on Vieques for your holidays, there's actually quite a lot here. The island has a lot of old abandoned military infrastructure, and you can visit some very cool rusty chunks of history just off some of the main roads. 

Abandoned Bunkers. Trains covered in Vines. Old factories reclaimed by nature. I had a blast on this little island, and after a week of exploring, was sad to leave.

SCUBA or a Snorkel are my favourite. Diving with Black Beard Sports was great. They seem to be leading the pack on the island for underwater adventures, and I highly recommend them. If you you haven't checked out my Bio Bay tour video I made with them, you should! It's right here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwfG9s1A8pI

title: AMAZON JUNGLE ADVENTURE CHALLENGE VLOG - EP. 1
description:
A new travel vlog series! A couple months ago, my friend and filmmaker buddy Caspar Diederik and I decided to take on a crazy challenge together.

We had finished a giant project in Germany together a few years ago, and never took that trip to celebrate the accomplishment. We decided to try something a little bit different, and sign up for a Adventure Challenge through the Amazon Rain Forest. 5 teams competed against each other for a week in the heart of the jungle. Swimming, Paddling, Hiking, Eating, every day was a new challenge. At the end, there was a winner.

We started off in the little town of Leticia in Colombia, then eventually crossed the border to both Peru and Brazil. I arrived a day late to begin the challenge, as I was trying to fly from Berlin to Leticia, and there were airport strikes in Europe. I made it to join on the night of day 1, and was greeted with a hell of a welcome party. Everyone was relaxing at a shaman's hut, trying Mambe and Rape. Powdered Coca leaves, and powdered tobacco. It was INTENSE, and gave you a huge head rush. The shaman sung as well all fell asleep that night in his giant hut. It was a great first night. The challenge started on day 2 for me, and that's where the story begins.

The company who ran this challenge is called Large Minority. They have a several amazing race style trips around the world. The Lanka Challenge in Sri Lanka, which teams race in Tuk Tuks around the country. The Cambo Challenge, which is a similar race around Cambodia, the Philippines Challenge, which is sailing, and the new addition was the Amazon Challenge.

It was a wild experience. Like I said at the end of the video. I thrive off adventures like this. Leaping out of your comfort zone, into the mud, allows you to come back home a better, more bullet proof version of yourself.

Did we win? Did we lose? Stay tuuuuuuuuned!

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

‚ô• Friends ‚ô•

My talented teammate, Caspar Diederik of Story Travelers, check out his films. He also shot some of the video featured in this series. https://www.youtube.com/user/StoryTravelers

Large Minority creates adventure challenges around the world. Philippines, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, and now the Amazon. This  was one of the most immersive organized experiences I've had. We were deep in the jungle and I loved every minute of it. Take a peek at their races here: https://www.largeminority.travel/

title: What's Your Excuse To Not Travel the World?
description:
Why aren't you travelling the world? What can you do today to get started? What's the problem? Money? Time? What's the excuse?

I got some friends together and we created this video. Some of you may not like it, it might make you feel uncomfortable, that's ok. It might make you angry, and that we don't understand... that's ok too. For many of us we were once at that point too. We just want you to look at your excuses, and really ask yourself, are these real? 
I know that some of you have legitimate reasons, and some need to think twice. We hope that this will help a few people off the fence. Changing your attitude is the real way to travel the world.

Many of life's obstacles can be overcome. Breaking goals down into small steps is how big dreams come true. A dollar a day in a bank account does more than make 30 dollars a month, it plants a seed that changes how you think. The idea behind this video is to give you some Motivation and Inspiration to make a change in your life. To join us.

There are hundreds of thousands of people making the sacrifices they need to, to be able to see the world. Why aren't you one of them?

We filmed this in Leipzig, Germany. There's a great event there called The Video Summit. http://www.videosummitleipzig.com/ Check it out if you're into Travel Video.

title: I was SCARED to speak for YEARS... Now it's my Job? | MOTIVATIONAL VIDEO
description:
This is a secret I've never told publicly. I'm sure many people won't believe it, but it's true. I was terrified to speak for most of my life.

Now it's job is to speak on camera... every day... to millions of people. As an adventure travel YouTuber and travel tv host, Getting over this fear has been one of the biggest and most rewarding challenges of my life. I thought it was about time I made a video about it. I want to talk about a side of my life that few have heard about. 

I had just finished recording a Podcast called "Living Vividly" with the Guys from Vivid Roots. This inspired me to make a full length video about it.

Those who spent the majority of their life silent, sometimes have more to say than everyone else. I feel that this is my case. A couple terrible events in my childhood really set me up for experiencing a lot of social anxiety in high school. Fear was part of my everyday life. 

But what if you could change your relationship with that feeling?
The usual reaction to fear, is more fear. It's like a roaring fire, and we just add more and more to the flame. Our mind spins, we lose control and fear takes the wheel. It's not a good driver. It doesn't think about tomorrow, nor what's best for you, nor what your long term goals are.

Through travel, I was able to encounter experiences that allowed me to challenge the terror that was holding me back from being my best self. 

I wanted to share some of this motivation with you, in hopes you can make a more knowledgeable decision when you find yourself in a similar position.

Let me know what you think of the inspirational video, let's all live a life that's free!

title: EATING PICKLED PIG FEET | PATITAS DE CERDO IN GUANAJUATO MEXICO
description:
Pickled Pigs Feet! (Patitas de Cerdo) I did not ever think I'd find something like this in Mexico. We stumbled across these in Celaya, Guanajuato and I had to make a vlog about it. Trying strange street food is a hobby of mine. The weirder the better. I think we all need to try things once, including food.

Mexican Food is on the rise. With many popular chefs and travel TV hosts praising it's diversity and complexity far beyond Nachos and Burritos, it will be no time before it becomes world famous. I agree with them all.

We were visiting the Mexican state of Guanajuato to see the Mummy Museum (Museo de Momias), as well as the Exploding Hammer Festival near Celaya. As a fun little activity, we went to a market to learn how to make Gorditas, a Mexican street food whose main component is a stuffed corn tortilla. Beside this little gorditas stand was a lady selling strange things in jars. I was curious and asked. She then pulled out all kids of different feet... and I just had to try one and vlog it.

How did it taste?

I think my reaction said it all. It was quite slimy and tasted a bit like sour stewed chicken. I realize it was pork, but I didn't really taste like it. How it melted into jello in my mouth made me react the way I did. Taste-wise ok. Texture-wise... Nasty. I don't think I would try it again!

Would you?

title: Men should be Wise and Interesting #travel #adventure
TOP 6 STRANGE PLACES TO VISIT IN 2018 (BEFORE THEY CHANGE) | TRAVEL GUIDE
description:
Jump into 2018 with me as I show my Top 5 (+1) places I visited this past year. On Kick the Grind, we travel to strange, unique, and amazing places. We search out the best travel experiences, and I've picked my top recommendations for your travel plans this year.

Real travel experiences are harder and harder to come by these days. I have to search pretty hard to find the gems. Big ups to Vice Magazine and Atlas Obscura for the inspiration this past year. These are all places to visit before you die, and some of the most amazing places I've come across in 2017.

----

#1 The Haro Wine fight

Also known as La Batalla de Vino, this crazy festival happens every year on June 29th in the small town of Haro in Rioja, Basque Country, Spain. For a little under an hour, locals pour hundreds of gallons of delicious Spanish red wine on each other to celebrate a Patron Saint.

VIDEO LINK: NONE

----

#2 The Baby Jumping Festival

Simply known as El Colacho to the locals of the small town of Castrillo de Murcia, Burgos, Spain. This cool festival involves a man dressed as a yellow devil whipping teenagers and jumping over newborn babies. On the surface it seems crazy and reckless... Who would ever put their baby on the street to be jumped over?

The reality is quite beautiful, and extra care is taken with the babies. When El Colacho (the devil) jumps over the baby, it is very similar to a baptism. The child is cleansed of the natural sin we are all born with, and it's a very exciting day for the family of the children.

The festival takes place on the first Sunday after Corpus Christi, so June 3rd in 2018

VIDEO LINK: https://youtu.be/bXXgB06y5xU

----

#3 The Exploding Hammer Festival

This festival is unbelievable. Men strap homemade explosives on sledgehammers and slam them into a field of small rocks. They do this every February 28th in the tiny Mexican Town of San Juan de la Vega in Guanajuato, Mexico to celebrate John the Baptist.

VIDEO LINK: https://youtu.be/vB9IdhcFAvY

----

#4 Toraja Regency Funeral Rites

Easily one of wildest travel experiences. The Torajan people of Central Sulawesi have very incredible rituals and beliefs around death. 

When someone dies, they are simply called "sick" and are kept in the house of the family. They are still treated like they are very much alive. Food is bought to them, music is played, the family comes to ask them questions.

When ready, the family has a extremely elaborate and expensive funeral to send them off to the afterlife. Experiencing this will change your life, and also your views on death.

If you'd like to see a Ma Ne'Ne, which is the opening of the coffins and is commonly called "The Waking Dead Festival" you have to visit in August or September. Also this is the time of year to see the Funerals. It is the best time to see these amazing funeral rites.

VIDEO LINK: COMING SOON

----

#5 Nido De Quetzalcoatl

Easily the Coolest AirBnn in Mexico (or maybe the world) this giant snake building is tucked into a small valley in Naucalpan, Mexico State. Javier Senosiain created this amazing structure while following his principles of Organic Architecture; building with natural shapes and forms, while respecting the surrounding environment. 

AirBnb Link: https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/10153978

VIDEO LINK: COMING SOON

----

#6 Amazonian Traditional Medicine

Slowly becoming mainstream is a big threat to experiencing real Amazonian Medicine with a legitimate shaman. As more and more people seek out these spiritual experiences, the more unqualified people want to take money from tourists. Asking locally is usually a better way to find what you're looking for. A friend and I went to Leticia, Colombia to find these experiences.

RAP√â AND AYAHUASCA VIDEO LINK: https://youtu.be/1BCwoAtW8Ak
KAMB√î VIDEO LINK: https://youtu.be/_ejHkW4yIyg

title: EATING PICKLED CHICKEN FEET | PATITAS DE POLLO IN MEXICO
description:
Eating strange foods while I travel has always been a guilty pleasure of mine. The more weird, slimy, gross, nasty ... the better.

I think it's amazing that the locals think these things are normal. Who's to say who's taste buds are right? I think we react too quickly to new street foods!

We were visiting the Mexican state of Guanajuato to see the Mummy Museum (Museo de Momias), as well as the Exploding Hammer Festival near Celaya. As a fun little activity, we went to a market to learn how to make Gorditas, a Mexican street food whose main component is a stuffed corn tortilla. Beside this little gorditas stand was a lady selling strange things in jars. I was curious and asked. She then pulled out all kids of different feet... and I just had to try one and vlog it.

How did it taste? Like chicken flavoured gummy bears... Like 20 day old chicken left to dry on a car dashboard, then soaked in vinegar. My reaction was decent I think.

Mexico is an amazing place for street food. I would rank it equal to Thailand. On top of the 100 or so different street foods I've found so far, It seems there is no end the variations on each of them from state to state. Chicken feet was a brand new one I associated with Asia beforehand. 

Mexico you always surprise me. Would anyone else try these?

title: EXPLORING NATURE IN LOS CABOS MEXICO WITH CAJAFRESCA
description:
Los Cabos is much more than it seems! Cajafresca and I were sent on a mission to vlog and explore the natural side of Baja California Sur, Mexico. This area is world famous for all-inclusive hotels, partying, and over consumption of tequila. We vowed not to get distracted by the obvious fun, and explore the world famous natural attractions; Whale Watching, Bird Watching, Snorkeling with Whale Sharks... Tons of stuff to do. This trip was an adventure.

Big love to Grupo Presidente, Interjet, and the Holiday Inn Los Cabos for creating this project for us. Awesome brands to check out.

First stop was bird watching and exploring Estero San Jose which was right beside our hotel (here: https://bit.ly/HIRLosCabos) I was amazed how many species there are here! It's a very important stopping point for many of the migratory species travelling from Northern North America, to the south. There were quiet a few Canadian birds I recognized as well. This was cut short by a turtle sighting. My personal highlight

Whale watching was incredible. I've had been a few times in Canada, but this was one of the best experiences I've had with these animals. Since the Gulf of California is basically a crack in the earth, the beaches drop off very quickly into the depths. Whales can get very close to shore allowing awesome viewing (even from the beach) We went near Cabo San Lucas, wish I could have spent more time there.

Swimming with Whale Sharks was almost an extreme sport. They are the biggest fish in the world, and they eat plankton, one of the smallest. They move deceptively fast despite their slow movements. When swimming with them, the boat drops you off slight in front of them. Your job is to slide into the water, find the shark, and try to keep up.

We had a great time, and we hope you did too!

title: EXPLORING RUINS OF ABANDONED MEDIEVAL TOWN | TRAVEL VLOG IN ESCO SPAIN
description:
This beautiful abandoned town is one of many located on the banks of the Yesa Reservoir in Northern Spain. Constructed sometime in the 11th or 12th century, Esco ( or Esc√≥) was abandoned 50 years ago because of the decision to dam a nearby river.

Exploring this location was on my urbex wish list, the bright blue water, and crumbling cathedral caught my eye, and I was hoping we could head that direction and make a travel vlog about it.

When we arrived to the ruins, we found exactly the experience we were looking for. No one was there, and we could explore in peace. Generally these places have a scary, or haunted vibe to them. Esco was peaceful, beautiful, and completely in ruins. 

Every house was abandoned except one, where a local sheep farmer had repaired one enough to live in. A man alone, living in a ghost town.

This abandoned city was a wild adventure. Soooo happy we could get into the tower. It made the trip. What do you think? Should I have walked on the wooden floor?

title: AMAZON JUNGLE ADVENTURE CHALLENGE VLOG - EP. 4
description:
Episode 4 of the Amazon Jungle Challenge! 

In this episode Caspar and I get dropped off on the stilt town of Islandia, and have to complete challenges with locals.

Here's the playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi2zdP9tvrLMOuomRSk82IH2

And some background of what this series is about. 
A couple months ago, my friend and filmmaker buddy Caspar Diederik and I decided to take on a crazy challenge together.

We had finished a giant project in Germany together a few years ago, and never took that trip to celebrate the accomplishment. We decided to try something a little bit different, and sign up for a Adventure Challenge through the Amazon Rain Forest. 5 teams competed against each other for a week in the heart of the jungle. Swimming, Paddling, Hiking, Eating, every day was a new challenge. At the end, there was a winner.

The company who ran this challenge is called Large Minority. They have a several amazing race style trips around the world. The Lanka Challenge in Sri Lanka, which teams race in Tuk Tuks around the country. The Cambo Challenge, which is a similar race around Cambodia, the Philippines Challenge, which is sailing, and the new addition was the Amazon Challenge.

It was a wild experience. Like I said at the end of the video. I thrive off adventures like this. Leaping out of your comfort zone, into the mud, allows you to come back home a better, more bullet proof version of yourself.

Did we win? Did we lose? Stay tuuuuuuuuned!

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

‚ô• Friends ‚ô•

My talented teammate, Caspar Diederik of Story Travelers, check out his films. He also shot some of the video featured in this series. https://www.youtube.com/user/StoryTravelers

Large Minority creates adventure challenges around the world. Philippines, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, and now the Amazon. This  was one of the most immersive organized experiences I've had. We were deep in the jungle and I loved every minute of it. Take a peek at their races here: https://www.largeminority.travel/

title: MEXICO: SCUBA DIVING AN AMAZING SHIPWRECK GUNBOAT 58
description:
This Wreck dive in Mexico was incredible. There's a ton of amazing things to see right of the coast of Isla Mujeres if you are into Scuba.

This shipwreck was called Gunboat 58, and it was Eagle Ray mating season when we did the dive. It was a deep dive, so it was a bit shorter than I'd like, but was super happy with what I was able to capture. I have not seen beauty like that before.

BIG Thanks to Pocna Dive Hostel on Isla Mujeres http://www.pocna.com Go play in the water, and check them out while you're there!

title: AMAZON JUNGLE ADVENTURE CHALLENGE VLOG - EP. 2
description:
Episode 2 of the Amazon Jungle Challenge! 

Check out the first epidodes if you haven't already. We wake up from our first night sleeping in our jungle shelter. Cas and I put some extra time in the night before making it extra special for the judges before discovering the winner at breakfast. Here, we also find out that today's challenge is the "indigenous olympics" with spear throwing, boat racing, blow dart shooting, and other local sports. Part of the entry fee of the challenge goes to supporting some of these remote local communities we visit. We delivered over 100 backpacks with school supplies to kids in the Tikuna Village. They were stoaked :)

Here's the playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW_NNmw_ILi2zdP9tvrLMOuomRSk82IH2

And some background of what this series is about. 
A couple months ago, my friend and filmmaker buddy Caspar Diederik and I decided to take on a crazy challenge together.

We had finished a giant project in Germany together a few years ago, and never took that trip to celebrate the accomplishment. We decided to try something a little bit different, and sign up for a Adventure Challenge through the Amazon Rain Forest. 5 teams competed against each other for a week in the heart of the jungle. Swimming, Paddling, Hiking, Eating, every day was a new challenge. At the end, there was a winner.

The company who ran this challenge is called Large Minority. They have a several amazing race style trips around the world. The Lanka Challenge in Sri Lanka, which teams race in Tuk Tuks around the country. The Cambo Challenge, which is a similar race around Cambodia, the Philippines Challenge, which is sailing, and the new addition was the Amazon Challenge.

It was a wild experience. Like I said at the end of the video. I thrive off adventures like this. Leaping out of your comfort zone, into the mud, allows you to come back home a better, more bullet proof version of yourself.

Did we win? Did we lose? Stay tuuuuuuuuned!

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

‚ô• Friends ‚ô•

My talented teammate, Caspar Diederik of Story Travelers, check out his films. He also shot some of the video featured in this series. https://www.youtube.com/user/StoryTravelers

Large Minority creates adventure challenges around the world. Philippines, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, and now the Amazon. This  was one of the most immersive organized experiences I've had. We were deep in the jungle and I loved every minute of it. Take a peek at their races here: https://www.largeminority.travel/

title: MANTA POINT SCUBA DIVING IN INDONESIA
description:
Manta Rays, Whoa. This was shot while SCUBA diving in Nusa Penida, Bali, Indonesia. There's a great dive site called Manta Point. We saw 8 Rays! Since I can remember, this animal has been at the top of my wish list. They didn't disappoint, it was a helluva show. I was staying in Sanur on mainland Bali, and met up with Blue Season Bali to take the boat together. You can stay on Nusa Penida, or Nusa Lembongan, but most dive shops leave from the mainland, as the sites really aren't much closer if you stay on the other two islands.

title: ANT EGG Ice Cream? | Strange Mexican Food | Helado de ESCAMOLES Taste Test
description:
After eating some amazing traditional Mexican Food with Dan of The New Travel, we went for dessert... Escamole ice cream aka ant egg ice cream at Tlacoyotitlan. Mexican sweets and Mexican dessert are usually delicious. We weren't sure about this one!

Tlacoyotitlan is a restaurant in colonia Santa Maria la Ribera in CDMX. In the centre of this neighbourhood there is a beautiful Kiosko where locals usually dance in the afternoon. This amazing restaurant in Mexico City is right beside this plaza and has some of the best Garnachas (Mexican street food), and best insect dishes I have had in the city.

In the previous video, The New Travel and I, had the Huarache Ancestral. A large corn tortilla filled with beans, topped with Chapulines (grasshoppers), Cocopaches (beetles), Gusano de Maguey (big worms), Chiliquiles (little worms), escamoles (ant larvae) and a tasty little scorpion on top.

What do you think? Would you give ant egg ice cream a taste test? I wouldn't say it's the best ice cream I've ever had, but was really surprised by the experience. It was pretty damn good!

title: SEAWEED HUNTING IN SCOTLAND | ADVENTURE TRAVEL VLOG
description:
After diving for scallops and surfing in a kayak, I ended up on the island of Easdale, home to the world rock skimming (skipping) championship, and Duncan, the resident seaweed specialist.

Growing up on Canada‚Äôs East Coast, I‚Äôve played around in the North Atlantic Ocean a few times before. I also studied seaweeds in a course called Phycology at my university. I can‚Äôt say I went in knowing nothing, but I was rusty at best. Duncan had a whole afternoon lined up for us. Identifying, foraging, cutting, eating, and eventually cooking all sorts of different Algae, even one that tasted like Bacon!

Learn more about this area of Scotland: http://bit.ly/KtG_Scotland

title: SWIM WITH MANATEES IN FLORIDA. THREE SISTERS SPRINGS
description:
I've always wanted to Swim with Manatees.
I was in Florida for a conference what was quite close to Crystal River. The Manatee Hotspot. Three Sisters Springs is one of the only places in the world you can swim with these beautiful Sea Cows. I connected with River Ventures and my friend Kiersten of The Blonde Abroad and we made the trip. It was a beautiful underwater experience. You've got to try swimming with Manatees, I never thought we'd be able to get so close!

It's quite a special place actually. Besides the fact that hundreds of these animals huddle in this area to stay warm in the winter, it's the only place in the USA where you are legally allowed to swim with them. We had a kickass time. Would love to go back, this was shot during the off season, and there was no issue finding them. With cold water, there would have been many many more.

title: SCUBA DIVING WITH TARPON IN XCALAK MEXICO
description:
Xcalak, Mexico is a bit far off the beaten path. While quite close to Tulum, Playa del Carmen, and Cancun, rarely do tourists venture further south than the cruise ship town of Mahahual.

When you get to this sleepy beach town, you'll realize there's not too much there. A few tiendas selling groceries, a taco shop, and also... one of the nicest PADI dive shops I've ever seen.

I had watched a few videos of swimming with Crocodiles and Sailfish, scuba dives I didn't think you could do in Mexico, also I had my eye on diving a remote island reef called Banco Chinchorro. I investigated how to do each, and they all traced back to XTC diveshop in Xcalak.

During this time of year (April) the main attraction was diving with Tarpon, a huge 2 meter long silver-sided fish, that is often quite a trophy for fishermen. Here, fishing was off the table, but diving with these giants was in full season

During my stay here I ended up diving the site twice, as well as many other surrounding dive sites. This is one video of a few showcasing the diving in and around Xcalak and Banco Chinchorro. 

Thoughts on what I said at the end of the video? How much more diving do you want to see on this channel? Should I make a second one?

title: 86,402 Seconds in Madagascar
description:
Help me save the lemurs. 
Donate: https://www.crowdrise.com/86402secondsinmadagascar

I'm in Madagascar with the CrowdRise 24-hour Impact Project. We have one day to raise $10,000 to save the Greater Bamboo Lemur, a critically endangered species. There are only 500 left on earth and 100 of them are on the brink of destruction. Please donate to my fundraiser. If you give today, I'll immediately start working on-the-ground in Madagascar to save these lemurs.

Give today. See impact tomorrow.

Big love to the Centre ValBio in Ranomafana National Park. This project is their brainchild, and we are more than happy to help them! http://www.stonybrook.edu/commcms/centre-valbio/station.html

Hosting/Filming: Mike Corey (Me!)
Producer/Director/Creator: Mallory Brown
Filming/Editing/Video Production: Ryan Doyle https://www.facebook.com/VideoVision360
Photography: Malu Veltze

title: KAYAK SURFING IN ARGYLL, SCOTLAND | ADVENTURE TRAVEL VLOG
description:
When I landed on the Kintyre Coast in Argyll and Bute, Scotland... I didn't even know Kayak Surfing was a thing that people do on this planet. Adventure travel is my thing. I'm always trying to search out the strange and unique activities, but I had never heard a whisper of this one before. 

When I arrived to meet Andy Craven, I overlooked the man with the kayaks completely, and continued to drive around looking for a guy with surfboards, all I knew I was doing that morning was "surfing".

This day turned out to be one of the most fun I've ever had on the water. It's not an easy sport, but it's a ton of fun. We dressed up in wetsuits, rain jackets, helmets and life jackets and proceeded the paddle headfirst into a pretty big swell. Within the first 5 minutes we flipped, but that turned out to be a big part of the fun. Getting tumbled and flipped by the ocean was such a wild ride, and when we did end up catching waves it just felt like a bonus.

This HAS to go on your bucketlist if you are an adventure lover. We had a complete blast!

Learn more about this area of Scotland: http://bit.ly/KtG_Scotland

title: UNDERWATER FILMMAKING WORKSHOP 2018 | COZUMEL, MEXICO
description:
Heyhey!

I've teamed up with my friends at diveandmore.com to offer an 8-day underwater filmmaking workshop in Quintana Roo, Mexico.

We'll be launching June 30th 2018 from Cozumel, and during this time we'll be scuba diving it's towering coral reefs, then heading to the mainland to explore cenotes, the Mayan gateways to the underworld, and finally swimming with whale sharks along the coast.

I've been diving for 10 years, and spent the last 6 years as a professional travel filmmaker. On top of all the incredible diving, I'll be teaching you my tips and tricks on how to make better travel videos though 3 1-hour lessons, and private one on one's. 

If you aspire to be an adventure travel vlogger, a youtuber, a scuba filmmaker, or just edit something awesome to show your family and friends... there's no doubt you'll pick up a useful skillset to be able to do any of the above.

I absolutely love Mexico, especially the underwater world. I moved to the country a year ago, and can't wait to share it with you.

Looking forward to seeing you in Cozumel!

----------------------------------------¬≠¬≠¬≠--------------------------------------¬≠-¬≠-¬≠---------------

Sign up is here: http://diveandmore.com/upcoming-dive-trips/underwater-video-workshop/

title: PROJECT UPDATE: A GOOD ONE COMING UP NEXT!
description:
Hey yo!
I haven't done one of these in a while, and this one I'm excited about!
I'm teaming up with some friends - Grupo Presidente, Interjet, and Ale Ivanova. We're joining forces with Illuminemos de Azul por el Autismo to make some dreams come true. Three kids and their parents will be given a trip from Mexico City to Cozumel to see the ocean for the first time. Life for these families is tough, the children have all been born with Autism, and the parents have to work very hard for little money to help support their condition. It's not too much to say that there's a chance they could live their entire life without ever seeing the ocean. 

I can't wait to show them something that is so powerful in my life. The sea means an incredible amount to me, and I cannot imagine a life without it. I'm honoured to be working with these great people to make dreams come true. 

Can't wait to share :)

title: FROG VENOM, MUMMIES, AND TATTOOS - WHAT'S NEXT ON KtG
description:
I've been gone for a bit!
Instead of waiting for Wednesday to jump back on the weekly videos, I thought I'd update everyone with what's coming up in the next few weeks. 

It's been a wild past month... Mexico, Germany, Brazil, Peru, Colombia, and now I'm back and just recovering from a Malaria scare. I'll take the Flu with a smile!

So, let's quit the chit chat. Coming up next on Kick the Grind!

Kamb√≥ - Traditional medicine from the Brazilian Amazon. Warriors and hunters used to do this to prepare for the hunt/war. It also supposedly gives your immune system a huge jolt and makes you more beautiful. Also... it makes you extremely sick.

The Mummies of Guanajuato - Seriously one of the most morbid and creepy places I've been. (And you know from this channel I've seen some pretty wild stuff around the world) The mummies of the Mexican state have a crazy story!

The Amazon Challenge - My friends over at Large Minority Adventure Challenges set us up with a one week race through the amazon rainforest during rainy season. It was intense, and one of the best experiences I've had in South America. I vlogged my way through it.

Getting a Sleeve Tattoo - A couple years ago I decided I wanted to do this. It took me several years to decide what I wanted, find the right artist, and also be in one spot long enough to complete it. It takes 30-40 hours over several months to finish a sleeve. I made it happen in Mexico City

____ _____ - A very difficult to access abandoned location in Mexico City. I met a new friend La Catapixia (check out his urbex channel) and he got us in. We have to keep it secret for a few weeks. Shhhh.

As always that you all so much for the love and support. The channel has grown so much in the past year, and as it does so, it allows me to show you more and more amazing things around the world.
